PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW BUSINESS AFTER 11 P.M.: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing order 48A, as amended by sessional order, relating to the adjournment of the House, and standing order 103 (11 o'clock rule) be suspended for this sitting.

I indicated to the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair) yesterday that it was my desire to move this motion today. We have a certain amount of business which I am desirous of the House of Representatives dealing with this week in order that the Senate can deal with the same matters in the week it sits when the House of Representatives will not be sitting. This will allow people who are listed to speak during the program today and tomorrow to do so, which is the normal procedure. It will give us the additional time we require to complete our business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not resist the concept of sitting on Wednesday evenings towards the end of this session. We understand that the Government has a volume of legislation and that, with the prospect of sitting in the first week of December, there is an advantage for us all if we can sit on Wednesday night, have a normal dinner adjournment and then rise perhaps earlier than might otherwise have been the case. However, there are a couple of aspects to this motion which people need to understand and to which we are opposed. The first is that standing order 103 relates to the introduction of new business after 11 p.m. At the moment we are not aware of any new business that has to be introduced after 11 o'clock. We are not inclined to accept that, even in ordinary circumstances, it is desirable for this place to sit after 11 o'clock. Given the extraordinary hours we are now sitting, whereby we sit for a fortnight with very long and demanding hours applicable to honourable members, there is every reason why the House should rise, as far as possible, at 11 o'clock.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the House (Mr Young) would know, a predecessor of his, a former honourable member for Grayndler, introduced the fairly arbitrary rule that the House rise by 11 o'clock. For our part we would far prefer that rule to be retained. We are opposed to the suspension of standing order 103 for the rest of this sitting on the basis that it might be required. If there is a reason for the standing order to be suspended, we would be prepared to consider it on that basis. But at the moment we are being told that the Government might want it and that it just wants to cover its flank. Frankly, that is not good enough. It is for that reason we will oppose this motion.

In addition, it would be desirable between now and the end of this year that we perhaps also look at the sitting pattern for next year. An increasing number of honourable members are not altogether content with the present sitting hours. I do not know whether the Government has had any survey conducted within its ranks, but the Leader of the House will recall that, prior to the introduction of the two-week on, two-week off sitting pattern, there was a great deal of deliberation about the pros and cons of that sitting pattern. I know that there are honourable members, particularly from Western Australia and more remote places, who certainly like the idea of having the fortnight off. However it is interesting that there are many who nonetheless go home on the weekend, so that in between times the advantage of staying in Canberra is virtually not being pursued.

In that climate I am not too sure of the basis of opinion in the House. I have in mind, if the Leader of the House is not pursuing the matter, that we might discuss it within our joint parties to see what the attitude is towards the fortnight on, fortnight off sitting roster. It certainly creates a lot of problems for members in many respects in that short weekend, for when they wish to pursue their normal electoral functions they do not get home until too late to attend most functions on the Friday night. To try to get to one's electorate office on a Saturday morning is just about impossible. Those of us who have rural electorates have to make an election as to which town we are going to because physically we cannot attend more than one town. Whereas in the past many used to go to their electorate offices on a Monday morning, that opportunity is now denied. I think it would be worth while considering for next year whether we ought to revert to the alternative sitting pattern which for so long applied in this place. I think there are within the Parliament quite a few people of that mind. I would be interested to hear the intention of the Leader of the House in that matter.

As far as Ministers are concerned, the two-week on, two-week off pattern frankly must be hell. I do not know how they accommodate the problems of seeing those they are required to see, attending to their Cabinet deliberations, attending to their committee responsibilities, attending to their other Party responsibilities and also running a department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just very talented, that's all.

—You could have fooled me. I think that what happens is that the department tends to run them. We have so many of the Yes Minister variety in this Government that we are all beginning to see the product. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is making an absolute fool of himself over the Australian Bicentennial Authority. We are all very conscious that the implications of that are largely that the sitting hours are not suitable for a reasonable work input. I think that common sense, medical health and even reasonable concentration suggest that there is an advantage in changing the present sitting pattern. For that reason, apart from any other, I put to the Leader of the House that it would be desirable for some reconsideration of the whole question before the final sitting pattern is determined for next year. The Leader of the House has given me an assurance, but members of the coalition parties are interested to get as soon as possible full detail of the program which will take us to the rising of the House. We know that the Government is in trouble about getting all the legislation printed. Whether that is because of the Parliamentary Counsel or ineffective or inadequate instructions from Ministers is another thing, but we are interested in knowing what legislation will be introduced and we are also interested in the sitting pattern for next year. The Leader of the House, in a few words in answer to this, might give me some indication of what they are so that members of this place can pursue the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis that the motion seeks to suspend standing order 103, the 11 o'clock rule, for this sitting, members of the Opposition will be opposing it. As I say, we do not oppose sitting on Wednesday nights provided we rise at 11 o'clock, but I think most people, given the two-week sitting pattern, would far prefer that, whatever the other business of the House, we rise at 11 o'clock. I put it very strongly to the Leader of the House that that should be achieved whenever possible for the sake of everybody in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There are just a couple of things I should say in regard to the sitting pattern of the House. I understand from the Chairman of the Procedure Committee that that Committee is looking at bringing in some recommendations to the Government, after talking to a lot of people, regarding future sitting patterns. There is no doubt that on both sides of the House there is a very strong contingent of supporters for two weeks on, two weeks off, particularly among those who travel from a long way away-the Western Australians. I think those who represent Sydney and Melbourne electorates ought to have a little more thought for those who have to travel a long way from the Northern Territory, Western Australia or the top end of Queensland because it takes them quite a while to come down here.

SPEECH.PARA: I have undertaken to try to get to the Leader of Opposition Business the program until the end of the year. As he said, it depends very much on the draftsmen and how much of the work they can complete for the purposes of our having the legislation introduced into the Parliament and debated before we get up. I have indicated to him that it may well be necessary for us to sit for the first week of December, but we should know within the next week or so whether that will be necessary. I will give him the information as soon as I have it.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:SALES TAX (Nos. 1 to 4 AND 6 to 9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1985SALES TAX (No. 5) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill cognately with Sales Tax (Nos. 1 to 4) Amendment Bills, Sales Tax (No. 5) Amendment Bill (No. 2), Sales Tax (Nos. 6 to 9) Amendment Bills and Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a package of Bills to give effect to the changes in the wholesale tax schedules and the rate structure which were announced in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 19 September of so-called reforms of the Australian taxation system. We need to go back to the draft White Paper of June 1985 to see what was originally meant by the word `reform'. The centrepiece of the Government's brave approach to reform before and during the early stages of the July tax summit, as honourable members may recall, was a substantial broadening of the tax base to allow significant cuts in personal income tax. I quote from the overview paper that was put out with the draft White Paper in June 1985. These are the Government's words in the draft White Paper:

SPEECH.PARA: The main approaches to fundamental reform are to:
broaden the income base as much as possible and use the resultant revenue to lower marginal income tax rates; and
achieve much more substantial reductions in marginal income tax rates across-the-board by broadening the indirect tax base.
The overview paper goes on to state:

Important as it would be in helping to achieve worthwhile tax reform, any feasible broadening of the income tax in itself would not permit the Government to go far in lowering marginal income tax rates. These would remain discouragingly high and, correspondingly, incentives to evade and avoid tax would remain strong. It is the desirability of going further than this-and at the same time rationalising the consumption tax regime-that has led the Government to turn to possible approaches to broadening the indirect tax base.

In other words, what the Government is saying in its June White Paper is that the kinds of measures in the Treasurer's statement of 19 September are not nearly enough in order to achieve the kind of reform that is necessary to reduce personal income tax rates. In looking at what it might do beyond broadening the income tax base, the Government thought of two possible approaches or options. The overview paper states:

Two of a range of possible approaches to broadening the consumption tax base are discussed in some detail in the draft White Paper. Each is combined with the income base-broadening measures which make up approach A.
What is termed approach B would involve a dual consumption tax arrangement comprising:
a wholesale sales tax of 10 per cent in respect of passenger motor vehicles, wine, soft drinks and those goods in the current 32 1/2 per cent rate class; and
a broad-based consumption tax of 5 per cent (on virtually all goods and services, including those goods remaining subject to wholesale sales tax).
That was approach B, or option B as it became known. Of option B, it was stated:

The relatively modest revenue yield would, however, permit only modest changes in income tax rates, notwithstanding that a substantial change to the structure of the consumption tax base of the nation would be involved.

Approach C in the draft White Paper, which is the Government's preferred approach, would permit larger reductions in marginal income tax rates across-the-board as well as imposing a more significant tax burden-at the consumption level-on income which escapes income tax.
On the next page, it states:
Substantial net gains are possible for low and middle income groups, especially with approach C.
The Government's conclusion in the White Paper of June 1985 was:

The Government's present view, as expressed in the draft White Paper and based on the belief that the macroeconomic and other issues can be dealt with satisfactorily, is that approach C is the one best calculated to achieve the basic objectives of tax reform.

Option C, as it became known, was the object of an extensive sales effort on the part of the Treasurer and, at least initially, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Let me quote to the House what the Prime Minister said in June 1985:
We sought the clearest possible mandate for reform . . . We accept the responsibility conferred on us by the people.

To do otherwise-to attempt to shift or shelve our responsibilities-would be to turn our backs on all we stand for as a Government and as a party. But it would be more than that; in a very real sense we would be turning our backs on the people of Australia.
Also in June 1985 he announced that he would be willing to sacrifice government in order to secure meaningful tax reforms. He was quoted in the Age of 20 June as saying:
Well, if it costs me government . . . I would do it, because I don't want to take the easy way out . . .
If we pay a political price well, okay, but I believe that in the longer term Australia is going to be better off, that's the course I'll take.

But even before that, we began to see some of the crumbling away of the Prime Minister's support for the Treasurer when he was speaking to the Canadian economic summit in March. He appeared to step away from tax reform by saying:
. . . the government will not proceed with the legislation of a tax package which does not have broad community support.
He said further:

. . . we are not in the business of committing political suicide on this or any other issue . . . you've got to get a feeling of what's acceptable unless you want to be engaged in the process of political hari-kari.

The Treasurer might have taken heed of that if he had been careful, but the Treasurer continued, believing that he had the full support of the Prime Minister, to push the option C proposal. In early June the Treasurer said:
If we don't as a nation adopt this proposal, then you won't see significant reform in this country in taxation for the balance of this century.
A little later, the Treasurer, hinting even at his possible resignation if his campaign for tax reform failed, said:

If this sort of proposal doesn't get up, one has to decide if there's much point in someone like me worrying about the Australian institutional process, and in Australian institutions, very much longer.
Under attack in late June he said:
We're not shrinking violets and we're not about to disappear when the first whiff of grapeshot passes the trenches.
In a report in the Sydney Morning Herald the Treasurer gave this clear message to the Australian Labor Party's Left and Centre Left factions which are opposing a consumption tax:
So if any of our colleagues think that there may be some easy road to soft options, we're not about the soft path.
As late as Thursday of the National Taxation Summit the Treasurer said:
I am still pressing for a broad-based consumption tax.

But after the Prime Minister had gone off to make a deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions at a Canberra motel and after the Prime Minister had pulled the rug from under his Treasurer, the Treasurer said:
It's a bit like Ben Hur's-we got across the line with one wheel off.

On 13 August 1985, in a very sad Press conference, the Treasurer announced that the remainder of the consumption tax package was to be dumped as it was `unworkable and impracticable'. So the Prime Minister deserted his Treasurer at the Summit. He left Parliament House where the Summit was being held and went to a Canberra motel. He was summoned to meet the ACTU executive who had told him that it had never supported what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister had been putting up; that it was not going to have it; that the Government would have to come to heel and all that the Government would be allowed would be the nasties of option A of the draft White Paper. That is what the ACTU executive required of the Government. Of course, under the infamous ACTU-ALP accord it was necessary for the Government to meet those trade union demands.

So the Government was left with the punitive option A proposals for broadening the income tax base which had been subject to such grave criticism in its draft White Paper. These proposals certainly did not meet the Government's criteria for reform. I wish to quote again from the overview paper of June 1985 about option A where the paper states:

While helpful in making for greater equity in the system, such reductions in marginal rates are quite modest, particularly at lower levels, and the average wage and salary earner would be left facing a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent.

How prophetic that that should be in the White Paper because that is precisely what the Government has been left with after the ACTU has exacted its price. So in the package before us we have a capital gains tax, entertainment and fringe benefits taxes, the abolition of negative gearing on rental properties, limits on the write-off of farm losses against non-farm income, the abolition of the concessional expenditure rebate, and other higher taxing proposals, offset by a necessarily restricted set of concessions on marginal income tax rates and a new system of taxing dividends. Then there is that essential ingredient of taxation reform of which the Treasurer said:
If we don't as a nation adopt this proposal, then you won't see significant reform in this country in taxation for the balance of this century.

What of the proposal for an indirect tax that would give a net revenue yield, after compensating needy groups, of $6.8 billion and allow for substantial net gains for low and middle income groups? Well, here it is in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills: A minor rationalisation of the existing wholesale tax with a net revenue yield of not $6.8 billion but a lousy $75m, or about $110m in a full year. A wholesale sales tax indeed! It is the very tax that was treated with contempt by the draft White Paper. I quote from chapter 13 of the Paper what the Government was saying about the wholesale sales tax it now has as the only centrepiece of consumption tax in its overall package.

The existing WST is a narrowly-based tax which applies only to selected consumption goods and some intermediate goods. It does not cover any services and it has many anomalies and inconsistencies . . . Its lack of comprehensiveness in coverage, and its multiple tax rate structure, lead to a number of problems:
the narrow tax base means that higher tax rates are required to generate a given level of revenue;
the tax impacts differentially on various commodities and so interferes with consumption and production decisions;
individuals with the same income bear different tax burdens merely because they have different consumption patterns; and
the extent of commodity exemptions and the multiple tax rates lead to greatly increased administrative costs.
It goes on:
Even if some of the problems in the existing WST could be eliminated, the point remains that wholesale . . . taxes suffer from inherent problems:

tax is levied at the point of last wholesale sale so that the base excludes value added at the retail level-other things being equal, therefore, the tax base for a WST will be smaller than for a BBCT-
a broad-based consumption tax-
. . . levied at the point of final sale and the rates of tax will be higher;

a WST cannot be applied to services, which are normally provided at the retail level. This both limits the base and in the absence of a supplementary tax on services, distorts consumer choices and leads to inequities;
I am describing here, from the Government's own draft White Paper of June, all the criticisms of the measure that it is left with as the fag end of this tax package. The Paper goes on:

A WST is also susceptible to valuation problems because the tax is levied at the point of last wholesale sale. The value of that sale can be influenced by the inclusion or exclusion of transport or other services in the price of goods, with taxpayers having an incentive to exclude such services whenever possible. This further reduces the tax base relative to a VAT or BBCT which is levied at the point of final sale and is much less open to this kind of manipulation.

the integration of some wholesalers and retailers creates difficulties in establishing the appropriate value on which to charge tax. The traders who are most vertically integrated can shift profit margins beyond the point where the tax is applied and thereby gain a tax advantage;
Finally it states in relation to the wholesale sales tax:

will increase business costs to a greater extent than a retail sales tax with an equivalent revenue yield since retailers are required to carry stocks which include WST in their value, adding to their demand for working capital.
The Government concluded in this chapter of the draft White Paper:
The inherent and introduced limitations of the WST constitute strong arguments for its replacement by a new broad-based tax.

That is basically what the Government thought of this particular measure that we are facing in the House today. After one has heard all that, one can understand the Treasurer's despair at being left with only this miserable offering in the cupboard after it had been raided by the ACTU. One can also appreciate his effrontery in calling this tattered remnant of his grand design a far reaching reform.

Let us look at the remnant to see what it contains. It replaces the existing wholesale sales tax, which has a four rate structure of 7.5 per cent, 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 32.5 per cent, with three rates of 10, 20, and 30 per cent; a modest rationalisation. On the face of it this seems sensible. However, when one looks at the inclusions at each level, one gets the impression that the cards have been shuffled carelessly, leaving loads of glaring examples. Let us take the simple examples of biscuits and ice cream. I thought that the Government had rejected the idea of taxing basic food items. That was one of the demands of the ACTU; one of the things the unions said they would not wear. There was also a big outcry at the National Taxation Summit from social welfare groups and so on against taxing food. The Prime Minister said: `No, we will not tax food'. Let us look at the application of these taxes, the way they will be administered and the rather extraordinary thinking of the Treasury and the Taxation Office on this matter. The Treasurer, at page 50 of his statement of 19 September, said:
The present WST system taxes confectionery at 20 per cent while exempting close substitute products such as snack food, biscuits and ice cream.

That refers to close substitute products. It takes a peculiar sort of mind to equate biscuits and ice cream with confectionery. All those mums who keep biscuits in the cupboard and ice cream in the freezer as basic food items, but will allow their children lollies and chocolates only occasionally, will be amazed to learn that the Treasurer has slammed a 10 per cent sales tax on biscuits and ice cream yet has reduced the tax on lollies and chocolates from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. They are basic food items in every kitchen these days. The big ice cream container in the freezer is the basic standby for puddings when mum is too tired to make a fresh pudding or alternatively the children want a change. The ice cream is always there as a basic food item. Does the Treasurer never go around an ordinary supermarket and see cannister after cannister of bulk ice cream, which is now to be taxed at 10 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is living in a world of his own.

—He is absolutely out of touch with the ordinary reality of every kitchen. The shadow Treasurer goes down to the supermarket every weekend to have a look at the prices and find out what is going on. Always I see people with big trollies loaded up with ice cream and biscuits. Biscuits are a basic food item. They are not confectionery, they are not the same as chocolates. What do those people think they are doing? This lofty paper prepared in the inner recesses of the Canberra bureaucracy, brought in by the Treasurer, wants people to swallow the idea that ice cream and biscuits are not basic food items and will be taxed at 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time the Treasurer has removed entirely the tax on imported thoroughbred race horses. All the mums will be delighted at that. Ice cream is a $500m retail sales industry. It also supports in a very great way the dairying and sugar industries-two Australian industries in dire trouble. It has been estimated that some $6m of sales from those industries to the ice cream industry will be lost as a result of these measures. There is an absolute and basic insanity in this particular measure. I ask the Government to re-examine exactly what it has done in switching around these scales. It should look at exactly what is happening in the supermarkets and kitchens and also in those two distressed industries, the dairying and sugar industries.
Let us go on. A week or two ago there appeared an advertisement, of which some honourable members made a joke, which had a picture of the Treasurer and a picture of Senator Ryan, and it said:
Why should Senator Susan Ryan have to pay 50% more sales tax than Treasurer Paul Keating to be well-groomed?

Some people regarded that as a bit of a joke, but there is a very serious issue behind this. Why on earth should men's toiletries be taxed at 20 per cent and women's cosmetics be taxed at 30 per cent? I have here a list provided to me by a manufacturing company. I know, Madam Deputy Speaker, that you disapprove of some of what this company has done, and I note your concern; but that is unrelated to what I am saying, and the actual argument has to be addressed. This particular manufacturer of toiletries and cosmetics wants to know why Pears toilet soap is taxed at 20 per cent and Pears shampoo is taxed at 30 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about dog shampoo?

—I shall not give to the honourable member the obvious response to that; we shall come to that matter. Why should Menage after-shave be taxed at 20 per cent and Menage splash-on be taxed at 30 per cent? Why should fabric conditioner be taxed at 20 per cent and Sunsilk conditioner be taxed at 30 per cent? The honourable member will not be disappointed: Why should dog shampoo be taxed at 20 per cent and family shampoo be taxed at 30 per cent?
—But worse, it is put in the list of male toiletries. I should like to emphasise that there are female dogs.

—The honourable member is concerned because it is put in the list of male toiletries. It is a grave reflection on the behaviour of some members of this House if the honourable member thinks that there is some correlation. However, shaving cream is taxed at 20 per cent; depilatory cream is taxed at 30 per cent. Room deodorant is taxed at 20 per cent; Rexona deodorant is taxed at 30 per cent. Breath freshener is taxed at 20 per cent; Norsca cologne is taxed at 30 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I should have thought that the Prime Minister, in his concern for the status of women in Australia, would have drawn attention, in the Cabinet discussions on this matter, to the obvious disparity between the treatment of men's toiletries and women's cosmetics. It is a bit like this business of the ice cream and the biscuits. I just wonder how much out of touch the Treasurer and all these other people are. Women's cosmetics are used in very great quantities even in the most modest households. They are not a luxury item in modest households. Women use cosmetics of various kinds on a daily basis. They buy them in supermarkets these days. Perhaps during the war, when apparently the thinking of these ice cream and biscuit taxes was fixed, and when they were all rationed in any case, taxes had to be slammed on them as luxury items. But these days are the ordinary cosmetics to be found in every household luxury items?

We have the saga of the pianola rolls. There was a report in the Age of 20 September 1985 headed `Keating faces the music over pianola roll tax'. There is a history attached to this. It is not a major item. It just shows how silly these things can become if there is not someone with common sense overseeing the work of the officers in the Australan Taxation Office. The article states:

Mr Howard removed wholesale sales tax from pianola rolls in the 1980 budget after learning that a western suburbs manufacturer was the only Australian still punching holes in a paper roll for those who could work a piano's pedals but weren't too good on the keys.
That manufacturer is Mr Barclay Wright, of Petersham, New South Wales, who is the only manufacturer of pianola rolls in this country. The article continued:
Mr Keating has now imposed a 20 per cent tax rate on pianola rolls--

And here I quote from this delicious tax statement of the Treasurer, which shows how arcane the thinking is. The 20 per cent tax rate has been imposed on the rolls produced by this single Australian producer:
. . . to achieve a consistent treatment with pianos, player-pianos, and the proposed treatment for similar home entertainment items such as records and tapes.

The whole industry of people making pianos, player-pianos, entertainment items, records and tapes, is trembling at the competition it is getting from Mr Barclay Wright, of Petersham, who is turning out these pianola rolls so effectively!

In order to aid this vast industry, trembling at the terrible competiton from Mr Barclay Wright, the Treasurer is to impose a 20 per cent tax on his products. What an absolute nonsense! That is just a dopey example. But what else do we have? A 10 per cent sales tax is to be imposed, not on books-the Government said it would not impose a tax on books and it appears to have kept that promise-but on `books consisting wholly or principally of maps'. What on earth is the sense in that? I presume that the Government is talking about atlases. What is the difference between a book and an atlas? If the Government wants to tax the maps that one buys for tours and that sort of thing, they can be distinguished easily enough. But to tax atlases, which are used by families and schools for educational purposes, strikes me as being yet another nonsense.

I notice that the Government is also bringing in a tax on solar hot water systems and solar energy equipment. That seems to go against the Australian Labor Party's platform, constitution and rules of 1984 which state, under the heading `Energy Consumption and Conservation' that Labor will:

. . . investigate the feasibility of offering financial incentives and assistance to encourage the more rapid adoption of energy-efficient technologies and practices, including renewable energy technologies . . . for example, low energy features in first home purchases of low to middle income earners, and the purchase of solar energy equipment-

I am turning the Labor Party's words against itself on this issue, because it said in its platform that it would not do this sort of thing but has included it in its proposals. What about soft drinks? There is a peculiar thing about soft drinks which I have never been able to understand. It was an anomaly in the old system which we, I confess, did not remove. According to the Treasurer's draft White Paper on taxation, if one has a wholesale tax which has all sorts of anomalies in it, now is the time to do something about it. But nothing has been done about the business of soft drinks. A still drink with 25 per cent fruit juice-in other words, it is three-quarters water-is not taxed. But if one puts a few bubbles in it and it becomes a carbonated drink, it is taxed. I cannot quite see the logic of that. If the drink were 100 per cent fruit juice maybe the Government would say that it was more nutritious or there might be some sort of argument for not taxing it. But does one make taxation decisions on the basis of whether things are nutritious? I am not sure that that is a good tax principle. I merely draw the attention of the House to the fact

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on whether you put spa water in it.

—The honourable member for Dundas raises further complications which are beyond the Australian Taxation Office to solve. I merely point out that a still drink with 25 per cent fruit juice in it is not taxed but, if it has a few bubbles in it, it is taxed. The Government is introducing some earth shattering changes which I am sure the House will applaud. For example, the sales tax on toothpicks and paper weights is down from 32 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent. This measure merits a full line in the Treasurer's tax package statement. The net taxation take went from $6.8 billion, proposed in the draft White Paper, to give major relief to taxpayers at the lower and middle levels of income, to what we have in the final package-a whole baggage of goods which reduces, for example, the tax on toothpicks and paper weights from 32 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent. That typifies this whole package.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, the serious side of this issue is what I noted at the beginning of this debate, that is, that the Government said to everybody that tax reform was one of the most important national objectives. The Government invested months and months going around the country persuading everybody that there had to be a sufficient shift from income tax towards indirect taxes so as to relieve people at the lower and middle levels of income from excessive marginal tax rates on their personal income tax. That was the whole thrust of what the Government told us for months and months. The Prime Minister said that he was prepared to stake the whole future of the Government on it. The Treasurer said that he was prepared to leave politics if he did not achieve his reforms. But what do we find? We find that instead of the Government's preferred Option C, which would have shifted $6.8 billion off the income tax scales into indirect tax, providing major reform and major relief to low and middle income earners, we have before the House a measure which transfers, not $6.8 billion in that direction, but a lousy $110m, and, in the process, produces yet another set of anomalies in the wholesale sales tax rates and schedules. That is the issue before the House this morning. That is what the Government has to be nailed on. Once again, the Government has come out with high promise and failed us on every single count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we are discussing national issues such as taxation it is important to look at the historical position. It is also important to suggest in this debate that the piety the Opposition displays about tax is quite extraordinary. The community is not persuaded by what the Opposition says. We have only to reflect on the Opposition's performance when it was in government to realise that. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), has admitted that there were inequities in the wholesale tax system that the previous Government did not iron out. Also, if we consider the current debate within the Opposition, we are not really sure whether the Opposition wants to have income splitting, a consumption tax or a capital gains tax using section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act which provides for a very punitive capital gains tax, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has repeatedly said. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is well aware that section 26AAA, which taxes at the full marginal rate full nominal gains, is a very punitive capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not really sure where the Opposition stands on the whole question of tax policy. All we know-our knowledge is shared by the community-is that when the Opposition was in government it certainly did not act against tax avoidance and evasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —They encouraged it.

—Exactly. On the basis of the Opposition's performance in government, it has no credibility. Some tax evaders and avoiders are being dealt with by the court system now. However, the Opposition certainly is not credible on taxes and the community knows it. It knows very well that, when it came to tax policy, the previous Government was a tattered government. It did not perform. The present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was unable to get any sort of consensus on tax policy. He would roll up some ideas and would be knocked over again and again in Cabinet.
—Messner is doing the same thing to him now.

—As the honourable member says, the same process is taking place now. Between the agrarian socialists of the National Party who have certain goals and the Liberal wets and dries, the Leader of the Opposition is unable to come up with a credible tax policy. Little wonder that the shadow Treasurer is unable to come up with a credible tax policy. When we paint that picture it is no good the Opposition coming into this chamber and doing what the shadow Treasurer has just done-nitpicking. The Opposition when in government did not perform and, in opposition, is unable to put together a substantial policy. The Opposition is committed to the exercise of choosing minor items and having shots at them. Ross Gittins, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October, identified very accurately the kind of dilemma faced by some members of the community and the Opposition. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If ever there was a classic example of the business community's political ineptitude, it's the cosmetic industry's belated campaign to have the sales tax on its products cut from 30 per cent to 20 per cent.

The article then develops the argument a little more. It goes on to say that the difficulty the cosmetics industry faces and, I suggest, the difficulty the Opposition faces, is that when governments-we can talk about governments over a long time-come to office and try to put together a comprehensive tax reform proposal oppositions are not prepared to weigh into the debate in a substantial way. What this Opposition is prepared to do is to hold its fire. When the Government puts up a proposition the Opposition gets very excited and tells the Government what a raw deal it is getting. But at the time, in the context of the discussion, it is not prepared to weigh in intelligently. We saw that in the context of the tax debate we had in Australia. We saw very clearly that the Opposition was not prepared to contribute in a substantial way to that tax debate.
Rather, it stood off and was prepared to take shots, which it is doing now. We saw that with substantial sections of industry. It is not good. As Ross Gittins said:
In the antics of the cosmetic industry we have a classic example of the business community's perverted approach to politics-
and I suggest the Opposition's perverted approach to politics-

. . . it won't back governments when they are trying to achieve something positive, all it will do is attack them when it reckons it is getting a raw deal. The cosmetics industry has left its run far too late. It has Buckley's chance of getting the tax on its products reduced. But perhaps the association doesn't care about winning so much as it cares about keeping in the clear with its members.

I suggest that that is an adequate response to what the shadow Treasurer said about the cosmetics industry issues. He made great comment about the detail of the issues, but that is substantially the point. When the debate about tax was on in this country the Opposition and many people in business were found wanting. So it is no good those opposite bleating at this stage and saying: `We are not happy with this item or that item and so on'. They were not prepared to contribute to the national tax debate and they are not prepared to contribute substantially to it now because they do not have a policy. The people in the community well know that those opposite, when in government, had nothing substantial in the way of a tax policy; it was a shambles. There was an enormous drift in pay as you earn tax collections. There was rampant tax avoidance and evasion that the then Government did nothing to curb; it let them go on. The people out there are still angry about that-the people who had no choice with respect to pay as you earn tax. They still have no choice with respect to pay as you earn tax, but we are doing something about reducing those marginal rates. Those opposite, when in government, were not prepared to do it. They let the tax avoiders and evaders go. What we are now seeing is the wash-up of that in the court system.

What has to be recognised in the context of this debate is that in the tax package we have substantial reductions in the marginal rates. We are faced with the absolute ineptitude of the Opposition. The Opposition is saying: `We are unhappy that the Government has removed the sales tax on imported horses'. Those opposite were never prepared to deal with the fact that the horse racing industry is a substantial employer of labour-250,000 people around the country. In fact very little was collected from sales tax on imported horses because very few horses were brought into the country. That is just an example of their inability to recognise that tax policy can play a part in bringing about sensible equity.

What we are offering is substantial reductions in marginal rates. From 1 September 1986 the 60c rate will go to 55c, the 48c rate to 46c, the 46c rate to 43c, the 30c rate to 29c, and the 25c rate to 24c. That is part of this whole arrangement in respect to sales tax. From 1 July 1987 the five-rate scale will be compressed to four. The 55c rate will become 49c. It should be recognised that people currently paying 60c in the dollar will be paying 49c from 1 July 1987. The 46c and the 43c rates will come back to 40c, again substantial reductions in marginal tax rates. As part of this overall tax package the 29c and 24c rates will remain.

We are suggesting that there is a strategy and an approach on tax. It is no good the Opposition saying: `We are all concerned about these minor items'. What the Opposition has not got is a comprehensive approach to tax policy. Those opposite certainly never had one when they were in government and there is no evidence of them developing one at this stage. The community well knows that. I say to those opposite: `Where is your comprehensive tax policy? Where is your approach to taxes and wages?'. We do not know. There is a debate between the agrarian socialists, the Liberal wets and the Liberal dries. All the factions are weighing in, but those opposite have not got a comprehensive tax or wages policy. The community well knows that. The community knows that those opposite are divided. While they remain so divided it is no good them sounding pious in debates because the community can see through all that piety and nonsense, as we can. That is all it is.

In this tax package and in these sales tax amendments we have a substantial approach to tax reform. We had a debate in this country. The Opposition and sectors of business were not prepared to participate in that debate. It is now too late. We have now taken some firm positions with respect to taxes, and the community knows that what is involved in these sales tax adjustments is the pay-off for substantial reductions in marginal rates of tax. That is what members of the community have been saying for a long time. They were saying it when those opposite were in government and they did not listen. All they listened to were their mates in the tax avoidance and evasion industry. They cosseted them. That is all they listened to. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when he was Treasurer, knew that the ramps and rorts were on. It was well known in the community and in the accounting profession that they were on. There were people selling schemes. Theirs were the only voices those opposite listened to and they stand condemned for it. The only voices were those of tax avoiders and evaders who were out there doing their thing. But they could not hear the ordinary citizens who were committed to paying pay as you earn tax. They were not interested in tax indexation. They certainly were not interested in reducing marginal rates.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I will not go on further because I know that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) will do a substantial job of putting propositions before the House. There are a lot of things to be said about tax reform. The Opposition is not in a position to say things about tax reform because its record is shabby indeed and because it does not have a policy. This side, as will be seen from following speakers on the Government side, is well aware of what is involved in tax reform and we are pleased to be supporting these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is proper in this place, I must respond to some of the statements made by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). A substantial part of his speech referred to tax avoidance and evasion. I have chosen in this place to retail the difference, which he from a professional standpoint should know, between tax avoidance and evasion. Tax avoidance has always involved people telling the Commissioner of Taxation what they were doing and then telling him why he could not have any money. Tax evasion involves people not telling him. Last night I drew the attention of the House to the potential activities of a very close member of the Labor Party. It is all right for the honourable member for Stirling to lecture us, a Party that brought in 40 separate pieces of anti-tax avoidance legislation, and to vote against me personally by voting to expel me from the House to protect one of his own Ministers, whom I branded as both a tax avoider and a tax evader under the definition I have just given! It is total hypocrisy for him to pontificate in the way he did a few minutes ago while he is prepared time and again to see his name in the list of voters printed in Hansard. He can point the finger at people associated distantly and at arm's length with the Liberal Party. Never has he been able to point the finger at a member of our front bench in the way that I have pointed at his front bench. Do not give me that sort of rubbish! I hope that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is not going to give us one of his standard speeches in that regard.
—On a point of order: On a previous occasion, as the honourable member for O'Connor quite correctly indicated, he was expelled from this chamber for disorderly conduct as a result-
—Will the honourable member come to the point of order?
—I am. That puts it in context. As a result of accusations which were made against them, unfounded, unsubstantiated, grossly defamatory accusations made against a-
—Order! The Chair is listening very carefully to the honourable member for O'Connor. He will now continue to speak to the Bill.

—In answer to that accusation, should the honourable member invite me I will table again the probate statement that saved $1m for the Minister for Finance. So do not say it is unsubstantiated. There are substantial items to consider, discuss and in fact criticise in regard to this legislation. The honourable member for Stirling wanted to lecture us on the racing industry. It might be proper at this stage of the game for me to declare an interest in that matter because I am an owner and breeder of race horses. I am quite happy for those present to be aware of my position in that regard because I think it allows me to speak with some experience and knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately I have never had the privilege of buying a race horse from Ireland, as this legislation will allow me to do free of sales tax. I have bought race horses from New Zealand, and they were not subject to sales tax. In answer to a question from the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) gave us a lecture on all these things and finished with these words:
Racing has had such a profound impact on the society of Australia that Phar Lap, a dead horse, and Tommy Woodcock, his gentle trainer, will be remembered long after most of us have been forgotten.

He made this impassioned plea for the racing industry, supporting the situation that this legislation brings about. Schedule 1 will include new clause 117A so that all race horses imported are free of sales tax. I can tell honourable members that that will help a lot of people; it will help those people who import horses from places that are quoted in the schedule, for example, Ireland. In other words, it will not help very many people. But at the same time, the tax package, as we know it, will cause the quarantining of farm losses. A substantial proportion of the 250,000 people who the Government boasts are employed in the racing industry are employed in breeding horses. As the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) who has just entered the House would tell us, the owning and the breeding of a race horse is seldom profitable. It is only the people who are prepared to put in capital and take advantage of some tax concessions who go into race horse breeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or those who are a bit mad.

—Yes. Unfortunately one has to have substantial assets behind one in order to go into race horse breeding. The history of breeding race horses is that one can go for probably 20 years sustaining losses for the grand dream that one day one will have a Bletchingly, or something like that. Then, of course, one gets substantial profits and one is taxed quite heavily on them. At the moment this Government has made a substantial attack on that industry because of the effect on those people who have quite deliberately calculated and taken the tax benefit of those losses. Let us remember that those people initially lose 100c in the dollar. They could have the whole 100c. My wife is at pains to explain to me that she would rather we keep the 100c than I have the advantage of only having to spend 54c, or whatever the rate is at present, out of my dollar in trying to breed race horses. I promise honourable members that it is a long time since I made a profit in that area, but I am still hopeful. It is the grand gamble.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I have a 200-acre property which, if it were to run cattle, would employ nobody in a full time capacity. Generally my property employs three people because of the huge labour intensity of horse breeding. Nevertheless, one must look at what one is doing in that industry. It is an industry in which people invest 100c in the dollar and they see it discounted by the tax effect, but it does keep a lot of people in jobs. These people support the industry which the Minister has elevated above this Parliament in his answers to questions. The Government should be quite clear about what it is doing: The sales tax benefit is insufficient compared with the attack that the Government has mounted by trying to quarantine farm losses. On another occasion I shall go into the overall effects of that at much greater length. The racing industry is extremely angry and the Government has not won many friends in that area because it has taken much more than it has given in this alteration and the creation of new clause 117A.

More important to me at this stage of the game are the issues that I wish to raise on behalf of my area of responsibility, small business. I mention particularly wholesalers, but again I do not think I need declare an interest because not that long ago my firm cancelled its sales tax licence as we did not need it any more. I am well aware of the operation of the sales tax laws of Australia and consequently I am aware of the huge burden that the present collection measures place upon the business community involved. The legislation labels the person whom we all see as the collector, as the taxpayer. He is considered to be the taxpayer, and that he is. He is obliged to pay the tax on the products he sells on the twentieth of the month following the month of invoicing, whether it is a cash or credit sale. He is obliged to pay that tax whether or not the person he invoices on credit pays him promptly or at all. That is another matter altogether. There are some provisions to allow him in certain circumstances to claim the tax back if the amount is not paid eventually, but in the short term-by that I mean many months-he carries the burden of paying the present inflated interest rates of 20 per cent plus that this Government has imposed on the Australian business community. He has to pay that rate of interest on that money until the client pays him.

Everybody knows-I am told by the small business community that even the Treasurer agrees-that this is an unnecessary burden. Absolutely no remuneration whatsoever is paid to the business community for collecting the huge amount of tax for the Government, I think some $6,000m in the present Budget. The business community gets no remuneration and no encouragement whatsoever. In fact, in many cases it is obliged if it is granting credit-and most wholesalers do-to borrow money to pay the tax. Wholesalers issue invoices at the end of the month with the tax shown and by the following twentieth of the month that tax must be in the hands of the Commissioner. The Commissioner is quite active in ensuring that it is. Nobody is likely to have his accounts paid by even the best of his customers by the twentieth of the month following the date of invoice. We talk about a 30-day account and that means it is 10 days later, at the minimum, after the date on which the wholesaler pays the tax that he can expect to find his revenue coming in from his clients. Many people, particularly in these hard times with inflation and devaluation pushing up the value of the stock on their shelves, find it extremely difficult to be good payers. Often they pay something like 60 days later which means that for 40 days the wholesaler is carrying the Government and paying 20 per cent interest on that money. That is grossly unfair and I am aware that past governments have not been able to address the problem.

I am advised that the Treasury reckons that it would cost about $250m to extend the collection period by a further 30 days. That is a lot of money. I did my calculation differently. I worked it out that the $6,000m of collections means that this can be broken down into approximately $500m a month. If the collection period were extended by a month it would mean $500m lost to cash flow. It would not be lost to the revenue, but the whole thing would be bumped back. There would be a bump in cash flow, as we in business understand it, and that would mean that the Government would be $500m short. The interesting point about that is that if the Government went to the bond market to get that money-I will not argue the implications of that-and paid the rate that governments can get money for today, about 15 per cent, it would cost $75m a year.

The interesting point about the Treasurer's statement on this so-called rationalisation is that for a long time it was presented to the Australian taxpayers as being revenue neutral-in other words, the Government just wanted to clean up the mess as it saw it, but it was not trying to get more revenue out of the arrangement. We now discover that there will be a $75m tax windfall in the first year, $110m in the second year and whatever from thereon in. The Government could actually extend by one month the collection period for all these disadvantaged wholesalers at the cost of its tax windfall of $75m. So theoretically not a penny has been lost. Alternatively, if the Government chose to extend the collection period on a daily basis at a cost of $16.43m a day, it could extend the day back as well. This means that with the first tax windfall-that is, the money the Government did not really want anyway-it could extend the period by four days. That does not sound very much, but the next year the Government could extend the period by another six days at no cost to revenue if it accepted that this was a tax windfall and something that accidentally occurred. The Government would be in a position to give the business community a chance over a period. It is not that often that the Government gets a tax windfall of this nature, so the opportunity will not come around again. I sincerely hope that this plea that I make on behalf of the small business community in particular will be heard by the Government.

I am also aware that some sections of big business can get their sales tax in very promptly. I believe the car industry gets it in extremely quickly so maybe the Government should look at that in the context of this arrangement. I do not see that one side of business should have to borrow money at 20 per cent-generally small business-and another have the Government's money out at 20 per cent or 15 per cent on the bond market or short term money market.

The reality is that this question needs looking at. There are probably other options that the Government could take to give a reasonable opportunity to the small business wholesaler to pay. I hope that the Government will take that plea on board. The evidence is there. The Government has had a tax windfall; it has admitted so. That tax windfall should be used to extend the time of payment from the 20th of the following month.

While I am on this subject, it is interesting to note how tough the Taxation Commissioner has become in making people pay their various tax commitments on time, even if they are tax collectors for government-and the responsibility is not truly theirs. Yet there is ample evidence that the Government is slipping further behind again, particularly in the case of Pharmpay, in paying its creditors. This Government does not seem in the least bit anxious to help me bring forward my prompt payment of government debt legislation, which would be of great help in this regard.

That issue is one of great concern to me, but, furthermore, I represent a rural electorate and I must put the point to government that every time a tax of this nature is imposed or increased, there is an additional cost to people in the country. Sometimes it is overstated. Because the tax remains a wholesale tax at present, many goods directed to country people are charged out at the metropolitan wholesale price. In those circumstances it is untrue to say that the additional freight is taxed; it is not, and that is often overstated. Nevertheless, there are many wholesale organisations operating in rural centres, particularly some of the larger centres. If goods are transported to those wholesale centres and billed at that point, there will be an additional unit cost burden for the country people, and it should not exist. It is time that both sides of politics addressed this problem. It would be a considerable problem with regard to the imposition of a retail tax whereby all goods would be charged at that point. I am talking about the additional profit margin as well as the freight.

I have made the point frequently in this Parliament that one wonders what rural Labor voters in particular get for their vote. They get very little consideration whatsoever on these issues. They will certainly pay a higher unit tax. The packet of weeties that is consumed by a three-unit family is consumed in exactly the same period by a wages and salary earning family living in a provincial town or by a farming family. All of those people who reside in the country are getting a raw deal at present from this Government, particularly with regard to fuel prices, where a huge cost is involved because of the multiplier effect. People in the country do not have the opportunity to use public transport to the same extent as do those in the city. It is nothing to do a 20-mile trip just to get one's kids on to a football ground. That is a huge cost that country people, whether they be farmers or wage and salary earners, have to meet. In the case of the sales tax, the proposed increases will have the same effect.

The rural community is deeply concerned too about its food products. Last night, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) went to great pains to draw the Government's attention to the fact that apparently an almond, irrespective of its condition and irrespective of the fact that it may be used as a health food or a sweet, will be taxed under this legislation. The Government had better look quickly at that. I am told that the industry is not concerned when almonds are spiced up and treated almost as confectionery, but when they are sold in health shops in competition with other types of health foods, such as dried fruits and things of that nature, it would be quite ridiculous to have them taxed in the form proposed. Almonds are a nutritious food. The almond industry is a substantial primary industry within Australia. There is absolutely no reason why almonds should be taxed in any way. I hope that the Government will look at this question very quickly.

The major points that I wish to make and repeat are that these sales tax proposals were presented to the Australian public as being revenue neutral. They are not revenue neutral. They will pick up $110m in a full tax year. That tax windfall could quite easily have been applied by one means or another to reducing the burden on that legion of unpaid and unassisted tax collectors whom the Government has regimented for itself and who have been called upon to collect tax over many years. They should at least not be disadvantaged in carrying out their responsibilities to collect tax. I add in that regard-I do not know whether the proposed rationalisation will help in some way-that there is huge confusion in the industry. It is my experience that it is no good writing to the Australian Taxation Office and asking: `Can you give me a list of the taxes I should charge on goods?'. The Taxation Office responds: `No'. One has to send the Taxation Office a list of what one wants to sell and then the Taxation Office will tell one what tax to charge on those items. There are various areas of confusion in that regard, and that should not be so. I am sure that there should be some other way.

In closing, this legislation is considered a tax package. I do not like to consider it as a tax package. My view is that it should not be. I reject entirely the criticism of the honourable member for Stirling, who said that we do not know where we are going. It is not our obligation to know where we are going. Honourable members opposite are in government. We know where we are going. We are taking the proper steps and are taking the time that an Opposition is entitled to take to put together the right package by election time. Honourable members opposite have to run the country. They got too much benefit from all the things we did before they came into government. I refer to the wages pause and a few other measures. We had to take over Labor's expenditure splurges. Honourable members opposite boast about all sorts of things. The Government has borrowed $20,000m. The interest bill has jumped from $3,300m to $6,700m. It has doubled the accumulated debt of the Federal Government, something which had not happened over the previous 80 years. By dividing the Government's claim of 500,000 jobs into that debt total, I can tell honourable members that it has cost $40,000 a job. Of course, the Government has not created 500,000 jobs; it has created a fraction of that amount. The others would have created themselves anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present wholesale tax base operates to tax all goods at the general rate of 20 per cent, unless they are specified to be taxed at a different rate or they are exempt. Six schedules of goods are contained in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 for that purpose. The multiple rate structure of the wholesale tax base and the various detailed descriptions of goods in those schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act are widely recognised as being the sources of significant problems in its application and administration. There is no doubt that difficulties can arise in the assignment of particular commodities to an appropriate rate class, with consequent administrative burdens and costs. In some relatively isolated instances, unfair competition between like commodities or close substitutes can arise in the market-place due to those wholesale tax discriminations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, which is the main Bill in this package of Bills before the House, is designed to broaden that wholesale tax base and to remove some of the classification anomalies and inconsistencies that presently exist in the wholesale tax structure in Australia. Honourable members would be aware that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced only just over a month ago-on 13 August-that the Government would not proceed with either a tax on selective services or an extension of the wholesale tax base to major new categories of goods; instead, the Government would be embarking upon a rationalisation of that existing wholesale tax system which taxes goods in categories. He said that we would be changing that system and the tax rate structure to reduce distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies.

As I have just outlined, the Bills before the House will effect a number of changes to that system. One of the major changes proposed is the rationalisation of the rate classes. Under this legislation, the rate structure is to be simplified to include an exempt category and also to reduce the number of rate categories from four to three. They will be at the 10, 20 and 30 per cent rate. That will be done by absorbing the 7 1/2 per cent rate category into the 10 per cent rate category. Items currently taxed at 32.5 per cent will be shifted to either the new 30 per cent rate category or the 20 per cent rate category.

There are a number of schedules to this legislation which outline the specific goods which are taxable at those rates. The items which will be taxed under this legislation at 30 per cent and which were formerly taxed at 32.5 per cent include jewellery, goods made wholly or principally of precious metal, cosmetics, perfumery and bath salts, cameras, films, and radio and television receivers.

It is also intended that earth stations designed to receive the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service and purchased for domestic use to receive such services will be exempt. In the first instance, we have a large range of goods the rate of tax on which has been reduced from 32.5 per cent to 30 per cent. That is at a cost to revenue of $66m. The Government ought to be congratulated for reducing the tax on those items, which are used by most Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —The HACBASS decision.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Stirling says, the HACBASS decision is a very good decision. A number of goods formerly taxed at 32 per cent will now be included at the 20 per cent rate. These include things, which again are common use items, like serviette rings, book ends and book marks, clothing accessories, paper weights, cigarette lighters and so on. They include fountain pens, ball point pens, felt tip pens-which are very popular nowadays-shaving equipment-which of course most males use-ornaments, artificial flowers and so on. Those changes will go some way towards reducing the effective dispersion in the rate structure and the distorting effects of the tax on the relative price of goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The aspect of this Bill on which I wish to concentrate in the limited time available is that of some of the base broadening measures. They have been the subject of some criticism by the Opposition, particularly one base-broadening measure that will apply a tax of 10 per cent to ice cream. There has been criticism from a number of organisations-the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, the Australian Dairy Industry Council and the Ice Cream Manufacturers Federation of Australia. Basically, the coverage of the wholesale tax system will be extended in a number of areas, principally with the very honourable intention of reducing anomalies. Major changes relate to confectionery, snack foods, biscuits and ice cream.

The present wholesale tax system taxes confectionery at 20 per cent while, quite anomalously, exempting close substitute products such as snack foods, biscuits and ice cream. For example, popcorn is taxable while potato crisps are exempt. Chocolate-coated biscuits are taxable if marketed as confectionery but, if marketed otherwise, they are exempt. That demarcation leads to administrative complexities in deciding the appropriate rates to apply, and it leads to obvious inequities in the taxation treatment between those goods.

To ameliorate those problems, this legislation makes a number of changes. A number of goods will now be taxed at 10 per cent. They include things like potato crisps, chips and straws, other savoury food products such as corn chips, prawn chips and pork crackling or nuts and seeds that have been salted, spiced, smoked or roasted. Biscuits will be taxed at 10 per cent, together with ice cream, ice cream cakes, ice cream substitutes and frozen confectionery other than frozen yoghurt.

The issue I wish to raise is that the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, the Australian Dairy Industry Council and the Ice Cream Manufacturers Federation of Australia have complained bitterly about the Government's intention in this legislation to impose a tax of 10 per cent on ice cream. I must say that the letters from these three organisations all come from the same address, which is 576 St Kilda Road, Melbourne, that is, Dairy Industry House. We have also received a telex from Mr Clay Manners who is Secretary of the Australian Dairy Industry Council. It states:
On behalf of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference, I wish to register the strongest possible protest at the Federal Government's announced intention to levy a 10 per cent sales tax on ice cream.
Ice cream is a nutritious and relatively pure food comprising approximately 70 per cent dairy ingredients. Approximately 70 per cent of the total volume of ice cream is sold in take home packs . . .
It goes on to state:

The ice cream industry is a major customer for the dairy industry. We estimate that the ice cream industry purchases approximately $40,000,000 worth of ingredients from the dairy industry annually . . . The dairy industry fears that the introduction of a tax on ice cream will encourage consumers to purchase cheaper substitutes to ice cream. This may be iced confection or some other dessert food (eg. jelly, frozen yoghurt, custard) which is not subject to sales tax
It would seem the Government's decision to impose sales tax on ice cream was made on the basis of this common misconception of the nutritional value of ice cream.

The letter from the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation states, among other things, that ice cream competes in the market not only against ice cream substitutes but also against other desserts such as cake, jelly, custards, puddings, et cetera, which are not subject to sales tax. There is a great deal of literature from those organisations and I cannot read it all. But I want to summarise their arguments. What they are saying is that ice cream uses large quantities of dairy product and sugar and is consumed predominantly in the home as a dessert or as a supplement to desserts. They then say that a tax of 10 per cent on ice cream will cause a reduction in its consumption; in other words they are saying that there is an elastic demand market for ice cream and that, with that tax of 10 per cent, there will be a reduction in consumption of dairy products because dairy products make up a large part of ice cream. They also go on to argue that the price increase in ice cream will undoubtedly lead to increased consumption of ice cream substitutes, of yoghurt, of custards, cakes and puddings. They then go on to say that somehow that will be bad for the dairy industry in total and that the dairy and sugar industries will lose revenue and sales.

I want to state a few facts about those claims, which are at best tenuous. If one took a more harsh and more fair assessment, one would say that they are reactionary, illogical and in fact just show all the signs of shooting from the hip. I should begin by saying that ice cream substitutes will also be subject to tax. That is made quite clear in the legislation. Schedule 2, clause 23(h), states that goods which will be subject to the 10 per cent tax include `ice-cream, ice-cream cakes, ice-creams, ice-cream substitutes'. So the argument that putting a tax on ice cream will lead to an increased consumption of ice cream substitutes is simply baloney because ice cream and ice cream substitutes will be subject to 10 per cent tax. There will not be any consumption switch because there is no change in price relativity.

The second point I want to make is that in this legislation products of 95 per cent and more dairy product will be totally exempt from tax. So the argument that we are knocking the dairy industry is rubbish. Anything consisting of 95 per cent or more dairy product will be totally exempt. For instance, products like yoghurt will be totally exempt. It is a fact that consumers may make a minor switch to other dessert foods such as cakes, custards, cheesecakes or puddings. However, the point I make in this debate is that, if they do, those foods-custards, cakes, cheesecakes and puddings-contain more dairy product than ice cream.

I make the point a bit stronger. I happen to have had presented to me recently a wonderful publication called the Country Women's Cookbook. It has many excellent recipes which I commend to all members of the House. It is a great publication. Honourable members will be aware of the Country Women's Association and the contribution it has made to improving our society in rural Australia. It has produced a number of recipes, which of course are not commercial recipes; they are home made recipes. I want to give honourable members, the ADFF, the ADIC and the ice cream manufacturers an idea of how dairy product consumption will not be affected. These are home made recipes. Let us look at equal serves of ice cream and other desserts. One recipe for ice cream has four heaped tablespoons of powdered milk, half a cup of sugar, two cups of fresh milk, half a cup of hot water and some vanilla essence and gelatine to taste. The most commonly consumed puddings in rural Victoria, according to my understanding and that of the Country Women's Association, are in the book. I have picked out a few of them. One of the common ones is Perfection Pudding. Perfection Pudding, which I can re- commend, uses three eggs, two tablespoons of butter, two tablespoons of flour, two tablespoons of golden syrup, a teaspoon of vanilla essence and three cups of boiling milk. Perfection Pudding has more dairy product in it than ice cream. It has two tablespoons of butter; it has sugar, because it has two tablespoons of golden syrup, and it has three cups of boiling milk.

Perhaps honourable members do not like Perfection Pudding. There is another pudding which the Country Women's Association recommends. It is called Milk Pudding Deluxe. Milk Pudding Deluxe, again a very popular line at lunch time, is made with two tablespoons of butter, two tablespoons of plain flour, two tablespoons of sugar, two or three eggs to taste, two and a half cups of milk and vanilla to taste. The fact again is that in milk pudding there is more butter and more milk than in the same size serve of ice cream.

I do not want to go through all the recipes. But the fact is, if we switch to ice cream substitutes, that will not happen because they will be taxed as well. So the arguments that the ADFF makes about ice cream substitutes, such as palm and coconut oil, most of which are imported, is not on. There is no change in price relativities so there will be no change in consumption. All people can change to is cakes, custards, puddings, cheesecakes, jellies or chocolates. If people change to chocolate-the ADFF does not make this point in its letter; it is a strange sort of a letter-they will find that chocolate, which used to be taxed at 20 per cent, will now be taxed at 10 per cent. Basically, chocolate is all dairy product. Chocolate will be cheaper; so people will buy more. Even if people eat jelly, we know that jelly is made out of gelatine which is made from the pulverised hooves and horns of cattle. In summary, if people eat cake--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have suddenly gone off jelly. Try another recipe.

—The last recipe which I will finish with is mocha steamed pudding. Mocha steamed pudding contains four ounces of butter, four ounces of sugar, two eggs, two dessertspoons of cocoa, two cups of flour, two teaspoons of vanilla and one cup of milk. I again make the point that this pudding has more butter, more sugar and an almost equal amount of milk as the recipe for ice cream.

SPEECH.PARA: I have researched very thoroughly the claims of the Dairy Farmers Federation, the Dairy Industry Council and the Ice Cream Manufacturers Federation and I have found that they are not substantiated. If there is an equal tax on ice cream and ice cream substitutes there will be no consumption switch. If there is a consumption switch to chocolate-as there may be because we have brought down the tax on chocolate from 20 per cent to 10-per cent it is virtually all dairy product so that is good for the dairy industry. If there is a consumption switch to cakes, cheesecakes, puddings, or even jellies, that again will lead to the consumption of more dairy products because there are more dairy products in cakes, custards, puddings and cheesecakes than there are in ice cream. I conclude by saying that the claims of the ADFF are unfounded.
