It is a pity that such an organisation can make such ill-informed and illogical claims and expect people in this Parliament to take it seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I should thank the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) for his cooking lesson. When he goes back to his electorate I am sure that he will find some means of using his expertise in one of the shopping centres. He can indicate to people how they will be better off getting out the mixmaster every time their kids want an ice cream to whip up something else in a hurry.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis of the tax reform process, as pronounced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), was to be encapsulated in nine principles. The ninth principle-that any reform package must have widespread community support-was, of course, the one by which the Prime Minister's decision not to proceed with option C, but to proceed with some nebulous option D, was justified. Having taken such a stance-I might say that it was a matter of principle-it must follow that the package delivered to the Australian public last month must have the widespread support of the community. By what criteria this can be justified remains known only to the Government.
We were assured by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) on 17 September 1985 about this fact:

The Australian Labor Party will finalise its deliberations and it will present its package in a totally unified way. The package is endorsed by the overwhelming majority of the Party and it is a package which gives us the most comprehensive taxation reform that this country has ever had.

I note that the honourable member's concept of `totally unified' is not `to make as one', but merely `a substantial majority'. I agree with his description of the package as the most comprehensive tax reform we have ever had. However, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), has said:
The test of whether these changes by the Treasurer to the taxation system deserve the title of fundamental reform is not measured by the number of changes that have been made but by their quality.

On 13 August 1985, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Government was not proceeding with either a tax on selected services or an extension of the wholesale sales tax plan, but that it would be embarking upon a rationalisation of the existing wholesale sales tax goods categories and a tax rate structure designed to reduce distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies in the system. Any move to reduce distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies is to be applauded, especially if the moves are successful.

Notwithstanding the Treasurer's comment in August about not extending the wholesale sales tax, it is noteworthy that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), in delivering the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985, said that the reform package contained initiatives that would broaden the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system. I find it illogical that the Treasurer says in August that the wholesale sales tax will not be extended and then, in September, he says that its base is to be broadened. This broadening, which is not necessarily inimical, is somewhat irrelevant when the inconsistency of both announcements is considered.

We are dealing with legislation which is spreading the tentacles of the Commissioner of Taxation even further. The multiple rates of taxation still apply, though they are reduced in number, for which we must be thankful. Whether the broadening of the tax base and the reduction of the spread of the tax rates has removed the problem of arbitrariness and administrative complexity is conjectural and it is doubtful that it has ameliorated or lessened consumption decision distortions. The argument that the broadening of any tax base can enable the same revenue to be raised and permit a reduction in the rate levels is incontestable. However, in this instance, the broadening of the base and the accompanying rationalisation of the schedules and rate structure will see an additional $110m of revenue raised in a full year.

When one looks at the schedules and analyses the products now being taxed that previously were not, and when one looks at the items that have been reduced in the second schedule from 32.5 per cent to 30 per cent, I believe that it is a fair comment that one will see that those people on the lower end of the socio-economic scale will be the ones who will suffer the most from this legislation. I do not see those people buying furs, opera glasses, jewellery and goods made from precious metals, though items such as ice cream and biscuits form part of their normal consumption expenditure patterns. I wish to talk for a while about the tax on ice cream as the honourable member for Bendigo spent some time supporting the Government in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —He always does.

—Of course he always does. I say the greatest Treasurer in the world, not being satisfied with killing off the great chefs of Australia in the restaurant industry, is now starting to tax the pocket money of the kids of this nation by putting a tax on snack foods, such as potato chips, ice cream and other goods. I have received information from the Ice Cream Manufacturers Federation of Australia which reveals that ice cream accounts annually for 10,000 tonnes of milk fat, 14,000 tonnes of non-fat milk solids and 22,000 tonnes of sugar. The Federation's estimate-I believe it is a conservative estimate-of a market loss of 5 per cent in the first year of the new tax will cost the dairy industry nearly $2.5m and the sugar industry about $1m at a time when both these industries can least afford this sort of loss.

SPEECH.PARA: Ice cream is listed as a food by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in its consumer price index calculations. I ask honourable members to note also that a 1982 survey by a Queensland Insitutute of Technology nurtritionist reported that ice cream was the only source of calcium for a number of primary school children. There are a lot of other nutritional values in ice cream. This very acknowledgement of the value of ice cream as a food in 1962 prompted the government of the day to remove the sales tax that existed. So ice cream has been established as a food and it should be seen as a food.

I suggest that, if the Government is not prepared to do anything about this iniquitous tax in this House, the Opposition should ask the Senate to take some action to see what can be done to have it removed from the Schedule. The wholesale tax changes which, as I have said previously, will result in a revenue to the Government of $110m in a full year, commenced on 20 September 1985. The tax cuts will be effective from 1 September 1986 and 1 July 1987 and will be equivalent to a 2 per cent wage increase. This is to be achieved by raising the tax threshold and lowering the marginal tax rates. We have been told by the Treasurer that in the first year of operation of this reform package the average income earner will receive an income tax cut of $9 a week. To get some perspective of the significance of that figure it is worth remembering that the average income earner referred to by the Treasurer is grossing around $22,000.

I have always made it known within my Party and in other areas that I do not accept the use of an average income. We should be supplied with the most common salary and wage in Australia. The majority of people certainly do not reach the $22,000 limit, and that average income is based on some nebulous figures which I am trying to get from government departments. If one is unemployed or a pensioner, that will not help much, if at all. If one receives $12,500 a year the net gain will be only $3.80, rising to $4.90 at $17,500 per annum. In other words, at this end of the income scale the income tax gains, which are not coming until 1 September 1986, are minimal; whereas the pay-out in sales tax, which is a `right now, straight away' impost, has started eating into the household disposable income already. However, I believe it is worthy of favourable comment that earth stations designed to receive the household and community broadcasting satellite service and purchased for domestic use to receive this service will be exempt.

The move to include most major household appliances in the revised Third Schedule at a 10 per cent tax rate is a matter of some concern and is all the more topical and relevant when the present problems at Rank Major Appliances Pty Ltd at Blacktown are taken into consideration. The white goods industry is at a disadvantage compared to overseas countries in regard to production costs. Wages form a component in this consideration but cannot be viewed as the only source of higher costs. Other major cost disadvantages apply to components such as compressors, evaporators, condensers and electric motors. Both the Tariff Board and the Industries Assistance Commission have at various times commented on these aspects of cost disadvantage that the industry faces relative to similar overseas product material and components. The additional 2.5 per cent sales tax impost is hardly the news the industry wants to hear right now. The mergers of 1979 saw rationalisation and the elimination of much duplication of heavy capital expenditure and the resultant waste, but still economies of scale in individual plants were never achieved to the extent that true competitiveness with overseas competitors could be claimed. The calls by Brian Girdlestone, Managing Director of Hoover (Australia) Pty Ltd, for strong government intervention to save the industry in the face of large scale dumping by foreign competitors on the Australian market must be taken seriously. The increase in imports appears not to have been stemmed by the effects of devaluation to an extent that would help the local industry, given the problems Rank Major Appliances is facing. It is paradoxical that the demise of Rank Major Appliances as an Australian entity and provider of jobs will assist those remaining Australian white goods manufacturers in improving their economies of scale and hence their competitiveness.

There are a number of anomalies in the wholesale sales tax system which require some response from the Treasurer. I hope that he takes notice of them and replies to them in his closing speech. The first problem is one which affects the manufacturers of carbonated soft drinks. Item 36(3) in the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act provides exemption from sales tax for cordials, concentrates and beverages containing the juice of Australian fruits and, in particular, cordials and concentrates which consist of not less than 25 per cent by volume of juices of Australian fruits. Unfortunately carbonated beverages are not accepted as being either cordials or concentrates for the making of non-alcoholic beverages, irrespective of whether they have that 25 per cent Australian fruit juice content. It would be fair to say that carbonated beverages are enjoyed by all sections of society and cannot be regarded today as a luxury. They are also a valuable alternative to alcohol for teenagers, young adults and teetotallers in general. The imposition of the general rate of tax on this product is discriminatory. The moment any such beverage is carbonated the exemption is forfeited. It seems that bubbles and fizz act as the catalyst for tax to be applied.

Advice I have received from two soft drink manufacturers in the Hinkler electorate indicates that representatives of the Australian Council of Soft Drink Manufacturers, in discussions with Treasury officials, were advised that the discrimination suffered was never based on anything other than revenue grounds as the current exemption enjoyed by fruit juices is based on an Australian fruit juice content of 25 per cent. A story in the Australian Financial Review of 15 March 1985 reported the Council's discussions with Treasury officials in a similar vein. This discrimination surely is worthy of investigation by the Treasurer if he is sincere in reducing anomalies and inconsistencies in the wholesale sales tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is not.
—Of course he is not. I do hope, though, that after the debate has finished on this Bill his advisers will take it back to him and suggest that he should have another look at it.
—I think they might.

—I hope they do. There is an area of wholesale taxation which has long angered those taxpayers who reside outside the metropolitan areas. I am referring, of course, to the imposition of sales tax on the freight component of goods costing. The general principle indicates that all costs incurred up to the point where the property in goods passes to the buyer and which are charged by the wholesaler to the buyer form part of the price for which the goods are sold. The manner in which charges connected with a sale of goods are invoiced by the vendor is not in itself a determining factor in deciding whether or not those charges form part of the sale value of goods for tax purposes. Hence the sale price necessarily includes all amounts charged by the vendor, who is not entitled to deduct from the sale value of goods sold by him by wholesale any amounts which are an element of cost such as freight. The High Court of Australia has held, in the case of Commonwealth Quarries and the Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1938), that where the sale price of goods includes the cost of delivery, the sale value of the goods for the purpose of section 18 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) is the price actually charged, including cost of delivery.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to the rural policy speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Griffith in New South Wales on 20 February 1983. The Prime Minister said:
The added cost for country people imposed by sales tax calculated on the freight component of goods will be abolished.

Of course, we have heard many a similar memorable quote from the Prime Minister. Now this much-heralded tax reform package has failed to incorporate the Prime Minister's rural policy speech promise. One would have thought that, given the opportunity to embark on a rationalisation of the existing tax system to reduce distortions, the greatest Treasurer in the world would have honoured his Leader's promise. In the Sunday Sun of 29 September 1985 the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) has been quoted as saying:

People in rural and provincial Australia still bear enormous financial and social costs by living where they do. One of the worst is sales tax on freight. Freight is an enormous component in rural living costs and it is taxable as well. It has been described as impossible to move, and I have sought from the Treasurer some means of balancing this sort of cost.
As a member of the Government's rural policy committee he has had a great part to play in devising this sales tax legislation.

I add also that the honourable member for Capricornia has a pet answer when he is barrelled by constituents who are concerned about matters in his electorate. He goes to the media and states that it is clear that the Government has been ill-advised by the relevant department. He forgets that he is a member of a committee which could be ensuring that information received from the various departments, which is passed on to Ministers, is in fact correct.

Listening to the self-praise the Government heaps upon itself I would have thought nothing was impossible. I ask the Treasurer, in regard to the freight component, whether it is impossible to remove the freight component from the calculations used to determine sales tax at the point of sale. I put that question to him so that he can answer it and clear it up once and for all. I do not necessarily mean now, under the existing legislation; I mean, is it impossible forever? Is it possible for the legislators in this House to take some action to stop that iniquitous situation of the imposition of sales tax on freight, which is a burden on people in the more isolated areas. It is a ridiculous situation when they are trying to make a living.

There are many other things I wish to bring to the notice of the House. One matter we should look at is the difference between the 30 per cent tax on cosmetics and the 20 per cent tax on toiletries which has been referred to in this debate. I am not sure whether that discriminates against women or it is a deterrent tax on those men with feminine tendencies who may wish to buy some lipstick now and again. I think that we should look at the question from both sides and find out why there is a 10 per cent difference between those two sales taxes. I mention also that I wish Ministers would use some other words when presenting statements on the various Bills which come before this House. In regard to horses imported into Australia, the explanatory memorandum to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill states:
. . . where horses have been imported into Australia . . . but are entered for home consumption on or after that date . . . no sales tax will be payable . . .
I stress the word `consumption'. Therefore, I would hope that the humble pie which the Government must eventually eat on this Bill does not contain that horse meat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are considering is a package of Bills concerned with the sales tax adjustments that were part of the sales tax proposals announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this chamber on 19 September. The most important of those Bills, which has been recognised by other honourable members who have spoken in this debate, is the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985. The whole series of 11 Bills is designed to give effect to the rationalisation of the base broadening measures which formed part of the Treasurer's statement presented to the House recently. Apart from the rationalisation of some of the applications of the rates to particular types of commodities, to which attention has been drawn by other honourable members, one of the most important provisions is the reduction of the four rates to three. Those three new rates, apart from commodities which are excluded completely from any sales tax, are 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. I think that sufficient attention has been given to the particular details of these proposals, according to the concerns and priorities which have been expressed by individual members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the contribution made by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the shadow Treasurer, who led for the Opposition in connection with this legislation. I do not mind-I think it is desirable-that members take advantage of the opportunity on occasions to introduce some humour into their contribution. My colleague, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), did that admirably, but I think we should expect a little more from the person who leads for the Opposition. Probably one of the reasons that the honourable member for Mackellar made a speech which was considerably less than substantial-

TALK.START.PARA: —Trivial.

—He trivialised it. I appreciate the suggestion by my valued colleague, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who made a very compelling case when he made his contribution to this debate earlier. He said that the speech was trivialised. Of course it was trivialised and I think that is most unfortunate. The honourable member for Mackellar, in the process of trivialising his speech, took the whole half hour while we have been cutting our speeches to 10 minutes because this legislation has to get through. I noticed that the members of the Opposition have been taking their 20 minutes, but the fellow who led for them took 30 minutes. He spent one-third of that time discussing the ice cream question. He did that because a few representatives of the ice cream industry were sitting in the gallery.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not mind honourable members playing to the gallery-we all do it to some extent-but when the person leading for the Opposition takes one-third of his half hour to talk about one particular commodity contained in the provisions, simply because a few representatives are sitting in the gallery, it indicates the paucity of his understanding and thinking about the whole question of the tax proposals and the tax structure in Australia. It indicates also the complete absence at this stage of any alternative proposals which the Opposition might put before the Parliament. We expect the person who leads for the Opposition to present the Opposition's alternative. The members of the Opposition are not doing it. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said that it is not their responsibility. He said that they are supposed to be given time. I accept absolutely that honourable members are entitled to have time to get their act together, but they had better start doing it because so many people on the Opposition bench at present are making contradictory statements about the Opposition's taxation policy.

We know, for example, that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when he was Treasurer and shadow Treasurer, said all the time that we could not have substantial, significant, effective and long lasting amendments to the taxation system in Australia unless we moved to a broad-based consumption tax. He has been betrayed, sabotaged and isolated. He has been repudiated by his own shadow Minister for Finance, Senator Messner, who said that if the Opposition gets into government it will not have a broad-based consumption tax. What a ludicrous situation this is. I do not mind members of the Opposition referring to ice creams and blaming us for putting a tax on the ice creams the kids buy. That is all good stuff. I am sure that it went over very well with the children who were in the gallery. They probably thought that our chief pre-occupation while in government is to take the money out of the pockets of school kids.

Let me put this into context. I am being serious about this. I do not mind that sort of approach. I do not mind even the hypocritical elements that might be in that sort of argument, but I want to put it into context. In the last year that the Opposition was in government an extra quarter of a million people were thrown into unemployment. They were breadwinners; mothers and fathers with families to support. The members of the Opposition should not come in here and go on in that hypocritical way about the Government taxing ice creams whey they were directly responsible, with the economic policies they pursued and the lack of economic direction they had, for throwing on the unemployment scrapheap 250,000 people in one year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Honourable members on this side of the Parliament seem to have drawn to their attention fairly frequently that they must confine their remarks to the Bills before the House.
-Order! There is no point of order.
—There is a point of order which is relevant.
—Order! I have ruled to the honourable member that there is no point of order.

—An outstanding ruling you gave, Madam Deputy Speaker. By way of contrast, I refer to the fact that during the three years we have been in government, we have only about 13,000 jobs to create to reach that half a million level we set as our target.
—Did you say half a million?

—That is exactly what I said; half a million more people are in jobs now as a result of the policies of this Government. Members of this Parliament should know that many of those people in those 500,000 new jobs that have been created are breadwinners in my electorate. The economic policies for which members of the Opposition were responsible made sure that the kids, whether ice cream was taxed or not, could not buy ice cream. When my constituents were unemployed as a result of the appalling policies of Opposition members, there were no ice creams being brought into those households. But there are 500,000 households in Australia now where the kids can buy ice cream. Let us not have any of this hypocritical posturing we have been hearing from members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to an article to which my colleague the honourable member for Stirling, in his outstanding contribution, also referred. It is an article by Ross Gittins, a person of objective perceptions, a person who writes very effective columns and makes very effective commentaries on many of these issues. In his column `Monday Comment' just recently, Mr Gittins started off with these words:

If ever there was a classic example of the business community's political ineptitude, it's the cosmetics industry's belated campaign to have the sales tax on its products cut from 30 per cent to 20 per cent.
Further on, he went on to say:
So where was the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association last June, when Mr Keating was fighting the battle of his career to persuade the unions and his own party-
let me say that I was one of his own Party-

to accept a broad-based consumption tax? Where was it when he was battling to have the tax on the association's products cut from 32.5 per cent wholesale to 12.5 per cent retail? Was it taking out full-page advertisements to demonstrate that there was a lot of business support for the Treasurer?
Ross Gittins said:
No fear! It was keeping its head down, leaving politics to the politicians.
Ross Gittins went on to say:
In the antics of the cosmetic industry we have a classic example of the business community's perverted approach to politics-
What a compelling comment to make. He said:
. . . it won't back governments when they are trying to achieve something positive, all it will do is attack them when it reckons it's getting a raw deal.
That is precisely what has happened.

I want to draw attention to the fact that this particular proposal and these tax proposals generally are very much an essential component of the trilogy commitment that this Government undertook-the most rigid fiscal discipline that any government in Australia's history has ever willingly adopted and committed itself to. The most important part of that trilogy of commitments, the first one, was that the overall level of taxation would not be increased as a proportion of gross domestic product. All of this tax package is directed not only towards restructuring the taxation system to ensure that, as far as possible, we introduce into the system greater fairness, equity, justice, simplicity and efficiency, but also to ensuring that in the process of bringing about this restructuring we do not take advantage of the opportunity to increase the total taxation take. We are not doing that.

It was a further confirmation of those extremely important taxation principles that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) explained in one of the most important statements on taxation that has ever been presented to this national Parliament. The Government's taxation policy statement by the Prime Minister on 31 October l984 is one of the reasons why we were so convincingly returned to the treasury bench at the last election. We spelt out very clearly the principles that would govern the Government's approach to taxation reform. Just for the sake of the record, and in conclusion, I will repeat what they were. There was to be, first, no increase in overall taxation; secondly, more cuts in personal income tax; thirdly, a smashing of the avoidance and evasion; fourthly, the system must be simpler; fifthly, it must be fairer; sixthly, there must be no disadvantage to welfare recipients; seventhly, it must be acceptable to employers and unions; eighthly, it must encourage growth; and ninthly, it must have widespread support.

We know and the Opposition knows-and the Opposition is embarrassed by the fact that it knows-that the Australian community right across the spectrum rejoices in the great successes of this Government and applauds the Government for the successes that it is achieving.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Darling) Before calling the next speaker, I draw the attention of honourable members on both sides of the House to the fact that a certain amount of leeway is allowed by the Chair when the House is debating Bills such as these, in regard to bringing in anecdotal and comparative material, and the Chair makes that decision; but when an honourable member goes on in an unrelated manner and for a prolonged amount of time, that member will be called to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the comments made by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), I would like to make some observations and draw these to the attention of honourable members. I think his comments were quite unkind and quite unnecessary. He suggested that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who led for the Opposition, trivialised the debate. I must say that, in comparison with the honourable member for Charlton, at least the honourable member for Mackellar was able to join issue on the matters that were relevant to the debate, whereas I must say, without in any way reflecting on the Chair, Madam Deputy Speaker, that most of the address of the honourable member for Charlton bore little relationship to the important issues that are being discussed today. Really, it was only in relation to the evidence that the honourable member brought before the House in the form of a quotation from an article by Mr Gittins that he really attempted to canvass, by way of debate, issues raised in the discussion that has taken place today.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the honourable member for Charlton might have been somewhat mischievous in quoting Mr Gittins to suggest that the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia had not put a view to the Government on the question of sales tax, because the honourable member quoted a writer who could be forgiven for not knowing whether representations were made in relation to this matter. However, the honourable member himself did not offer a view from his own knowledge as to whether a submission was made. He was perhaps being a little disingenuous about that, because he would have been in a position to have made inquiries to find out whether a submission had been made. I do not know whether a submission has been made by the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia, but I did receive a letter-I am sure it is the same as the honourable member received-and in that letter, dated 8 October l985, this statement is made:
The CTFAA provided detailed submissions to the Government and the Economic Planning Advisory Council at the time of its review of the Australian Taxation System.

That is what that organisation says it did. I do not suggest that it would want to be misleading me or the Parliament; but the honourable member would have been in a position to make inquiries about that. For him to come in here quoting some writer who would not be in a position to know that, as if it were in some way authoritative, to rebut the arguments that have been advanced in this matter does not do the honourable member any credit whatsoever.

I am prepared to take the cut and thrust that we have in this place. I am prepared to accept the arguments about whether we were responsible for unemployment or whether the Government's record is better than ours or worse than ours. Those arguments will go on from time to time. But in advancing those arguments we have not heard any reasoned comment in relation to the claim made by the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia about the impact of these sales tax changes on its industry in particular. I do not believe it is trivialising the debate one iota for honourable members to canvass in this discussion the way in which the wholesale sales tax rates are being rationalised and the impact of those decisions that the Government has made. Nor do I regard it as being trivial that one should want to canvass-as I shall do, in a short while-the extent to which the decisions taken by the Government, in its own words, represent a real rationalisation of the wholesale sales tax system.

When one recognises the Government's statements, as I do, looks at them and is asked to accept them at face value, in my judgment, one is certainly entitled to go through the individual decisions that have been made and to ask whether those decisions give effect to the Government's stated objectives. That is not trivialising the debate one iota. It is a serious contribution, as was the contribution by the honourable member for Mackellar. It will be equally seriously put by me in this debate that the Government's decisions in this area do not represent a reduction in the distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies that exist in the wholesale sales tax system.

I have an interest in this matter because a significant manufacturer in my electorate is Rexona Pty Ltd, a company that manufactures at North Rocks, New South Wales. The company wrote to me. It may have written to other honourable members. I know that the honourable member for Mackellar had the information the company provided before him when he was speaking on this subject. The letter made the point that the statement by the Treasurer suggested that only cosmetics, perfumery and bath salts, as personal products, would be left in the Schedule that deals with luxury items and that one would have been entitled, upon reading that statement, to have assumed that the tax on other products, that were not perfume, cosmetics or bath salts, would have been reduced to the 20 per cent margin and those products put into the general category.

Rexona was genuinely surprised when it read the detail of the changes that are to be made by the Government. It has noted particularly that shampoos, hair conditioners and deodorants are being classed as cosmetics and taxed at the luxury rate. All honourable members would recognise that those products, in particular, are used by something of the order of 90 per cent of Australian households. Very few Australian households would not use those products. They do not differ significantly from toilet soaps, toothpaste or shaving preparations. They are personal products, clearly regarded by most Australians as necessities of life. They are sold through major department stores and outlets, supermarkets and the like. They are not sold in perfumeries in the broad. Rexona's product range, in particular, is sold in places such as Coles, Woolworths, Franklins, Bi-Lo, Jack the Slasher and Jewel. Those stores are general food and merchandise outlets.

Rexona makes the following comparisons in relation to its product range. The following products are taxed at the 20 per cent rate: Pears toilet soap, Menage after shave, fabric conditioner, dog shampoo, shaving cream, room deodorant and breath freshener. The following products are taxed at the 30 per cent rate: Pears shampoo, Menage Splash-on, Sunsilk conditioner, Family shampoo, Depilatory cream, Rexona deodorant and Norsca cologne. Clearly, those products are comparative. Yet when one looks at the way each product has been taxed, one sees very clear distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies. Such anomalies could have been addressed quite reasonably by the Government if it were prepared to look at the second Schedule. I draw to the attention of honourable members the items contained in the second Schedule. They can make their own judgment as to the simplicity of the change that could have been effected if the Government had the will to do so.

Item No. 19 of the second Schedule includes: Hair oils, hair lotions, hair lacquers, hair settings, hair dressings, hair trainers, hair tonics, hair restorers, hair tints, shampoos, hair rinses, hair bleaching preparations, hair dyes, hair dye removers, pomades and hair waving solutions, hair emulsions, sachets and hair medications. In regard to some of those items, particularly hair medications for dandruff and the like, one asks: On what basis should they be classified as luxury items? If one were determined to catch exquisite French perfumes, one might elect to leave in the Schedule item 27, which clearly refers to perfumery, eau-de-cologne and toilet waters. Products such as leg tan creams, suntan oils, body powders, foot powders, nail polishes and lacquers, face powders, rouge and items of that sort clearly should be removed from the Schedule and, in my judgment, properly so.

When one looks at the goods that are to be removed one sees greater inconsistencies. The Government saw fit to remove from the Schedule item 31 which deals with safety razors, safety razor blades, electric shavers and other mechanical shavers and parts and accessories for those shavers. The Government also saw fit to remove from the Schedule item No. 32, shaving brushes, and item No. 33, shaving sticks, shaving creams, shaving soaps, shaving powders, shaving tablets, styptic pencils and liquids and other preparations for use before or after shaving. Item No. 34, shaving sets containing any goods covered by items Nos 31, 32 or 33, is to be removed from the Schedule. Item No. 35, toilet or dressing cases and toilet or dressing sets, including home hair waving sets, hair brushes, hair combs, eye-brow brushes, hand mirrors, clothes brushes, hat brushes, manicure and pedicure sets and pieces, dressing table sets and hair tidies, is also to be removed.

Looking at the other items the Government has seen fit to remove from the Schedule, such as serviette rings, book ends, book marks, collar boxes, jewel boxes, jewel cases, tie boxes, handkerchief boxes, stud boxes, paper weights, paper knives, fobs, nut crackers, incense burners, card cases, cocktail picks, toothpicks, cigar or cigarette cases and lighters for cigarettes, cigars or pipes, serves only to highlight the Government's inconsistencies. Item No. 8 is to be removed from the Schedule. It includes fancy goods made of ivory. I thought we were not able to sell ivory goods in Australia because they are made from a prohibited import, the elephant, from which the ivory comes being an endangered species. Yet fancy goods made of ivory are to be taxed at 20 per cent. Inconsistencies abound, yet the Government would have us believe that this reform is very significant, that it is a rationalisation of the wholesale sales tax system and part of the Government's efforts to put in place significant tax reforms to meet the objectives the Government set for itself and held out to all Australians as being significant. Yet in these inconsistencies we recognise-I certainly recognise-that we have been presented with an ad hoc arrangement put together in the dead of night, certainly very much in a rush-

TALK.START.PARA: —In a motel room.

—I do not know whether Government members got down to dealing with what items they would leave in the Schedules when they met at the Canberra International Motor Inn to settle the tax arrangements. However, obviously the arrangements were made at that time in that way. The Government has brought forward a document that is easily as defective as all that has gone before, of which people have been critical and which people have claimed has been full of distortions, anomalies and inconsistencies. Certainly, this document is every bit of that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Charlton suggested that honourable members on this side of the House were not giving their time and attention to dealing with tax reform and that we were not announcing our own proposals on tax reform at this time. I make the point, very properly, that the Government is now bringing forward its proposals. They deserve to be examined properly. I am prepared to be involved in that process and to discuss with the Government its proposals. Our proposals have to be put to the people at the time they have to make a decision as to whether they will re-elect the Government or elect us. The proposals do not have to be advanced on the Government's timetable. They have to be advanced at a time when the electorate can make a judgment of its own. They will be in order at that time. The people of Australia will be in a very well informed position as a result of the efforts of the Opposition to ensure that they have before them proposals that will present a coherent and realistic reform of the taxation system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government makes much in support of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill about introducing a more rational and fairer system of sales tax and of correcting anomalies. We have heard honourable members in the debate this morning dilate about anomalies that seem to have been created or will be created by this legislation in relation to items as humble as ice cream, biscuits, cakes, cheescakes, puddings, chips, cosmetics and the like. We heard the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) dilate about the shadow Treasurer trivialising this debate by discussing ice cream. It may be trivialisation, so far as that high flying macro-economist the honourable member for Charlton is concerned, to talk about a tax on ice cream, but it is certainly not trivialisation for the ordinary housewife, the average Australian, to whom ice cream is an important and pleasant part of the diet. The honourable member for Charlton, the great macro-economist, is obviously out of touch with the ordinary people of this country-the people he is elected to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of note that the legislation does not attempt to address the greatest injustice, the greatest irrationalism and the greatest anomaly of the sales tax system. This was referred to earlier by my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest). It is quite simply, as has been stated many times before in this chamber, the imposition of additional cost on Australian consumers who have chosen to live at any distance from the major centres of production and manufacturing. I am sure that I do not have to draw the attention of the responsible Minister to this discriminatory facet of the sales tax system. The plain fact is that, since manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers must make provision for freight costs in their prices, sales tax is proportionately higher for the retailer who supplies the market in more remote locations. Of course, the retailer passes on that cost to the consumer-the same person who eats the ice cream. It is one of those factors that impose upon those living in the Northern Territory, northern Australia and those other parts of Australia outside the south-eastern seaboard a higher cost of living.

I am fully aware that this Government could not give a hoot for the residents of the Northern Territory, and the Government's failure to address this discriminatory aspect of the sales tax is one of the least proofs of that. However, since this Government makes so much of its alleged concern for a more equitable Australia, I might be forgiven for believing that it would wish to address this anomaly. After all, while anomalies concerning the importation of horses or the cost of dog shampoo may more readily capture the imagination of Ministers, anomalies concerning the equal treatment of people should also cause them some worry. I accept that there is no easy answer to this anomaly through the sales tax system. The Northern Territory Government some years ago introduced a system allowing rebates on the freight component of sales tax, so I understand the complexity of the problem. I am by no means certain that I accept the arguments put forward that changes to the points at which the sales tax is levied would only create other difficulties, but I am aware that the Taxation Review Committee chaired by Justice Asprey and the first Commonwealth Committee on Taxation both addressed themselves to this problem and recommended that no changes be made. Specifically, the Asprey Committee stated its view in these words:
Equity cannot be achieved without sacrificing simplicity and certainty and unduly increasing compliance costs and the costs of collection of the tax. It therefore does not recommend any change.

Accordingly, bowing to higher authority, I propose that the Government should find ways and means outside the actual sales tax legislation to correct the anomaly. It is obvious how the Government can achieve this move towards a more equitable Australia. A zone tax rebate was introduced specifically to compensate Australians in the more remote parts of our country for exactly this kind of additional cost of living charge. In fact, I am reliably informed that, if the Government were to take into consideration the inflation factor and match the level at which zone tax rebates were set when Ben Chifley introduced the concept in 1945, they would presently stand at 10 times their current level. I would not expect this Government to be willing to multiply the current rebate system by a factor of 10. However, the zone deduction-since 1975, the zone rebate system-has been steadily whittled away since it was introduced. We saw marginal increases in the zone A and B rebates in the 1984 Budget and in 1981-82, but those increases have by no means compensated remote Australians for the annual inflation rate over the years.

It is also of some note that deductions allowable were considerably increased in the early years of operation, rising from $80 to $240 in 1947, to $360 in 1956 and to $540 in 1958 for zone A recipients. This reflected the then national Government's concern to encourage the development of the more remote parts of this country. In more recent years the zone allowances have in no way served to compensate for the imposts placed upon remote Australians by such anomalies as those contained in the sales tax system as it is today. The sales tax impost is only one of many ways in which those Australians who by choice or by birth live in remote areas are discriminated against and treated unequally by Commonwealth legislation and priority. If this Government finds itself unable to find ways and means, either through direct rebate on the freight component of sales tax or through zone allowances or by other means, to compensate these people, it must accept that it will be justly accused of pure humbug when it parades its alleged concern for a more equitable Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills before the House today are the remnant of the Hawke Government's broad-ranging proposals announced in June to reform this area of the taxation system. We all saw the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stand up before the people of Australia and proclaim that we were going to have, in effect, a brave new world. We all saw the way in which the Treasurer claimed that the Government was going to move decisively and firmly and take steps that would be looked up to for many years by the people of Australia. We know the way in which the Treasurer claimed that the tax reform he was going to introduce would be the most wide-ranging and broadly based tax reform this country had seen for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: The wholesale tax package which this Government has the hide and the audacity to bring before this Parliament today is the only remnant of that late, unlamented, bold attempt just a short time ago to broaden the indirect tax base. It is interesting to consider the way in which the Treasurer, after he produced in June 1985 his little white booklet entitled `Reform of the Australian Tax System', at taxpayers cost, expended so much time and effort in trying to sell these unacceptable alternatives. We had option A, option B, option C, and so on. But as the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, quite rightly indicated, there really was only one option on the agenda, one option on the menu, and that was option ACTU.

We heard a lot about tax carts. We heard claims from various members opposite that they were firmly inside the Treasurer's tax cart. What an awful place to be, particularly when that tax cart became a night cart and was hijacked by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. What a terrible shock Australian Labor Party members must have had when that night cart crossed the finishing line minus a wheel, as I think the Treasurer said. It was a very unpleasant situation for them, and I am certain that we on this side of the House have every sympathy for their wholehearted endorsement of the Treasurer in this matter.

The Prime Minister also gave us a keen insight into his loyalty and character. We now know a little more about this man who promised so much to the people of Australia in 1983, this man who was prepared to promise anything in order to crawl into office. We saw the loyalty that he gave to his Treasurer. The Treasurer was sold down the drain by the Prime Minister when the Prime Minister pulled the rug from under him in his deal with the ACTU, a sordid deal in a Canberra motel during the tax summit fraud.

The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), one of my National Party colleagues, was ejected from this chamber when he, as a representative of the people, tried to come in here and listen to the charade that was going on when the Government had spent a fortune to bring people from all over this country to talk about tax options. What happened? These people came into this Parliament-I might add that permission was not asked of Parliament for this place to be used-and kicked the Government. They said they would not have options A, B, C or D at any price. The people of Australia rejected overwhelmingly the repeated efforts of the Treasurer to sell his preferred option. That option-C, I think he called it-was designed originally to raise a net $6.8 billion, just a bit more than the Government's anticipated budgetary deficit this year. It was thought that sort of money raised from indirect taxes would give substantial relief to the ordinary taxpayers of Australia, the ordinary taxpayers who have been over-taxed by this high spending profligate Government since March 1983. The $6.8 billion that was supposed to be raised has turned out to be a fizzer. We find that all the Government claims it will now raise is a net $110m extra revenue in a full year. Yet the Treasurer comes into this place and tries to suggest that he is like Moses bringing forth the commandments. He tries to suggest that Australians will in some way be impressed by his meagre efforts.

It was interesting to hear some of the various anomalies that were outlined by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who will soon be the Treasurer of Australia. The honourable member spoke very eloquently just a short time ago on this matter. He pointed out that basic food items, such as biscuits and ice cream, would be taxed at 10 per cent despite the Government's earlier decision not to tax food. That is another promise that has been broken, another worthless promise which can be added to the promises that were torn up after the Labor Party policy speech charade at the Sydney Opera House in 1983. Men's toiletries and even dog shampoo are taxed at 20 per cent, whereas cosmetics for women are taxed at 30 per cent. What does this mean? Does it mean that this Government is discriminating against women?

TALK.START.PARA: —It hates women.

—It could be. Perhaps that is why it brought in that ill-conceived Sex Discrimination Act just a short time ago. The Government believes that women are not able to take their proper place in society without government assistance. I believe that the women of Australia and yourself, Madam Deputy Speaker, as a woman who has come into this House representing her electorate, have indicated that they are quite able to compete. The people who conceived that Sex Discrimination Act must stand condemned because of some of the terrible things that were included in that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Government has a down on music, but pianola rolls, for which there is only one manufacturer in Australia and from which the tax was removed by Mr Howard when he was Treasurer, are to be taxed at 20 per cent. On the other hand, toothpicks and paperweights have had their tax reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. The Government suggests that these are rationalising measures and claims that it is trying to make the situation a little better. But as the shadow Treasurer said:
The changes fiddle at the edge of tax reform, but even the fiddling is out of key.

I would take that just a little further. I would say that not only is the fiddling out of key, but also that the Government is totally out of step with the Australian people. At the time of the next election-and we do not know exactly when that will be-the people of Australia will sweep this Government to the dustbin of history where it can join its late unlamented predecessor, the Whitlam socialist Government.

We, on this side of the House, wish to stand up and expose once and for all the audacity of this Government in parading before the men and women of Australia in coming to this place, in going on to the television screens and into the newspapers of this nation pretending that it is bringing forward the most wide ranging changes in the Australian taxation system. This package which is being brought before the House today is an attempt, an attempt which will fail, to salvage a bit of face for the Treasurer. With the Prime Minister stabbing him in the back over this issue and the people of Australia rejecting the Government's preferred option and its surrender to option ACTU with its associated tax carts, night carts and so on, I think that the Treasurer and the Government are in real trouble and I am quite certain that they will be swept from office at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all the honourable members who have taken part in this wide ranging debate. Whenever the subject of sales tax is before the Parliament it gives a lot of joy to a lot of members of the Opposition because it is easy to find anomalies. Where lines must be drawn, there are always difficulties on the margins. However, I wish to pay attention to a couple of the points that were raised by honourable members. For example, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) raised the question of sales tax on freight. On 15 May 1985 I addressed this matter during my reply to the debate on other significant reforms of the sales tax law that have been introduced by this Government. As I explained, we are all interested in this issue. We would love to be able to do something about it. However, it is a very complex issue. Years ago it was considered by a Senate select committee and to date no one has been able to devise a legislative solution to this problem. I believe that there is an inequity in sales tax being applied to freight and I would welcome any suggestions from the Opposition that are constructive in resolving this matter. However, I understand that many manufacturers and wholesalers, when dealing with country clients, arrange their transactions so that the property and the goods pass free on board and the freight is excluded from the sales tax. I wish that we would see more of this practice.

SPEECH.PARA: There were also concerns about sales tax on cosmetics, toiletries and similar products. We have all noticed the advertisements and I will not describe them because unfortunately I have only a minute to go as these Bills need to be passed by lunchtime. It is not argued that the tax treatment of those items is wholly free from anomalies. With a multiple rate structure anomalies are difficult to avoid, as I said earlier. Retention of certain items at the 30 per cent rate was necessary, principally for revenue considerations. Getting rid of anomalies was not the main consideration. We had difficult choices to make, but all in all this is a package which can be defended. I defend it and I believe that all the nit picking that has gone on in this debate is nothing more than that-nit picking. The total package is one that is worthy of a responsible and worthy government. Once again I thank all honourable members who took part and I hope that the Bill will receive the recognition that it deserves.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
