QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. I ask him: Will he ask the acting head of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet whether a report in this morning's Press that that same acting head had been subject to duress in providing what purported to be an apology to the Prime Minister last week is in fact a correct report? Will he arrange for the tabling in this Parliament of all drafts of that apology which were apparently the subject of duress exerted by Mr Barron of the Prime Minister's staff on Mr Visbord?

—I can assure the Leader of the Opposition that the acting head of the Department saw me yesterday to suggest that there might be some questions such as this and to reassure me that there is no truth at all in the story now published. The story must have been going the rounds for a couple of days. I accept what the honourable gentleman has said on the basis of a Press report. I hope that he accepts what I now say: The Press report is without foundation.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware of a report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald which claims that the New South Wales Law Reform Commission has questioned the publication of disclosures by jurors on their deliberations and proposed that such coverage should be made an offence? In the light of the publication of jurors' disclosures in two recent trials, will the Attorney-General give consideration to enacting legislation to restrict disclosures of jury deliberations in Federal courts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dobell for the question. It is a matter that has been of some concern in the course of the administration of justice. The system of justice relies on the integrity and acceptance of the jury system. There has been a suggestion that, where there is some attempt, perhaps even well meaning, by the media to find out what might have happened in the jury room, to find out whether there was unanimity or for some other purpose, this could well seriously jeopardise the trial of someone. More importantly, from the point of view of justice, it could jeopardise public support for the jury system.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice the report by the New South Wales Law Reform Commission. It talks not only about that but also about the question of majority verdicts. I will address my mind to the question of the right of privacy of the jury and the right of protection from harassment. These are the important things. If we accept the view that the verdict of the jury is final, conclusive and singular in that sense, it detracts from it if attempts are made to go behind that verdict and suggest that there may have been a plurality of considerations or differences of opinion. In other words, we could reach the situation where there is no respect for the jury decision.

It is recognised that the freedom of the Press entitles it at the appropriate time to make Press comment and perhaps to refer to the decision of a jury. But in some of the more recent media interest in jury matters, there has been a suggestion that perhaps a jury brought in a verdict that was not intended and, in one case, that occurred while the jury had brought in the verdict, but the judge had not brought in the question of what penalty might be imposed. In that lapse of time, all sorts of imputations are made not only within the media but also in other places. Then there is the inevitable result that members of the jury start to defend themselves in the media. There was nothing but a contest in the media of what might have happened in the jury room. It did nothing for the question of justice. At present we need to consider this matter in the context of freedom of the Press. We must also place emphasis on the fact that there should be no harassment or interference with the decision of a jury.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Hayden?

—The honourable member can point to people on his side. I will not be diverted from what I was endeavouring to say which is that the jury system is one of the most valuable ones. It is one that I want to see continue without having to impose legislation. There is always the question of contempt, which can be a matter for the court itself. I am reminded by advice that I have received that the Australian Law Reform Commission was given a reference on contempt which would include the question of the law of contempt to protect the secrecy of jury deliberations. That reference was given to the Commission in April 1983 and we will consider that report as soon as it becomes available. I look forward to it. I assure the honourable gentleman that the question that he raised is a very serious one. It is very important that not only the people but also the media understand that they have a responsibility not to try to interfere with the course of justice. That means allowing the jury to come to its deliberations without any harassment or invasion of privacy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Will the Government, without any qualification, condemn the 35-hour week deal done between the Builders Labourers Federation of Australia and a major building company, in clear breach of the accord, the building industry agreement and the Government's own code of conduct for the building industry? What action will the Government take to stop this deal in particular and to prevent any more such deals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a number of things about this question. Firstly, of course, we are aware of the situation to which the honourable member refers. There were various reports in the newspapers and other media this morning relating to claims by the Builders Labourers Federation of Australia to have achieved a 35-hour week on one substantial building project in Victoria, and to being close to achieving a 35-hour week in another one. My understanding of the situation is that neither of those claims is correct. In respect of the first development, the Jack Chia development in South Yarra, Melbourne, which is a very large construction project, a 36-hour week has been negotiated not by the Builders Labourers Federation as such but by the building industry unions under the auspices of the Victorian Trades Hall Council.

ANSWER.PARA: What has been the situation in Victoria for some time-indeed, throughout virtually the whole of the period of the previous Government-has been a shopping industry agreement. This shopping industry agreement began, interestingly enough, with the Grollo organisation. The agreement provided for over-award payments in respect of work on shopping centre projects and, gradually, for the extension of fewer hours. Since 1981 in Victoria the shopping industry agreement, an informal agreement, has provided for a 36-hour week on Victorian shopping centre construction sites where the shopping centre construction is worth more than $1m. In the case of the Jack Chia project, in stage one there is a shopping centre element worth about $40m in a project worth between $200m and $250m. It is on that basis that the unions have negotiated this 36-hour week on this construction project, in conformity with what has been an arrangement of several years standing in this industry. It is something which began during the reign of the previous Government, which did nothing to reject and repudiate it. It was a pretty well established element of the industry when we came to office.

In respect of the second claim by Mr Gallagher that there was virtually agreement reached on Victoria's central project, which is a major proposed development in La Trobe Street, Melbourne, my understanding is that there have been no negotiations whatsoever with the Builders Labourers Federation regarding a 35-hour week on that project which, at this stage, is a project on paper which may or may not go ahead. More generally, the question of the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation are, of course, a matter of concern to the Government. We totally repudiate Mr Gallagher's claim that he has a right to pursue a 35-hour week. It is quite clear that, under the national wage guidelines, there is no capacity for him to do that. It is quite clear from the building industry agreement that, generally, it is a 38-hour week with the proviso that existing arrangements, such as those at the Victorian shopping centre, will continue to apply. Mr Gallagher is in breach of that agreement and in breach of the national wage principles in trying to achieve a 35-hour week. On the information available to me, his claim that he has achieved one and is about to achieve another is totally incorrect. This Government will certainly do all in its power to prevent breaches of national wage guidelines by the Builders Labourers Federation or any other organisation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QANTAS AIRWAYS LTD: CONCESSIONAL INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware of allegations relating to concessional international travel obtained by a director of Qantas Airways Ltd? If so, what action is being taken on the allegations?
—I am aware of allegations of the nature referred to by the honourable member. The matter is the subject of urgent consideration by me at the moment.

—Will the Treasurer please explain the difference, for tax deduction purposes, between a lunch provided for a client in a restaurant, a lunch provided for a client in a board room and a lunch provided for a client at something called a seminar?

—I can hardly believe this. This is about the fifth go around on the restaurant issue and I do not think I have much more to say. Obviously, if anybody tries to circumvent this change to the tax system by seeking to arrange sham seminars for luncheons, that simply will not be accepted. I am quite certain that the Commissioner of Taxation will break into those arrangements like Elliott Ness into a Chicago brewery.
—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State.
—What about-

—I am not going to ask my question in monosyllables so that the honourable member can understand it. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in today's Age concerning a letter alleged to have been written by Dr Tiller in which Mr Justice Murphy is mentioned? Has he any information to provide to the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the honourable member for O'Connor raised a question during the adjournment debate concerning an alleged letter written between two Perth businessmen which included the name of His Honour, Justice Lionel Murphy. I do not think anybody here needs any introduction to the person so named or to the circumstances in which he now finds himself. Like the previous Government, or those people who have held my portfolio in the past, it has been my intention not to involve the Parliament in investigations being conducted by the Australian Federal Police or, now, the National Crime Authority because there is very little the Parliament can do to help those sorts of things. Nevertheless, this matter has been raised and, as it has received some publicity, I felt it best that those members of the Press who have not already run anything about this matter should be made aware of the circumstances surrounding it.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised by the Australian Federal Police that they received from the Age newspaper a photostat of the letter allegedly written by Dr Tiller to Mr Quartermaine which refers to arranging a meeting with Lionel Murphy on a particular matter. Dr Tiller was interviewed on 5 April in relation to the letter, after the letter had been handed over by the Melbourne Age to the Australian Federal Police. So the matters contained in the letter were not news to the Melbourne Age today. Dr Tiller, in his interview, denied writing, sending or having any knowledge of the contents of the letter. He also stated that he was in Canada at the time the letter was allegedly written. He admitted knowing Mr Quartermaine but denied knowing or ever having met Lionel Murphy. I should say in relation to this matter that, on 24 September, there was an article in the Melbourne Age headed `Surgeon urged agent to avoid tax scandal'. The article states:

A leading WA surgeon under Tax Office scrutiny discussed with a Perth businessman the futility of making `further inducements' to department officials and urged him to seek support from a powerful public figure in Canberra to avoid what he called a public scandal.
Federal Police have questioned orthopaedic specialist Mr Michael Tiller about the letter sent to them by the National Crime Authority in which he wrote to former travel agent Murray Quartermaine.

The letter was not sent by the National Crime Authority to the Australian Federal Police; it was sent by the Melbourne Age. On page 3 of the first edition of the Age, which reached us this morning-obviously, the honourable member for O'Connor must have talked to the Melbourne Age before he made his speech last night-we see an article headed `Murphy was figure named in tax case letter, MP claims'. The article then carries substantially what the honourable member for O'Connor had to say last night.

As I have said, this news is nothing new to the Melbourne Age. It was aware of the content of the letter. That newspaper knew the problems it would have concerning writing anything about it prior to the matter being mentioned under privilege here last night because it had been responsible for handing it to the police, rightly so, for the police to carry out their inquiries.

I should also add that the Australian Federal Police investigations have been hampered by the absence from Australia of both Mr Quartermaine and Mr Moll and the unavailability of the original document. The Australian Federal Police are not in a position to prove the author of the letter. There has been substantial evidence in the past of falsified documents in the Moll case. Australian Federal Police investigations into the activities of Christo Theo Moll are continuing. A warrant has been issued in Western Australia for his arrest. Investigations have revealed a number of other persons involved in the illegal transfer of funds out of Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX: EFFECTS ON CAR INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In view of Senator Button's admission on 9 October that the Government introduced its new fringe benefits tax on cars without a study of its likely effects on the car industry-the industry itself estimates that it will cost 50,000 units and 12,000 jobs-will the Government either now abandon the new tax on cars, which the industry says could cripple the Government's car plan, or amend the car plan to accommodate the effects of the new tax on the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing about members of the Liberal Party of Australia is that they are always out there to protect ramps in the tax system for those people who, for years, they allowed to escape through the 60 per cent net. They never bothered to close loopholes in the tax system because they knew that their constituency was slipping through the 60 per cent rate while everybody else had to pay. Any government which moves to take away those tax opportunities and tax ramps comes under criticism from the Opposition. Let me just say this about the motor industry and the motor plan: At no time when the motor plan was being considered was it ever envisaged by the industry that production would run at these levels. It is running at the highest level that most managers in the industry can remember. The fact of the matter is that it is running at those levels because of demand and employment growth induced into this economy.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is that we are now in a position, as I have said before, where no industry is entitled to prosper under the advantages of tax minimisation. What was happening with the fringe benefits packages, particularly those in respect of motor vehicles provided by employers, was that 100 per cent business deductions were being made available for motor cars which were substantially given to employees for private use. The Government, in reaching its position on motor vehicles, took into account the views put by the motor industry lobby. Indeed, the outcome of the Government's package is fashioned differently from that proposed, for instance, in option A of the White Paper.

Basically, we have provided the users of motor vehicles, be they employers, employees or the self-employed, with a rule to fall back on for a proportion of business use as a deduction without substantiation, or a higher proportion of business use on the basis of substantiation. The fall-back rule is a very generous one. From zero to 25,000 kilometres, tax will be based on 11 per cent of the original cost; from 25,000 to 40,000 kilometres, where a lot of motor vehicles would be, tax will be based on 7.4 per cent of the original cost; and over 40,000 kilometres tax will be based on 3.7 per cent of the original cost. So it is not onerous; it is fair and reasonable. The implication in the question is that the Government should do an employment impact study on every change in the tax system. That is an absurd proposal. I would be in here all the time revealing the Government's assessment of employment impacts for a myriad of tax changes which affect various industries.

The car plan will proceed. The package is designed for possible impacts in respect of consumer choices on motor vehicle production in Australia at the moment. It has to be understood that when the car plan was put together nobody in the industry believed that motor vehicle production would be running at the levels now experienced. It has been experiencing boom conditions and, if anything, supply constraints in the industry have come under pressure. At the moment I think most of the car manufacturers in this country are delighted with the Government's policies. Some honourable members opposite shake their heads. If they shake them any more they will fall off. Why on God's earth do they shake their heads when I say that most members of the motor vehicle industry are delighted with the Government's policy? It has brought the industry prosperity at a time when it was in deep trouble.

Because we are turning back more than we are raising from these tax measures, which will promote consumption-in fact, we are handing back $3 billion more than we are raising by these measures-and reducing the burden of taxation by lifting disposable after-tax incomes on people who have been paying their fair share of tax, people will be encouraged to spend more and consumer confidence will be lifted. The likelihood is that the motor vehicle industry will benefit from lower marginal tax rates and a fairer tax system, a less distorting system. But this is a package, and, like all packages, each part hangs with the other. If these industries wish to complain about the impact of the treatment, the only comment I can make is that they have had it too good for too long in having 100 per cent business deductions for motor vehicles provided under fringe benefit arrangements substantially for private use.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science. What progress has been made in promoting the exploitation of ultraviolet blocking agents derived from coral, as discovered by researchers at the Australian Institute of Marine Science?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is something which may have enormous economic significance for Australia. Researchers at the Institute discovered compounds in the Great Barrier Reef corals which protected coral-producing organisms from damage by solar radiation. Essentially, the corals they are using are large white skull-shaped corals called-I regret to use the word as it is a bit archaic now-niggerhead corals.
—That's a bit racist.

—We will have to change that through legislation. The significance is that coral-producing organisms have been found which prevent damage to the texture of the coral from the sun. The research has been expanded into the isolation of new ultraviolet blocking agents which, as far as we know, are more effective and probably safer than the known agents in commercial use. I say probably because there has been a tendency for the ultraviolet blocking agents themselves to be carcinogenic. Of course, we will have to be very sure, and the testing procedures for human use will be very rigorous.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the economic implications are very significant for things such as varnishes, paints, coatings for wood, coatings for plastic, coatings for fittings in cars, and so forth. So economically it may be very significant indeed. AIMS has concluded a licence agreement with ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd whereby the Institute would apply for an Australian patent and the company would apply, on AIMS's behalf, for foreign patents in the major overseas industrial countries. All the patents considered to be required have now been applied for. The company will pay for and maintain all foreign patents and will pay the Institute royalties determined by the extent of usage of the invention. If the invention fulfils its expectations there is no doubt that it will have a very wide usage, not only in this country but overseas, and may make a major contribution in reducing the dangers inherent in the Australian sun-worshipping lifestyle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs recall the comments in the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security Agencies on Mr David Combe's attributes, which include `hostitility to the CIA and therefore probably to other secret intelligence services'? Can the Minister confirm that intelligence or security functions at the Australian Consulate in Vancouver, at which Mr David Combe will soon take up duty, are to be or have been either downgraded or transferred to the Australian Consulate-General in Los Angeles?

—The Consulate in Vancouver will not be dealing with Central Intelligence Agency matters. If the honourable member cares to look at a map of the world he will find that Vancouver is in Canada and not in the United States of America. I am not aware of Vancouver being a centre which has handled intelligence matters in the past, but I will certainly look at the proposition and let the honourable member know. Frankly, I doubt very much that the assertion explicit in what he said applies in that particular case.
—I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: What new initiatives has the Government undertaken to ensure an equitable share of access to programs and services for migrants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Calwell for his initiative in asking that question.

—It was done on his initiative. I place that on record, Mr Speaker, and I know it is a subject in which you are very interested as well. Indeed, this Government has taken initiatives to ensure that some affirmative action is taken to overcome the disabilities suffered by migrants.
—Make a statement about it.

—A statement has been made about this and it is the proper function of Question Time to elucidate on those questions. I know the Leader of the National Party of Australia is very sensitive on a lot of these issues because the Government of which he was a member for so many years totally ignored the needs of migrants, and particularly of those migrants with a non-English speaking background, who have special disabilities.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very glad indeed of this opportunity to outline to the House the initiatives taken by the Government. In difficult times, when spending has been restrained, our Government nevertheless kept up, and indeed increased, the services for migrant communities. Perish the thought that the coalition will ever return to government, because it would go through the rhetoric of cutting government spending and one of the first things that would go is special services for migrant communities.

I will go through the list of things that our Government has done. We have made information available to migrants in their own language, provided translation services, migrant resource centres and facilities for learning English and so on. So far I have referred only to those services which are being undertaken by my own Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This Government is going further. My Department basically looks after the more recently arrived migrants, but many services, for efficiency and equity reasons, must be delivered by other government departments and statutory bodies. For example, the ethnic aged have special needs which should be undertaken by the particular government department which looks after the aged.

There has been a lot of misunderstanding about the word `mainstreaming'. I will banish that word from my vocabulary because it should be understood that we need to ensure that migrants have equitable access to the programs and services of the Government across the board. The Government's new initiative is a mechanism is to ensure that the other departments and statutory bodies are looking after these special needs.

The Cabinet has given me responsibility to monitor and report on the actions of other departments whose affairs impact on migrants. Those departments will report to me by 30 September each year on the actions they have taken up to the previous 30 June and they will report prospectively on what they will be doing in the following year. The reports will promote for migrants this equitable access to programs and services. I am pleased to say that the reports are now being received from these other departments. When they have been studied and assessed I will be looking for an opportunity to report again to this Parliament. I will have much pleasure in doing so and I would hope that the Opposition will give me the opportunity to report on these important matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs no doubt is aware of the kidnapping of Rob and Jenny Williamson in May this year, while working for the World Bank in Pakistan. It is now claimed that they are in the hands of the Government of Afghanistan, having been held by the Khad, the Afghan State Information Service-the Afghan KGB equivalent-at a detention centre near the Pakistan border. What urgent action will the Minister take, with the Soviet Union in particular, to require this couple's release?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —These people have been in detention for some time, having been abducted by a Sasooli tribe several weeks ago. That was done in retaliation for the gaoling of a Sasooli leader, Alla Ghul, who in turn had been gaoled for the kidnapping of a young child. The proposition was that if Alla Ghul were released these people would be released. The situation has become increasingly confused. It is now doubtful that the Sasooli hold these people; it is more likely that a breakaway tribe has detained them. We suspect that these people are being detained in Afghanistan, although this cannot be established beyond any doubt. We have been involved constantly in representations and I must record publicly our extreme and deep gratitude to the Government of Pakistan for the way in which it has worked unflaggingly to be of assistance. It has gone to the extent of releasing Alla Ghul on parole, in spite of the fact that he was in gaol on a capital offence, in the hope that this would lead to the release of the Williamsons. I cannot say any more on those matters at this point.

ANSWER.PARA: We have made representations to a series of governments. We have made representations in Moscow and we have arranged for representatives to be made in Kabul. We have used friendly governments with good standing in Kabul to use their representatives there to make those representations. The most recent report I have on this matter I received shortly before Question Time. We are making another approach to such a friendly government. I am sure that I do not have to go into all the details here publicly, but I am happy for the honourable member to see all the files on this matter. We are asking that friendly government, because of its good standing with the Government of Kabul, to make further representations for us.

Assertions have been made that the Williamsons are being held by the secret service of the Afghanistan Government. That is not confirmed beyond any doubt. We have been advised equally that a breakway tribal group is detaining these people. All I can say is that we have maintained a constant and alert vigilance and involvement in this matter. We have been assisted greatly by a range of governments and by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, who has also involved himself in this matter. We have maintained very close contact with the parents of Dr and Mrs Williamson. That is where the matter stands. It is a matter of melancholy concern for me that I cannot tell the honourable member more than that, but I can assure him that the diligence and industry which has been displayed to this point will continue unabated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his capacity as Minister responsible for consumer affairs. My question relates to an article in yesterday's edition of the Canberra Times, headed `Tarago now safer'. The article states that Toyota is upgrading the safety standards of Toyota Tarago vans. The question at stake is whether previous Toyota Tarago editions may not have been safe in terms of their passenger safety. I note also that there is such a vehicle in the Commonwealth car fleet. Can the Minister advise the House on the current state of discussions in this respect?

—The question of product safety generally is now being addressed by consumer affairs organisations. As a result of representations made, the honourable member would be aware that the Office of Consumer Affairs in my Department is considering whether it should have the power to recall all unsafe products. So, we are dealing with the problem directly. At this stage the problem is handled on the basis that we would expect the manufacturer immediately to recall any product which was deemed to be unsafe, but I hope that the Trade Practices Act will soon have the force of law for mandatory recall. As to particular matters relating to the vehicle concerned, my attention has not been drawn to this problem. I will have inquiries made in the specific terms in which the question has been addressed and let the honourable gentleman have the advice I receive.

—In the light of the Treasurer's fairly contemptuous dismissal, when he said, in response to the question from the honourable member for Mackellar, that some entertainment expenses can be valid, will he explain to the House the justification for the anomalous treatment between the expenses incurred by a commercial traveller entertaining prospective clients in a restaurant and the Prime Minister entertaining members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the Lodge or Kirribilli House?

—It has not penetrated the dullards on the other side of the House that a business or government can still entertain, but at its own cost. If the Government chooses to entertain an official visitor at its cost, that is its option, as it is the option of a company to entertain a visitor or client. Commercial travellers can entertain clients, but the cost is not deductible. If the commercial traveller chooses to provide such entertainments, they are a cost to the business.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. What effect will the campaign by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory against the transfer of title to Uluru National Park to the Aboriginal traditional owners have on the Territory's tourist industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen for that question. He always exhibits an intelligent view of the tourism industry. It does not please me to tell the House that the campaign being waged by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory is not doing this industry any good at all. He is tramping the country telling the people of Australia, and by implication the world, that Ayers Rock has been lost to Australia, that it will be followed by Katherine Gorge, and that possibly the Barrier Reef will be next to go. Considering the parlous state of the Northern Territory's finances, particularly as the Northern Territory exists almost totally on the benefits of its tourism product, it seems to me to be a rather stupid thing to do, and particularly as he is wasting $300,000 of public money in pursuing his line. The odd thing about it is that this campaign is not only stupid but also highly hypocritical, because only last week the Northern Territory Government spent a lot of money promoting Kakadu National Park as a great tourist resort-as, of course, it is; it is one of the nation's great tourist attractions.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts about Kakadu National Park are worth examining. It is on Aboriginal land. The land was entrusted in the traditional Aboriginal owners by the Fraser Government, to its great credit, in 1978. It was leased back to the Commonwealth and made into a wonderful resort for all Australians, but particularly for international visitors. Those honourable members who have not been to Kakadu National Park should just take the trip there, particularly to Yellow Waters, the wonderful lagoon, where the motel and all the operations are run by an Aboriginal tribe. If honourable members did that, their fears about Ayers Rock might dissipate. So the whole thing is highly ridiculous.

The week before last a questionnaire was distributed around Ayers Rock to the tourists, and 807 questionnaires were completed. One question was: `What is your attitude to the proposals for title transfer and Aboriginal involvement in the management of the Park?'. Of the respondents, 58.6 per cent supported the transfer; 9.7 per cent did not care; 23.6 per cent opposed it; and 8.2 per cent did not comment which is a fairly positive measure of the attitudes of visitors to Uluru National Park about the involvement of the Aboriginal tribe. What is more important is that in an interview last week in the Northern Territory, the manager of the Four Seasons Hotel at Uluru National Park made the observation that the greater the involvement of Aboriginals in the tourism industry in the Northern Territory the better, because one of the great attractions in the Northern Territory is Aboriginal culture. So much for Mr Tuxworth and his barn- storming around Australia wasting public money pursuing a very sleazy argument.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY FARM PRODUCTS: DUMPING

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Acting Prime Minister. It refers to the dumping of European Economic Community farm products on world markets and their effect upon Australian overseas trade. What new actions are being undertaken to make the EEC more aware of the great problems that it is creating for world trade and especially the viability of the Australian farmer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought, Mr Speaker, that I had answered this question yesterday for the honourable member for Capricornia. The new actions that we are taking in respect of the European Economic Community's subsidisation get down to the diplomatic level, exchanges at business level and at government level, trying to point out to the EEC the lack of wisdom in the path it is pursuing. Not only is it damaging efficient agricultural producers such as Australia; it is wrecking the agricultural enterprise of the developing world. In terms of Europe's own sticky economic performance, particularly with respect to manufacturing, the diversion of resources into agriculture is hurting the economic performance of the 10 nations of the EEC.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Agricultural Economics-at the initiation of the previous Government-has been conducting a study for four years, and it produced a report in September. It has come down with the conclusions that the cost to Australian agriculture and to Australia's standard of living is now amounting to about $1 billion a year. Not only that, but the cumulative effect of the common agricultural policy has probably cost Europe about one million jobs. All that the CAP is doing, apart from the attractive politics of it to the rural lobbies in the European countries, is capitalising into land, and about 80 per cent of the value of the CAP is now in the hands of about 20 per cent of the farmers in the European countries. Dr Stoeckel, the Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, is at present in Europe, at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, with various institutes-academic, business and agricultural-pointing out to the Europeans the lack of wisdom in the course that they are pursuing.

At the government level, as I pointed out yesterday, the Prime Minister and I were able to get some understandings with the Europeans on beef. We have been able to have taken on board our comments on the EEC's own internal regime concerning sugar. In terms of the Green Paper on agricultural policy that the Europeans have just brought out, we again are commenting on that and putting pressure on the EEC, through the Commission, and on the member countries. This is wholly a question of diplomacy, discussion, talking, arguing, putting forward academic studies, and taking every action that we can-as well the Opposition understands. The Opposition had a special Minister for trade representation there, the Hon. Vic Garland. The Opposition indulged in a range of strategies. Whereas when in government the Opposition felt that the best approach to the EEC was to kick it in the shins at every chance possible, we believe that the conduct of international relations should not descend to the level of abuse and we are pushing just as hard as Opposition members did in terms of factual content in trying to substantiate the deplorable effect that the CAP is having on agricultural producers in both the developed and the developing world.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has sought my indulgence to add to an answer given to the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I have granted the Minister that indulgence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the honourable member for Bradfield asked a question with respect to the new Trade Commissioner in Vancouver, I have asked the Department of Foreign Affairs to give me information on the detail of the question. The note that I have states:

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as his Consul-General work is concerned, Combe may be required to have access to the usual forms of classified information relating to visa and passport matters. TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Halverson,Mr McArthur and Ms Mayer.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not `windfall gains' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Fife and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Fife and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further capital gains and wealth taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of capital gains and wealth taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Slipper.

PETITION.TITLE: Compensation for Use of Private Property
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That all steps be taken to prevent the continuous erosion of the rights of the holders of freehold land.

Your petitioners draw to the attention of Parliament the denigration of freehold rights as practised in N.S.W. and calls on the Parliament to enact overriding legislation to allow full and proper compensation to all Australians where Government requires the use of private property and traditional rights attached thereto.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. That we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. That increases in fuel prices adds to farm costs and further reduces the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petitions of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That we wish you to reverse the decision to cut funding to children's services.

(a) Further cuts in Pre-School Education funding at the Commonwealth level will make it increasingly difficult for kindergartens to continue providing preventative, developmental education support to young children and their parents.
(b) Cuts to Fee Relief and services in the Child Care system are going to impose hardship on the middle and lower income earners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider these cuts.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective world peace initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being, maximum employment, utilising natural resources for peaceful purposes, developing healthy soils and growing a plentiful food supply and tree cover. By so doing, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops;
6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted sewage-sludge and organic garbage into hygienic humus for use in rehabilitating impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to irrigation systems and the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

that the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Preschools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test; That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas; That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian; That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) the Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue backgroung signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned ex-service persons in the electorate of Bass in Tasmania respectfully showeth that:
(i) The welfare of Australian veterans and their dependants should be kept out of bureaucratic costing exercises.

(ii) The Veterans' Entitlement Bill 1985 does not represent the actual needs of ex-service persons, especially the abolition of dependants' pensions, the alteration to the assessment of rates of disability pensions and the alteration to Section 47-the onus of proof.

(iii) As ex-service persons who served their country in time of need, and now apparently forgotten by governments, we are deeply concerned that our organisations were not consulted before the amendments were made.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) The controversial parts of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 be repealed.
(2) That ex-service organisations be given the chance of a ``Summit'' type meeting, as accorded management and trade unions, at which to express their opinions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Living Music Radio
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain Wollongong (electors of the Division of Cunningham) shows-Living Music Radio (here circumstances of case stated) has been allocated 104.5 Mhz on FM radio band and has blocked out all Sydney FM radio reception. Those stations affected 2 triple M and 2 day FM.
Your petitioners therefore pray that (1) They allocate to another frequency (here terms of action petitioned stated) (2) Reduce power output transmission.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to ensure that the public receives a reliable, cheap and efficient postal service.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a time for action and not for words by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). This morning when people in Canberra tried to post their letters they found on every letter-box in Canberra the following notice:

SPEECH.PARA: Please Note
We regret that due to an industrial dispute in the New South Wales mail network postal services will be disrupted until further notice.
Consequently customers should lodge all mail in a post office box or over the counter at their nearest post office.
This posting box will be out of service for the duration of the dispute.

A concerned citizen brought that notice to me this morning at Parliament House. A short while ago the notice was back on the same letter-box. The Minister has a lot to explain to the Australian public about this matter. Post offices have been closed today in Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, Canberra and New South Wales as a result of the strike in Sydney. We have had the nailing up of mail-boxes in New South Wales and the taping up of boxes elsewhere. Who has taped over them? Has it been postal workers? If so, by what authority? Are they committing a Federal offence? I ask the Minister to answer these questions. Did the management of Australia Post authorise it? If so, why in Canberra? For example, why is mailing letters in Canberra to someone else in Canberra now affected because of a strike in Sydney? Are Canberra's mail drivers out on strike as well? Are they on strike in sympathy with the mail sorters? Why is mail not being collected from mail-boxes and why are Canberra residents being prevented from posting their letters? The same questions may be asked about Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia where we are informed, at least, that a similar situation prevails.

What about Christmas mail? This is the time of year when everyone sends mail overseas. Is Australia Post to guarantee that mail which now cannot be distributed and will not be able to go by sea will be posted by air at no greater cost to the customer? I ask the Minister to answer these questions. I also ask him-it is a shame that he has left the chamber, but I hope that he will understand the importance of this point-

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Minister?

—Where is the Minister? I ask the Minister to explain why, when this situation has reached the sad stage it has, he has not used his powers under section 8(1) of the Postal Services Act 1975. That section states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, after consultation with the Commission-
that is, Australia Post-
give to the Commission, in writing, such directions, with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest.

Consultation may be begun by telephone this afternoon. The direction in writing obviously will not be posted. One could not even post it in Canberra's post boxes. However, the direction may be given by telex. Section 8(1) obliges the Minister to act in the public interest. For months the Minister has been telling Australia Post what he expects of it. Australia Post management has responded positively, but some of its employees, particularly in Sydney, have been anxious to defy the Minister and, therefore, the Government, the management of Australia Post, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and even the Federal Executive of its own union, the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union.
In March this year the Minister opened a new post office in Wodonga. In his speech he made the following observations:

I am glad to see that Post is trying hard to rectify the situation in New South Wales. It is consulting regularly with union representatives and its own employees and has instituted training programs to improve industrial relations and management skills among its supervisors and managers. It is implementing measures to tell the public quickly of delays in the mails and the reasons for them.

Several problem areas which have contributed to poor performance in mail processing have been identified and I am told Post is consulting with staff over rectifying these. But the plain fact is that these diverse issues-human relations, industrial relations, the authority of management and organisational arrangements-must be resolved if Post is to lift its performance standard in New South Wales.

If service quality in New South Wales continues to fail then growth in demand for Post services will decline as dissatisfied customers go elsewhere. The consequences of such a decline could well be catastrophic for the whole organisation.
I am encouraged by the fact that the senior managers of Post are confident that service can be improved, and know that this must occur before the end of 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Minister said that. We are very nearly at the end of 1985. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, the public cannot be expected to endure the poor level of service that prevailed last Christmas. It is, of course, essential that staff at all levels accept the need for changes that will improve performance and in turn ensure the continued viability of the enterprise.

The Opposition totally endorses the views expressed then by the Minister. So did the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Commission has endorsed the management practices of Australia Post and the changes it needed to make in order to make the New South Wales mail distribution system efficient. We know the problems of social engineering that occurred many years ago with the Redfern Mail Exchange. We know that Australia Post made a very conscious decision to create decentralised distribution centres. But sadly, in doing the right thing by its employees, it distributed the agitators. We now have these agitators who were on nothing short of a rort, a rort exposed by Australia Post management to the Arbitration Commission and totally condemned by the commissioner concerned, who was a former Transport Workers Union official.

It was totally condemned as a rort, which no other employee in a Commonwealth establishment anywhere else could expect to get and no other workers for Australia Post anywhere else in the country could have got. They were able to greatly increase their income by delaying mail processing during the week, and then insisting that everybody on a shift be rostered on at the weekend to get massive amounts of overtime-at great cost to the public and in contravention of the clear direction by the Minister to Australia Post to produce an efficient and low cost mail distribution service.

The importance of this today is that over 40 per cent of all Australian mail is processed in New South Wales. In Sydney only 60 per cent of the mail is distributed at the advertised time. Elsewhere in Australia 90 per cent of mail is now being distributed at that time. People are still putting mail in boxes, as they are entitled to do, especially with the Christmas period arriving and cheques to be paid and so forth. Over seven million articles are now banked up. This small section was described by the Managing Director of Australia Post, Mr Eltringham, on 21 June in the following terms:
It's the hard-heads, about 5 per cent of the work force, who make it hard for all concerned.

That is putting it mildly. It is they who are frustrating government policy and not only jeopardising a service to the public but in fact bringing it to a halt. They are denying their own Federal Executive and everybody else. I put it to the Minister that he has an obligation to read very carefully all that Commissioner Grimshaw of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has said and all that the people who use the mail services, all who are organised enough to band together and express opinions, have said must be done. For example, the Chairman of Major Mail Users of Australia, Mr Malcolm Overland, has been seeking to see the Minister, and on his last inquiry through his office was told in no uncertain terms that the Minister would see him when he was good and ready. That is not good enough. In a Press release on 14 October, two days ago, Mr Overland said:
After many years, during which unsound work practices were allowed to develop, the management of Australia Post is to be commended for trying to remove inefficiencies from the system.

It is to be regretted that management is being frustrated in its attempts by mail sorters, who are ripping the system off by their refusal to allow management flexibility in scheduling work rosters to meet the demands of a continuous work load.

As a result of excessive overtime, some staff are regularly doubling their wages. This prevents Australia Post employing up to 300 additional permanent staff needed to operate the system in New South Wales efficiently.
Business users of Australia Post's services have had enough. If the mail sorters refuse to handle the mail, they should be replaced by those who will get the mails moving again.

Since it is Government policy to retain Australia Post as a government monopoly, the Minister for Communications must accept full responsibility for the current intolerable lack of service to the community.
The Major Mail Users of Australia, representing more than 20 per cent (in excess of $200m) of Australia Post's revenue, is determined that the Minister face up to these responsibilities.
An urgent appointment is being sought with the Minister to reinforce this view.

A similar telegram was sent to the Minister by the Australian Direct Marketing Association. Again, it is worth putting on record what the degree of concern is amongst Australian commercial organisations using Australia Post and obliged under the Act to use Australia Post. The Association says to the Minister:
This Association is deeply disturbed by repeated disruptions to the mail network in New South Wales.

We fully support all the initiatives being attempted to be implemented by Australia Post management and urge that all measures necessary be taken to force the union responsible for these dislocations to resume work on the same basis as their counterparts in every other State.

This Association has been co-operating with Australia Post management over many years in an attempt to resolve the problems associated with the New South Wales network, but these senseless continual strikes by the union who have no regard for business and the community generally are forcing our members to take alternative steps.

If a reliable service cannot be restored a large volume of work currently enjoyed by Australia Post will be diverted causing significant job loss which may never be recovered. Our members are being forced to use other means to convey advertising mail and distribution of product.
This disruption is occurring when our members' mail is at its peak and loss of revenue will cause hardship if this situation brought about by the union is allowed to continue.

Members are currently considering withholding payments of moneys where delivery performance is not met. Provision should be made during protracted delays for non-payment of moneys owed due to non-performance. Further we request a relaxation of statutory requirements covering private delivery contracts when disruptions of this nature take place.

What people are doing is this: Many commercial organisations communicating with me and other people in Canberra are now buying heavy duty envelopes weighing more than 500 grams to post a simple letter because the Postal Services Act obliges everyone to post through Australia Post if the letter is less than 500 grams in weight. People are prepared to pay the extra cost to engage a private courier service to get the mails through. One of the essential things in any community is that the mails must get through. Here there is a total stalemate where everyone is in agreement about what has to be done. In those circumstances the Minister has no alternative but to act. Australia Post is on record as begging this Government, privately and publicly, not to do away with the no work as directed no pay provisions. It is on record as condemning the removal of other legislation such as the famous Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act-the CE(EP) Act-because it believes that the escalation and disruption is due to that. Mr McQuitty, then Managing Director of Australia Post, was quoted last year as saying:
In New South Wales, absenteeism, external disruptions, internal disputes and other problems have rendered service performance unsatisfactory for many years.
Decentralisation from the Redfern Mail Centre had improved efficiency from 79.5 per cent to 90.8 per cent in 1982-83.

Unfortunately it has not been practicable to maintain that improvement-due primarily to the effects of the repeal of the no work-no pay legislation which had prompted negotiation rather than immediate resort to industrial action.
As I recall, on only six occasions was this kind of legislation actually employed. The threat of it brought about a situation where people could actually start talking to each other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member knows what the situation is. A small group of people, in their own greed, are denying 300 other people the opportunity for jobs and are seeking to gain money they are not entitled to at the expense of the public. We believe that those people should be told: `Get back to work or lose your job'. The Government should be supporting Australia Post in that, and those in Sydney who want a job can replace them and, through the Government's training programs, can soon be given the opportunity to get the mails moving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been accepted by the Opposition spokesman and has not been denied at any stage by me that we have a real problem in relation to the mail service in New South Wales. One point I want to make right from the start relates to a quotation by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) of somebody saying that this problem had existed for many years. This is the first time in the history of this dispute within Australia Post in Sydney that Australia Post management has been in a position, as a result of the hearings before Commissioner Grimshaw, to take a stand on the issue. I want to go to the issue in more detail than the previous speaker did. The issue is, of course, the ridiculous overtime provisions which operated in Australia Post in New South Wales. I indicated in this place yesterday and confirm again today total support for Australia Post management in what it is endeavouring to do to bring about a situation whereby the union will have to understand that there is no way-I reiterate this because it is the advice of Australia Post management-that Australia Post management is going to allow what was known as the one on, all on provisions of overtime and the ridiculous situation that went on for so long in Australia Post in New South Wales ever to come back again. That is the core of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to say one other thing in relation to the work force of Australia Post. Unfortunately, as has been indicated, there is a small group of people who have brought about the situation in New South Wales. The vast majority of Australia Post workers, not only in other parts of Australia but also in New South Wales, are attempting to get on with the job and are making their best efforts in the interests of Australia Post and the community. However, the motion is interesting. It specifically refers to the Government's failure to provide `a reliable, cheap and efficient postal service'. The fact is that at the moment we have what can be described only as a tragic situation in postal services in New South Wales. However, it should be said that the mail performance nationally by Australia Post is excellent. In 1984-85 the national proportion of postmarked standard articles delivered which met delivery standards was 88 per cent. That is an overall national figure and it is based on world performance standards, not something invented by Australia Post, this Government, the previous Government or anyone else. When one breaks down that national figure one finds the following State results: Victoria, 94 per cent; Queensland, 93 per cent; Western Australia, 95 per cent; South Australia, 96 per cent; and Tasmania, 90 per cent. However, the figure for New South Wales was only 76 per cent-not 60 per cent, as was indicated earlier-and that is why the national standard comes down to 88 per cent. It has been dragged down by the performance in New South Wales.

Honourable members talk about cheap services. Let us have a look at that issue. The fact is that, subject to the problems we are facing at the moment and let us not entirely ignore the performance of Australia Post over a longer period, mail service performances in relation to delivery within advertised time targets are considerably better than those in most parts of the world. They are certainly better than comparable countries such as Canada, the United States and the United Kingdom. Let us compare our 33c charge for standard letters with charges of other countries. The figures I am about to quote are all calculated in Australian currency. The charge in the United States is 34.3c; in Canada 37.1c; in Japan 37.9c; in Sweden 35.6c; in West Germany 42.1c; in the United Kingdom 34.5c; and in France 36.3c. Those charges are for comparable mail articles. Australia Post is one of the only two postal organisations in the world which operates at a profit and receives no subsidy. In fact, it may now be the only one because of what is happening in the United Kingdom. The updated figures from that country may have changed the position. It is very easy for honourable members to come in here today and berate the performance of Australia Post overall. That is totally unfair.
