Let us look at the sort of advice that we are getting from the Opposition about the handling of this matter. We have had the Opposition spokesman on communications, the honourable member for Goldstein, talking about `no work as directed, no pay'. He then moved on to the infamous Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act. I will deal with that in a bit more detail, because it is no solution to the matter at all. It is well known to the shadow Minister that Australia Post, through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the hearings before Commissioner Grimshaw, has stand-down provisions for a period of six months. It is using those stand-down provisions and if people are not prepared to carry out directions and work as directed those provisions have been and will continue to be used. Let us have a look at the suggestion that Mr McQuitty is quoted as having made. He said that the repeal of the no work as directed, no pay and the CE(EP) provisions or a combination of both, was at the core of the problem. With the greatest of respect to Mr McQuitty, that is nonsense. The CE(EP) legislation, that great piece of industrial democracy, was introduced in 1977 and it came into operation in 1979. Let us now discuss what happened in relation to that legislation while the Opposition was in office. In December 1981 there were headlines like these in the Sydney Morning Herald: `Communications chaos'; the next day `Mail walkouts block pensions'; and then the next day `A million mail items pile up'. Those were the sorts of headlines we had in December 1981. Did the Opposition, then in government, use the provisions of the CE(EP) legislation? I am not suggesting for one minute that it should have used them because they do not do anything for the problem. Did the Opposition use them? No, it did not. I will turn in a moment to the occasions on which such provisions were used. The shadow Minister has been calling for dismissals of people. That is what he wants; he has a penchant for dismissals. A fortnight ago it was the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board; now it is Australia Post employees.

Let us look at the position in 1981. There were 28 million postal articles held up in that dispute; 15 million in New South Wales and 13 million in Victoria. What did the Government do about it? It did nothing. It could have acted then, it could have given the directions that the shadow Minister is talking about now, it could have used the CE(EP) Act, it could have done all sorts of things. In fact, the CE(EP) Act was used nine times between 1977 and 1983, but not once was it used for dismissals. The Opposition knows that as well as I do. Opposition members come in here and display absolute hypocrisy about the way in which we should proceed. They quote people as saying that the CE(EP) legislation would solve this sort of problem. That is nonsense. Honourable members know it is nonsense because they did not go down that track themselves. All they did was grandstand on those issues and do nothing about them.

Then we had the argument put by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that perhaps the answer to all this is some sort of privatisation. The way in which he put the argument was a bit hazy. He tends to be a bit hazy on detail. Nevertheless he indicated that that was the way in which we should proceed. Why that should be the way to go I have no idea, but the Leader of the Opposition seemed to see some value in it on 14 October when he was interviewed on the Channel 10 evening news bulletin. He said:

If a public monopoly held by Australia Post were not so tight, the consequences of this kind of strike would not be so great and it certainly is an argument in favour of greater privatisation and greater flexibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member says `Hear, hear'. What does `greater privatisation and greater flexibility' mean? When will we be told what the Opposition's policy actually is? The Opposition talks about greater privatisation; does it intend to sell off bits of Australia Post, privatising some areas and not others? No one has any idea. Yet these are the people who are telling us how to run Australia Post. They move from the wets to the dries to the rain forests. On 15 October, the very next day, we had a statement from the shadow Minister for Communications, who said-and nobody disagreed with the first part of this-

SPEECH.PARA: They are jeopardising-
he is referring of course to the postal workers in Sydney, that small group who are causing this tremendous industrial trouble-
the entire future of Australia Post as a national mail network . . .

I can agree with him that far. The honourable member goes on to say-in a sense no one can disagree with the fact that there is a lot of truth in this aspect, because I have said it too-that unless some of these people wake up to themselves they will give ammunition to people who want to privatise.

The night before, the Leader of the Opposition suggested that that was an argument in favour of greater privatisation. But that statement has been broken down and we have no idea where the shadow Minister stands, because he spoke about giving ammunition to those who would like to see it broken up and sold to private enterprise. It would be interesting to know who the shadow Minister is talking about. Is he talking about giving ammuntion to his Leader? Does he support him on this issue? It is about time the shadow Minister responsible for all the statutory authorities in the Communications portfolio came here-not around the corridors and not in various other places-and told us and the rest of the people of Australia where he stands on the privatisation issue.

There have been many interjections from the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). It is interesting to look at where he stands on this issue. In February 1983 the honourable member for Menzies said-

TALK.START.PARA: —Ancient history again.

—It may be ancient history to the honourable member but it is very worrying when we have a situation in which we have the Leader of the Opposition saying one thing and we have no idea of what the shadow Minister is saying on this issue, and yet they are posing as members of an alternative government. Let us go back and look at what the honourable member for Menzies said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a matter of principle, the exclusive power of the Australian Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be continued.

It is humbug for the honourable member for Menzies to come in here and carry on like this. For the benefit of the Leader of the Opposition, I ask: Why did the honourable member for Menzies believe that Australia Post should continue to keep its exclusive power? For the benefit of the National Party of Australia, I shall quote again the honourable member for Menzies, who said:
It is vital that the postal service should be able to keep down the costs of country and remote mail services which it would be able to do as a result of this decision.

Nothing put forward here today has been of any assistance in any way to any honourable members on this side of the House in the resolution of this dispute. We heard again all the confused talk about privatisation. We heard about no work as directed, no pay. Stand-down provisions are in fact already inserted in the award in relation to Australia Post and are being used by the Australia Post management. We were taken back to that nonsense about the CE(EP) Act, which was never anything more than a recipe for industrial anarchy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to the discussion on the matter of public importance highlighted the seriousness of the issue before the House this afternoon. From listening to the Minister, one could not help noticing that he does not have his heart on this issue. That he has avoided entirely the issue before the House is quite pertinent. He gave us a rundown on the effectiveness or efficiency of other countries' performances in delivering mail. He gave us a rundown on other countries' mail charges. He also asked what we did about Australia Post in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: These issues are not pertinent to the issue which is before us today. The issue we are discussing is a mail strike which is taking place today and which is causing disruption and chaos today. It is causing the loss of millions of dollars and is putting at risk hundreds if not thousands of jobs of people right throughout Australia. That is the issue before the House-not the cost of mail in some other country and not how quickly some other country can get its mail delivered. Those are not the issues. It just highlights the fact that this Minister is not prepared to defend the Government on this matter in his usual effective way. I truly believe that he does not believe that the Government and, indeed, the union involved in this matter are right.

One of the problems of having a Labor government is that it is too closely associated with the union movement in this country. The result is that whenever we have an industrial dispute that brings unions into conflict with the Government, the Government is long on rhetoric but short on action. We saw this take place only recently with regard to the Mudginberri dispute, which has gone on for months and months. That was a situation where unions-in this case the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union-were brought against the Government. What happened? Workers made mutually agreeable contracts with their employers, the employer got a new market and Australia got new export income. Yet what happened? The union movement tried to stop it. What did this Government do? It did nothing but give us words; it took no action. As a consequence, the viability of the abattoir at Mudginberri was put at risk, the jobs of those people who worked at Mudginberri were put at risk and the income that all Australians so desperately need in order to keep this country running was very nearly lost to us. We did get action. We got action from the National Farmers Federation and from Opposition members of this Parliament.

The issue that we are discussing today is a mail dispute over a new roster system. It has been pointed out to me that really the nub of the problem is that the mail sorters in metropolitan areas will lose part of their excessive and, in some cases, unearned overtime payments. It was also pointed out to me earlier today that, given the situation that has been operating in some of those mail sorting centres, perhaps Ned Kelly would be happy to work there, and he would be able to work there without his helmet on, too.

This strike is causing disruption and chaos, as I mentioned earlier. Some millions of postal articles are being held up, companies are losing money and Australians are losing their jobs or their job certainty. Indeed, 300 unemployed Australians will lose the opportunity of having a job if the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union gets its way in this matter. Why is this situation so serious? It is so serious because we have a government which is not prepared to stand up and be counted. We do not have a government which is prepared to enforce the sort of rhetoric that it espouses here in the House.

The APTU, which is the relevant union in this matter, is clearly wrong. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission does not agree with the APTU. The Australia Post management does not agree with it. The Major Mail Users of Australia does not agree with the APTU. The customers of Australia Post do not agree. Even the more responsible and, I dare say, majority of Australia Post employees do not agree. When I speak of Australia Post employees, I say that the majority are responsible, good citizens of this nation.

In Goulburn, in the centre of my electorate, the mail centre is still sorting mail. It is doing so because the sorters do not agree with the sorts of tactics that the people in the metropolitan areas who listen to the APTU espouse. They are working overtime in Goulburn in order to provide a service that Australia Post has been able to provide in the past with a degree of pride and, indeed, it has provided satisfaction to those people who work for it. I am told that the workers in Goulburn are handling in excess of an extra 1,500 bags of mail per day in order to try to make up for the lack of activity of their counterparts in the metropolitan areas. As a result, they are working up to an extra four hours overtime per day. They are doing this because they are responsible members of the Australian community. They have more interface, if I may use that word, with the community. They go home, to the pub, to the club or wherever it may happen to be at the end of work each day and they hear the complaints of the people who use Australia Post regularly. If Australia Post is on strike, the people who work at the Goulburn mail centre get to be told all about it and they understand the chaos that it causes. This does not take place in a metropolitan region. I guess the fact that the Goulburn mail centre is still operating means that it is worthy of congratulations and also is indicative of the better style of person that one tends to find in country areas.

Why do all of those groups that I mentioned earlier agree on what needs to be done? They agree because they subscribe to good old common sense, just as the workers and management at Mudginberri subscribe to it. These people know what needs to be done; in fact, even the Minister knows what needs to be done. On 30 April, in a speech to the National Press Club, he said:
And if, in fact, Australia Post is to survive, its performance has to be lifted.
We all agree with that; obviously the Minister does. He also went on to say in that speech:

. . . what the unions have to understand and what post management has to understand-and I think they both are starting to understand it-is that you cannot protect the monopoly position of Australia Post because it's being bypassed.
Those very words highlight the seriousness of the situation facing Australia today. He also said:

All I'm saying to you is that in my view Australia Post have got about this year to get their house in order or they won't have much of a house to get in order because of the fact, as I say, that people are now bypassing the system.

People are bypassing the system. That is why today the people at Goulburn mail centre are prepared to work against what their mates in Sydney are doing. They understand, as does the Minister, that if Australia Post does not perform satisfactorily it will not remain a viable operation and the jobs of the people who work within it will be put at risk. It is those very jobs that we on the Opposition benches are trying to protect, to ensure that Australia Post is viable and that those jobs remain viable. I will quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 October which reports what was said by a chap from the Major Mail Users of Australia. The article states:
Mr Overland said the problem in this instance was not with Australia Post, but with an unresponsive Government.
Since it is Government policy to retain Australia Post . . .
It further states:
. . . Mr Overland's comments come at a time when many principal users are moving away from Australia Post to private enterprise in an attempt to get their mail delivered on time.

The National Roads and Motorists Association is a clear example of what is happening. Eighty-five per cent of deliveries of its magazine Open Road are now delivered by private contractor-at a saving to the NRMA, I point out, of about $1m.

I also take the opportunity to point out that this Government has a major responsibility for this matter because it did away with the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act. That provided for the no work as directed, no pay principle. But this Labor Government got rid of that Act. The previous Liberal-National Government introduced it. That sort of legislation would give this Minister the opportunity to do what he knows is right and what we on the Opposition benches know is right to protect the viability of Australia Post and to give those 300 unemployed people an opportunity to work. If this Minister and this Government are not strong enough to act in a proper fashion, let them get out of the way and let someone who has the ability get on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this matter of public importance. When we listen to Opposition members, we hear the same old tired reaction. When they hear about industrial disputes, it is like waving a red flag to a bull. All they want is blood. They want to kick heads; that is their solution. Their solution is to go out and kick a few heads and not worry whether that resolves the dispute. Everybody recognises that there is a very serious problem that has existed in New South Wales for quite some time. We should perhaps look at what caused that problem. The problem resulted from the creation of the Redfern mail exchange, which occurred under the previous Menzies Liberal Government. It allowed what was obviously a very poor decision to take place. Millions of dollars were spent in establishing a centralised organisation, which created an imbalance in the power in the mail area. The creation by the Whitlam Labor Government of Australia Post and Telecom Australia created an opportunity for a re-organisation to take place in New South Wales. That has been going on for the past 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: During the period of the last Liberal conservative Government under Malcolm Fraser there were periods of intense industrial disputation in Australia Post. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), said that one of the problems of the relationship between a Labor government and the trade union movement is that we do not know how to handle industrial disputes. For the benefit of the previous speaker, let us see how the previous Government handled them. During the vintage years of the previous Government 323,000 work hours were lost in Australia Post through industrial disputation. During the year 1981-82, what was that Government's solution? Did it implement the CE(EP) legislation, which it had as a powerful weapon, when so many thousands of hours were lost through industrial disputation? No. What has been our record? Our record has been an average of 17,000 hours lost in Australia Post-20 times less than was achieved by the previous Government during its vintage years.

A delicate industrial dispute cannot be resolved by simply going out and kicking heads. We have heard the call of Opposition members saying that we should implement the CE(EP) legislation. Interestingly enough, last Thursday when we were debating the private member's Bill put forward by the previous Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, the present Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), did not even bother to come in and support it. That is probably because he does not know what sort of industrial relations policy he is supposed to implement. He talks to some of his colleagues in the passageway one day and comes up with a Press release of what the new industrial relations policy is to be. He then walks around the corner and bumps into good old Honest John who gives him a lecture on how he has made a mistake. So he changes his mind again and comes out with another Press release the next day. It is no wonder that he is confused. He cannot speak on any of these disputes because he does not know what Opposition policy is.

Interestingly enough the shadow spokesman for communications, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), started off yesterday with a question and talked in the House about sack, sack, sack. That is a change from his industrial relations policy when he was shadow spokesperson. But still I suppose it is understandable, given the absolutely abysmal performance of Honest John as Leader of the Opposition. The shadow spokesperson for communications is obviously making his move for the next challenge, which is inevitable at this stage.

The matter of public importance refers to a reliable, cheap and efficient postal service. The reality is that in performance Australia Post measures up very well against any yardstick that can be used in any other postal service around the world. It has a performance which sees about 88 per cent of its standard articles delivered on target. That figure is comparable with those anywhere in the world. But, yes, there is a problem in New South Wales; yes, the management recognises it and, yes, it is a serious problem.

There is a dispute of which we are all aware. But we on this side of the House know that one way to overcome that dispute is by proper management and proper discussion. The matter will be resolved in a way which will lead to industrial peace in New South Wales in the long term. One cannot resolve it simply by going in and using the solution of the Opposition, that is, by kicking a few heads or sacking a few people. Anybody who understands industrial relations knows that the reaction to that would be a widening of the dispute to cover not just the communications area. The fact that one would be reacting to a situation in which people are taking industrial action, and attacking their right to strike and take industrial action, would tend to bring in support, which at the moment does not exist, from other areas of the trade union movement. If one took that step and widened the dispute, one would almost inevitably lengthen the period of the dispute and complicate the resolution of it.

If Opposition members had ever bothered to study industrial relations, they would realise that that would be the inevitable result of the sorts of measures for which they are arguing. If they look at what happened when the CE(EP) legislation was implemented, they will find that that was the result of each of their actions. The previous Government stood down hundreds and in some cases thousands of people. But that did not resolve the dispute. The disputes dragged on and on. Then, as part of the resolution, people had to be reinstated with full rights and conditions. That was always agreed to by the previous Government. What resulted was a worse dispute than had been the case at the beginning.

Australia Post has been working very hard to overcome the problems of the centralised mailing system that was created in New South Wales. The reason performance is so high in other States is that this mistake was never repeated. Mail services in other States were decentralised which has resulted in very high performances-all of them in the region of 90 per cent and higher. Whilst Australia Post has been attempting to resolve this issue, it is not helped by people standing up in this chamber berating it and denigrating the performance that it has achieved. It has almost completed the decentralisation of the mail system in New South Wales. A small group of people who do not have the full support of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union, as a national organisation or even within their State, are embarking on industrial disputation. As I have said, those matters will be resolved before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and by negotiations between the union and the management of Australia Post. To try to resolve it by any heavy-handed method would simply worsen the dispute.

The clear evidence of industrial disputation is simply that it can be resolved ultimately by negotiation. No dispute has been resolved by legal manoeuvering or by tactics which are intended only to provoke the disputation. We have heard spokespeople in this House say that we should go in heavy-handed. I do not believe that they are saying that because they think it would resolve the dispute. They are hoping that the Government will overstep the mark and over-react to a matter which is being contained in several of the mail centres in Sydney central. Such action would spark a much bigger dispute and give them something with which to continue their attack on the trade union movement and the public enterprises that exists today.

As has been said, Australia Post is one of only two postal services in the world which operates without government subsidy and provides services which are cheaper than those available in any comparable country. Some of the figures mentioned by the honourable member for Gilmore indicate that we could give some of these services to private contractors who could perform them more cheaply. That is probably true. But the result for the supposed supporters of the National Party of Australia-the country people-would be that the cost of their services would rise astronomically. No private contractors would want to go into the middle of the bush and provide services at a cost of 33c a letter. In 1981-82, the previous Government's last full year in office, its record of management of Australia Post-it is a most damning record-indicates that 323,000 hours were lost through industrial disputation. Average man-hours lost in 1975-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments. Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routing administration. Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more noteworthy changes included in this Bill.
Amendments Incorporation Act 1905

Minor amendments to this Act allow the Government Printer to publish a reprinted Act containing all amendments up to a date specified in the reprint. This will avoid delays in reprinting Acts which at present are required to include amendments to the date of publication.
Bankruptcy Act 1966

The insertion of a new section 17AA will contribute to administrative efficiency by allowing a registrar or a deputy registrar of the Federal Court of Australia to exercise the powers and perform the functions of a registrar in bankruptcy. The new section could apply, for example, during the short term absence of the Registrar in Bankruptcy or where he may have to stand aside in matters that may involve a conflict of interests.

The amendment of section 41 removes an anomaly brought to light by the judgment in Re Ikin; Ex parte Ikin v. Lamborghini Tractors of Australia Pty Ltd-in the Federal Court of Australia before Pincus J., on 4 April 1985-where it was held that a valid bankruptcy notice could not be issued where the judgment debt was expressed in a foreign currency. The amendment enables a bankruptcy notice to require payment in a foreign currency or its equivalent in Australian dollars.
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918

The amendment provides for the continuation of a definition of `British subject' for the purpose of the franchise qualifications. This amendment is required because, when section 7 of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984 is proclaimed, it will repeal `British subject' status provisions in that legislation.
Crimes Act 1914

The amendments bring into immediate effect various provisions of the Crimes Act 1914 inserted by unproclaimed provisions of the Crimes Amendment Act 1982 and provide that other provisions are operative, except in relation to the Australian Capital Territory, only where an arrangment has been entered into with a participating State or Territory as defined. In the Australian Capital Territory these provisions will have full force and effect immediately.
Crimes Amendment Act 1982

The original amendments introduced in 1982 to enable Federal offenders to participate in non-custodial sentencing have not been proclaimed because agreement has not been able to be reached with all States and Territories in relation to their participation in the implementation and administration of non-custodial sentences. The proposed amendments will enable the original provisions to be brought into operation in a State or Territory jurisdiction with effect from that State or Territory entering into the necessary arrangement with the Commonwealth.
Crimes (Currency) Act 1981

The amendments are intended to exempt from criminal sanction under the Crimes (Currency) Act persons who are innocently holding counterfeit coins which, in the case of Australian coins, are of pre-decimal currency and, in the case of non-Australian coins, are no longer legal tender anywhere outside Australia. No mischief is involved in the holding of these counterfeit coins. Concerns that have been expressed about counterfeit items in collections being covered by the Act have delayed its coming into operation. The passage of these amendments will enable the Act to be brought into operation and, at the same time, give to persons innocently holding counterfeit coins within these categories exemption from criminal sanction and security of possession.
Defence Act 1903

Existing provisions enable a witness before a court or board of inquiry to be required to answer a question notwithstanding that the answer may tend to incriminate the witness, provided that such evidence is not admissible against the witness in civil, criminal or service tribunal proceedings except on a charge of giving false testimony before the court or board of inquiry. The amendments extend the application of the protective provisions to a witness who gives evidence voluntarily.
Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966

The amendments redefine a crime for which Australia can grant extradition, by providing that such crimes must not only carry a penalty of at least 12 months imprisonment in the country seeking extradition, as is presently provided, but also, had the offence been committed in Australia, a penalty of at least 12 months imprisonment. The amendments also enable postponement of surrender to allow outstanding Australian charges against the fugitive to be dealt with or any sentence of imprisonment to be served. Provision is made permitting the grant of bail where surrender is postponed due to outsanding Australian charges. As habeas corpus is an inappropriate remedy for a person not in custody, a statutory review replaces the existing habeas corpus procedure. In effect, a person serving a sentence of imprisonment in Australia could be surrendered immediately upon completion of that sentence. At present the extradition proceedings could only commence at that time resulting in a further period of incarceration pending hearing and determination of the application.
Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
The amendments to this Act are similar to those made in respect of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1968.
Family Law Act 1975

The amendments make it clear that Registrars and Deputy Registrars may exercise powers of the Family Court of Australia as delegates of the Court since the present section 37A may have been open to constitutional challenge on the grounds that it may vest powers of the Court in these officials. Moreover, the Bill validates the exercise of powers of the Family Court of Australia by Registrars since the commencement of section 37A on 2 January 1985 and declares the rights and liabilities of persons to be the same as if those rights and liabilities were attributable to an order of a judge of the Court.
Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

The amendment enables the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory to hear and determine any application in respect of a matter pending in the General Division of the Federal Courts of Australia that may be made to a judge of the Federal Court in chambers. The effect of the amendment will be to put the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory on a similar footing to State Supreme Courts. The amendment is necessary because there is no resident Federal Court judge in the Northern Territory and a Federal Court judge may not be available to hear urgent interlocutory matters.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975

Further to the amendments made in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985 this amendment increases the period of the operation of regulations relating to unzoned areas from three years to five years since the area became part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in August 1983. This will enable the Authority to grant permission for the operation of an activity in an unzoned area. At present any permission granted would expire in August 1986.
Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984

The amendments enable a member or a Territory senator to continue to employ staff under the provisions of the Act following the calling of a general election. The problem that arose in the case of the election of 1 December 1984 is remedied in relation to that election. In relation to future elections the amendments provide that members and senators shall not cease to hold office while continuing to be entitled to a parliamentary allowance.
Museum of Australia Act 1980

The amendments change the name of the Museum of Australia to the National Museum of Australia, conforming with the naming policy of other national cultural institutions such as the National Library of Australia, and will reduce confusion with the Australian Museum in New South Wales. Also, the amendments extend the application of the Act to include the continental shelf as well as present and former Australian external territories; provide a procedure for accession of material to form part of the national historical collection; and enable the Museum to stage travelling exhibitions, including materials from outside the national historical collection.
Patents Act 1952

The Patents Act is to be amended so that the declaration of certain matters relating to `Convention countries' is made by regulations rather than by proclamation. The change will allow consolidated lists of Convention countries to be more readily available to practitioners and the public. Further amendments relating to the requirements of patent applications for inventions involving micro-organisms, and to abstracts of patent specifications, will make administrative procedures more straightforward and will correct minor omissions.
Postal Services Act 1975

A number of amendments formalise the use by Australia Post of vending machines for the issue of postage stamps. The amendments also provide that where a criminal charge is amended, the suspension of the officer based on the original charge need not cease. They also protect the author of a report made in good faith on the work of an officer or employee of the Australian Postal Commission from legal action. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983. The amendments arise from the experience of the operation of the Act since it came into effect on 5 March 1984. The amendments clarify certain functions and powers of the Director as well as provide amendments to the existing Act where the existing provisions have required review since the Act came into effect.

Clause 3 of the Bill clarifies the circumstances in which the Director is authorised to present indictments in respect of offences not included in the committal order made by the magistrate. The amendments provide that, where a committal order is made in respect of one or more offences, the Director is authorised to present an indictment in respect of:
(a) any other offence for which a person was examined-that is, the subject of the committal proceedings-but not committed for trial; or
(b) any other offence founded on facts or evidence disclosed in the course of the committal proceedings.

In addition, the amendments provide that the Director is authorised to present an indictment where no committal order has been made provided the defendant consents. However, except in the circumstances described, the Director is not authorised to present an indictment where no committal order was made at all or for an offence not included in the committal order. Accordingly, the effect of these amendments is that the Attorney-General will decide whether an indictment should be presented where no committal proceedings have been conducted, except where the defendant consents to an indictment being presented in such circumstances, or no committal order made. Pursuant to this clause, sub-section 6(3) of the principal Act is also amended to make it clear that the operation of an instrument referred to in sub-section 6(3) does not depend upon publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The amendment will also permit the delaying of gazettal where public gazettal in relation to a particular prson may prejudice the investigation of that person.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends section 9 of the principal Act to provide that the Director may act as counsel or solicitor for an authority of the Commonwealth where that authority is a party to a proceeding in respect of a matter:
(a) that has arisen out of, or is connected with, the performance of any of the functions of the Director; or
(b) that may result in the performance by the Director of such a function.

This amendment will enable the Director to act on behalf of persons who may be the subject of civil proceedings in connection with matters in which the Director has advised or may advise. An example of such a situation is where the issue of a search warrant has been challenged.

Clause 5 of the Bill inserts a new section 15A to the principal Act to permit police prosecutors to represent the Director in remote localities in proceedings for summary conviction of a person or in connection with formal matters related to committal proceedings. The purpose of the amendment is to avoid the cost and expense of sending the Director's legal staff to remote localities for relatively minor hearings.

In relation to the amendment proposed in clause 6 of the Bill, provision was made in the civil remedies amendments to the Act, by virtue of the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Act 1985, for the prohibition of particular evidence or information in proceedings for civil remedies referred to in those amendments. The new sub-section 16A(1A) provides for a similar prohibition of publication of evidence or information in proceedings for the recovery of pecuniary penalties.

The purpose of the amendment referred to in clause 7 of the Bill is to enable the Director, with the approval of the Attorney-General or a person authorised in writing by the Attorney-General, to employ persons under term contracts. The terms and conditions of such persons are subject to the approval of the Public Service Board.

The amendment provided for in clause 8 removes certain controls from the Director's capacity to engage consultants and other contractors for services. On 2 July 1984 the Public Service Board notified all departments and authorities that they should make decisions to engage consultants and other contractors for services without reference to the Board within the financial limits set out in the Budget process for such expenditure. Since the date of the notification departmental secretaries have been responsible for the engagement of consultants and other contractors for services without reference to the Board. The purpose of the amendments provided in this clause is to give the Director the same capacity and freedom to engage consultants and other contractors for services as are possessed by a departmental secretary. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes two reforms to the Evidence Act 1905. The first relates to the obtaining of evidence abroad for use in criminal or civil proceedings in Australia under Commonwealth law; the second to the class of persons who are competent to give ancillary evidence to prove business records. Deficiencies in the law in these areas have been brought to attention by, in particular, the former Special Prosecutor, Mr R. F. Redlich, QC, and by the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, QC.
Obtaining Evidence Abroad

In relation to the first amendment, the Special Prosecutor drew attention to his 1982-83 and 1983-84 annual reports to the difficulty of obtaining evidence overseas for use in Commonwealth criminal proceedings. The problem was further highlighted in recent prosecutions in Western Australia for alleged breaches of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations. The Federal Court of Australia held that the relevant court, which was a magistrates court, had no power to issue letters of request to an overseas court to have certain evidence taken abroad. The Director of Public Prosecutions has recommended that action be taken to remedy the situation. He comments that most of the heavy work with which his office is concerned has overseas aspects. He gives as examples drug prosecutions and revenue and other fraud cases.

In most respects the law concerning evidence, practice and procedure in relation to Commonwealth civil and criminal proceedings is that applying in the State or Territory where the hearing is being conducted. The Evidence Act 1905 deals only with limited areas, and these do not include procedures for the taking of evidence overseas. The laws of evidence and procedure differ from State to State. The High Court of Australia, the Federal Court and Supreme Courts are able to order the obtaining of evidence overseas in civil matters before them. However, not all superior courts may order the taking of evidence in criminal matters. In no State or Territory does it seem possible for such evidence to be obtained in relation to criminal matters in inferior courts. The Bill will allow the obtaining of evidence overseas, both oral and documentary, for use in Federal and Territory courts or State courts exercising Federal jurisdiction in civil or criminal matters. This will fill gaps that exist in State laws.
The central features of the Bill are:

(i) In relation to proceedings before a superior court-the High Court, Federal Court, Family Court and State and Territory Supreme Courts-the legislation will empower the relevant court on the application of a party to the proceedings to issue letters of request to an overseas court, or to order the taking of evidence overseas by commission or by the appointment of an examiner.

(ii) In relation to proceedings before an inferior court, such as a district court or a magistrates' court, a party to the proceedings who wishes to have evidence obtained overseas for the purpose of those proceedings may apply to the appropriate superior court for an order for the taking of such evidence.

(iii) The use of evidence obtained overseas will be subject to the following safeguards, since it may not be obtained in the presence of the defendant, and in criminal jury trials will be obtained in the absence of the jury:
(a) The issuing of the order will be at the discretion of the superior court.

(b) The superior court may include special conditions or directions in the order; for example, that cross-examination of a witness be permitted as a special procedure where this would not otherwise take place.

(c) Only evidence which answers the tests of admissibility in Australia will be admissible in Australian proceedings. Where the evidence is obtained for use in an inferior court, that court will determine the question of admissibility in its proceedings, and this determination will be subject to normal appeal processes.

(d) The Australian court hearing the matter will have a discretion to exclude any of the material obtained overseas if it seems unfair to receive it, notwithstanding that the evidence satisfies Australian tests of admissibility.
Business Records

Turning now to business records, although the Evidence Act makes special provision for their admission into evidence in Federal and Australian Capital Territory courts, attention has been drawn to the difficulty in obtaining the admission into evidence of documents originating overseas where there is no witness in Australia, concerned with the making or keeping of the records, competent to give the necessary ancillary evidence to prove the documents. A provision has, therefore, been made in clause 3 to enable an `authorised person', including a person authorised by the Attorney-General or a member of the police force of or above the rank of sergeant, to give the necessary ancillary evidence on the basis of information and belief. This amendment is similar to provisions that have been introduced in New South Wales and Tasmania.
Financial and Regulatory Impact

The making of an order by a court of the taking of evidence overseas could result in increased costs for the parties since overseas representation at the examination could be necessary. In civil cases existing practice deals with this point. However, in criminal cases where the Commonwealth is the applicant for an order, it is reasonable for the Commonwealth to provide assistance to the defendant in cases of hardship, where in all the circumstances it is reasonable for such assistance to be granted. This will be done within the existing guidelines for financial assistance. The costs involved cannot be quantified but the occasions when such provision will be made are likely to be few. The Bill will have no regulatory impact. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill permits the waiving of crude oil excise liability where a State government introduces a resource rent royalty on petroleum developments within its jurisdiction, and where the State also enters into a revenue-sharing agreement with the Commonwealth. It should be read in conjunction with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which I will be introducing immediately after this Bill.

On 25 June 1985 the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Premier of Western Australia announced that the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments had agreed on the broad arrangements for the introduction of a resource rent royalty on income from petroleum production from Barrow Island. Barrow Island is an onshore development within the jurisdiction of Western Australia. The resource rent royalty-or RRR-is a State initiative, developed in consultation with the Commonwealth, to replace the existing State ad valorem royalty and the Commonwealth crude oil excise which currently apply to Barrow Island Petroleum Production. The RRR will be based on the Commonwealth's resource rent tax-or RRT-which was announced on 27 June 1984 to apply to offshore `greenfields' petroleum projects developed after 1 July 1984. The RRT has always been seen by the Commonwealth as a model for resource taxation generally, but will apply only in offshore areas, where Commonwealth jurisdiction applies.

The Western Australian Government has had the taxation regime on Barrow Island under review for some time. Among other concerns that the Government shared with the producers was the concern that future investment on Barrow Island could be rendered uneconomic under the present levy regime. The reason for this concern was quite straightforward, and provides a good example of the advantages of the rent tax concept. Being a mature oil field, further investment on Barrow Island cannot be expected to be as productive in terms of the amount of oil produced per dollar invested when compared with the results from earlier investments there.

Had the existing levy and royalty regime continued, economic production of oil could have been terminated prematurely, unless other complex concessions under the levy arrangements were devised. Under the RRR, the full value of the capital and operating costs can be written off in the year in which they are incurred. Major new investments are therefore encouraged and consequently this will assist in maintaining production which would otherwise decline. If, of course, the investments are sufficiently productive and profitable, the RRR takes a share for Government revenue. An example of the sort of major investment with marginal return that could occur on Barrow Island in the future could be the use of enhanced oil recovery techniques which could involve applying very recent and advanced technology.

For both constitutional and general policy reasons, the Petroleum Revenue Bill is not limited to Barrow Island. The Commonwealth-Western Australian announcement on RRR of 25 June, to which I referred earlier, concluded with a general invitation to all States to approach the Commonwealth with proposals to apply a RRR to projects in their jurisdiction. The Bill is designed to allow the Commonwealth to waive excise in any situation where a relevant RRR is introduced and a relevant revenue-sharing agreement has been concluded.

The first schedule to the Bill sets out in general terms a model agreement which a State would need to enter into with a producer to satisfy the Commonwealth that an acceptable rent royalty was being implemented. The main features of the first schedule-the model RRR agreement-are as follows:
It will replace the Commonwealth crude oil excise and the State ad valorem royalty.
The royalty rate will be 40 per cent.

The threshold rate of return which a project must achieve before the RRR applies will be, at a maximum, the rate applying to the offshore RRT; that is, the long term bond rate plus 15 percentage points.
The royalty will be payable on income from the recovery of all petroleum, including crude oil, condensate, liquefied petroleum gas, natural gas and ethane.

Current and capital expenditures will be written off as deductions for RRR purposes immediately in the year in which they are paid, with any excess of expenditures over receipts in a particular year being compounded forward at the threshold rate to the next year. Payments and receipts relating to the provision of debt and equity capital will not be allowable as deductions.

Each member of a joint venture will be assessed for royalty on the basis of its actual expenditure on, and revenue from, the project. This requirement will apply in the case of Barrow Island as Western Australian Petroleum, the operator, is a joint venture of Shell Development (Australia) Pty Ltd, California Cal-Asiatic Oil Co., Texaco Overseas Petroleum, and Ampol Exploration Ltd. Overall liability for royalty will not be influenced by changes in ownership or implementation of farm-in agreements. The RRR will be levied prior to company income tax and will be a deduction for company tax purposes.

The second schedule sets out a model revenue sharing agreement which any State introducing a RRR would need to conclude with the Commonwealth before the Commonwealth's crude oil excise was waived. This schedule of the Bill contains a formula to establish a revenue sharing ratio for any given project. The revenue share ratios have been based as far as possible on the concept of revenue neutrality, compared with the existing arrangements. Data relating to individual projects are considered to be commercial-in-confidence and therefore estimates of revenue under an RRR regime cannot be made public. As well, the schedule sets out certain auditing requirements which the Commonwealth required for accountability and to protect its share of the royalty revenue.

When the criteria contained in these two schedules are satisfied, the Commonwealth will waive its excise. I believe that revenues of State and Commonwealth governments are protected satisfactorily by these arrangements while producers face a far more flexible tax regime that reduces significantly the interference of the tax regime in their investment planning. In the case of the Barrow Island field, the Western Australian Government is currently negotiating a detailed agreement with the operator, West Australian Petroleum Ltd-known as WAPET-along the lines contained in the Bill.

The need for a revenue sharing agreement has also been foreshadowed, an agreement which, in accordance with the second schedule, will give 75 per cent of the revenue to the Commonwealth and 25 per cent to the State. If both the agreement with WAPET and the agreement with the Commonwealth satisfy the criteria contained in the two schedules, then the Commonwealth will proceed to waive its crude oil excise. Any overpayments of excise which could arise where the RRR applies retrospectively from the date of proclamation of the legislation to 1 July will be refunded.

The Bill represents a major step forward in reform of resources taxation in Australia. The resource rent tax concept is now firmly established in the petroleum sector both off-shore and on-shore. I am sure that other States and the Northern Territory will see the merits in the Commonwealth's policy on rent taxes and take advantage of this important legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921. The move from the ad valorem royalty and excise regime to a resource rent royalty will require some transitional measures to apply. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 meets the more important transitional arrangements. It is essentially a machinery Bill. It will enable the Commonwealth to determine appropriate levels of excise on the residual crude oil and naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas stocks held by producers at the date on which a resource rent royalty comes into effect. The measures provided for in the Bill will ensure that the Commonwealth's revenue raising position is protected. Data relating to individual projects are considered to be commercial-in-confidence and cannot be made public. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Government has been concerned for some time that Commonwealth programs can interact in a way that disadvantages the people they should help, by trapping them in poverty. It has been recognised that the most savage of these poverty traps occurs when tax and social security interact. An attack on poverty traps is an essential part of the Government's tax reform package. It was one of the nine principles in the Australian Labor Party's taxation policy in last year's election. It was also a commitment renewed as part of the renegotiated accord last month.

This Bill deals with the extremely high marginal tax rates faced by people receiving social security payments when they try to earn some extra income for themselves and their families. The effective marginal tax rates faced by such people can be higher than the total facing the highest income earners. This is plainly inequitable. It keeps people in poverty and it provides a disincentive to people to care for themselves through, for example, part time work. The attack on poverty traps embodied in this Bill will have three results. First, it will leave more money in the pockets of hundreds of thousands of people on social security with some private income. Secondly, it will ease the transition from welfare to work for people, such as supporting parents, who are temporarily out of the permanent paid work force. Thirdly, it will provide an incentive to all people on social security to provide for themselves, either through part time work or investments.

Poverty traps will be attacked on three fronts. First, the amount pensioners can earn privately before they are affected by the income test will be increased from $30 to $40 a week for single pensioners, and from $50 to $70 a week for couples. Secondly, the additional allowable income for pensioners with children will be doubled from $6 to $12 a week per child. Thirdly, the very strict separate income test for rent assistance will be abolished. Rent assistance will simply be added on to payments, and be subject to the normal income test. In particular, these reforms will concentrate on groups of special concern to the Government-the aged, children in poverty, particularly in sole parent families, and pensioners and the unemployed renting in the private market.
Pension `Income-Test Free' areas

From November 1986, the basic income test for pensions will be liberalised by an increase in the free areas from $30 a week to $40 a week for single pensioners and from $50 a week to $70 a week for a pensioner couple. This means that single pensioners with incomes above $40 a week will receive an increase in pension of $5 a week, and a pensioner couple with an income above $70 a week will receive an increase in pension of $10 a week-combined. Pensioners with incomes between the old and new free areas will receive slightly less. In addition, because the pension cut-out points will increase, some persons currently not entitled on income grounds will become entitled to part rate pensions. It should be noted that the free area increases apply only to pensioners. The benefit income test will not be affected by this Bill. However, as a result of changes in the 1985-86 Budget which are included in the Social Security and Repatriation (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1985, introduced into the Parliament on 9 October 1985, the benefit free area will be increased from $20 to $30 a week in May 1986. The assets test will be unaffected and will apply as it does now. The special income test applying to age pensioners 70 years of age and over will not be affected.
The `Income Disregard' for Children

From November 1986, the income disregard for children of pensioners will be increased from $6 a week to $12 a week per child. The income disregard for children is the reduction in the income of a pensioner for each child. This, plus the increase in the basic free areas, will mean that pensioners with children will have higher free areas than currently. For example, a sole parent pensioner with one child will be able to have a non-pension income of $52 a week and still receive a full pension. These amounts are to be increased by $12 a week for each additional child.

There is to be no change to the treatment of unemployment, sickness and special beneficiaries with children who will continue to have no income disregard. There will also be no change to the income disregard for children in the income test for concession cards and fringe benefits.
Rent Assistance

From November 1986, the separate income test for rent assistance will be abolished for both pensioners and beneficiaries. Currently, rent assistance is reduced by 50c for every dollar of non-pension or benefit income from the first dollar of private income. Private income will now be higher in the case of pensioners with children who currently benefit from the income disregard of $6 a week per child.

From November 1986, rent assistance will be income tested like other additional payments, such as additional pension or benefit for children and mother's-guardian's allowance. The effect will be that people now receiving a part rate of rent assistance because of their private income will become eligible for the maximum rate, and other pensioners and beneficiaries renting in the private market who satisfy the rent test will also become eligible for the full or a part rate of rent assistance. This will mean that people renting in the private market will receive an increase in payment of up to $15 a week for sickness beneficiaries and pensioners, plus the gains from other initiatives, and of up to $10 a week for unemployment and special beneficiaries. The later groups will become eligible for rent assistance of up to $10 a week from 1 May 1986 as a result of changes in the 1985-86 Budget, which are included in the Social Security and Repatriation (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1985.

There will be little change to other aspects of rent assistance. In particular, the rent test will remain as it is. Where a pensioner is being assessed under the assets test, the pensioner will now be eligible for rent assistance on the same basis as a pensioner assessed under the income test. Persons renting public housing will not be eligible for payments. However, the existing savings clause covering public housing tenants will remain. The categories of unemployment beneficiaries eligible for rent assistance from May 1986 will not alter.
Some examples of what the new measures will mean are as follows:

(a) A sole parent with one child and modest earnings of $80 a week will receive an increase in pension of $8 a week. If that sole parent pensioner is renting in the private market, his or her social security payment will be increased by $23 a week.
(b) An unemployment beneficiary renting in the private market and with modest income from part time earnings will become eligible for additional rent assistance of up to $10 a week.

(c) A single age or invalid pensioner with $100 a week in private income will receive an increase in pension of $5 a week. If the pensioner is renting in the private market, the increase in pension could be as much as $20 a week.

The explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill contains the text of the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) concerning these matters, together with details of the financial impact of the measures. These measures mark a significant development in assistance to those members of our community who are in greatest need and who want the opportunity to break free of the social security system and become self-supporting. The measures will encourage their efforts in a positive way, and the reduction of poverty traps will assist those pensioners and beneficiaries, their children and the wider community. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill is to consolidate, rationalise and simplify the entitlements available to members of the veteran community. It represents the most important and comprehensive overhaul of the repatriation system since its establishment over 60 years ago.

The need for an overhaul of repatriation legislation has been evident for decades. The Repatriation Act has been amended on 90 occasions since 1920. Supplementary legislation has been introduced to cover war-like conflicts in which Australia has been involved since World War II. This legislation, too, has been subject to considerable amendment. A a result of this legislative activity over the years, many difficulties have arisen. Outmoded and inconsistent language and concepts remain in the statutes; eligibility provisions vary between the wars and conflicts; entitlements for medical treatment and ancillary allowances and benefits are scattered haphazardly through the various repatriation Acts and associated regulations. As well, some well-established services have operated without a clear legislative basis. The Bill tackles these problems in a comprehensive and coherent way.
Background

Let me say at the outset that this Government fully acknowledges its continuing responsibility to the veteran community. The challenges of providing a continuing high standard of service to the veteran community throughout the remainder of the twentieth century and beyond are immense. While it is almost 40 years to the day since the end of the Second World War, there remain over 600,000 Australians actually or potentially entitled to repatriation benefits. As far as is known, we have two veterans of the Boer War, approximately 6,000 veterans of World War I, and about 480,000 veterans of World War II, together with survivors of later conflicts and members of the peacetime forces. Most veterans are now over the age of 65. On current projections, there will be more than 180,000 beneficiaries aged 75 years and over by the year 2000.

As the veteran community ages, so the Australian community's responsibilities grow. People in this older age group need more treatment and greater care. The demand for improved services will come on all fronts-for pensions, treatment, pharmaceuticals and, most importantly, in our hospitals and through home and extended care. The Government is meeting these challenges not just with words, but with action. Changes made to the repatriation determining system in January 1985 are now leading to reductions in the previously unacceptable times taken to process claims. Backlogs are reducing. Further improvement will occur.

In the past three years we have increassed spending on veterans' affairs by 40 per cent, or about 20 per cent in real terms. Substantial extra spending has been allocated to service pensions, as large numbers of veterans have reached retirement age, and to meet the increase in the numbers and success rate of claims for disability and war widows' pensions. There are also vital projects to update our hospitals by replacement of obsolete accommodation and equipment and to set up aged and extended care units. The Brand report on the Review of the Repatriation Hospital System has recommended further imporovements and these are now under consideration. There have also been increases in pensions and benefits, including significant non-indexation increases, and the introduction of computer technology to aid efficiency and improve service delivery.
The VEB Consultative Process

The introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in the Parliament marks the culminatin of one of the most extensive processes of consultation that this or any other government has ever undertaken. The Bill has been drafted around the recommendations made by the Advisory Committee on Repatriation Legislation Review which was constituted by representatives of the Returned Services League, Legacy, the War Widows' Guild and the Australian Veterans' and Defence Services Council. Ninety-five per cent of the Committee's 292 recommendations have been incorporated in the Bill. Since the Bill was tabled in the Parliament on 30 May 1985, material on the Bill has been circulated widely. Over 90 seminars have been held across the country. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has received submissions from many ex-service organisations and individual veterans.

The changes made by legislation which came into effect on 6 June 1985 and which are carried through in the VEB have received some adverse reaction. In particular, there has been criticism of the standard of proof amendment which, as honourable members will recall, was amended in the Parliament to make it subject to a six-month sunset clause expiring on 5 December 1985. It is intended that the VEB should include a new standard of proof provision, and this should be in place by 5 December 1985. Some have suggested, in the course of the recently completed consultation process, that particular entitlements under the VEB should be more generously framed. I remind honourable members that when Senator Messner, the predecessor of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, set up the Advisory Comittee on Repatriation Legislation Review, its terms of reference were drawn so as not to emcompass amendments normally taken into account in the annual budgetary context.

While some significant further concessions are to be made in the VEB, I make no secret of the fact that the Government has had to make some hard decisions about how generous particular entitlements available to veterans and their dependants should be, having regard to the expenditure implications. The Government must take into account not just the special interest of veterans but also the broader interest of the community in ensuring responsible economic management. Nevertheless, in the course of the VEB consultative process, the Government has endeavoured to accommodate the concerns expressed by the ex-service community. In particular, a new standard of proof provision which should have broad ex-service community support has been devised. The proposal to apply the less generous civil standard of proof in determining certain claims for war widow's pension when a husband died more than 40 years after service will not proceed.

Arising from the consultative process, the Government has also reviewed its decision to remove repatriation coverage for all future Defence Force enlistees. Future Defence Force enlistees will now be eligible for repatriation coverage in respect of hazardous service. Further changes are also proposed to treatment entitlements and to disability pension eligibility. I wish to pay tribute to the valuable assistance, during the consultative process, of former Judge Paul Toose, who reviewed the repatriation system in the early 1970s.

As a further indication of the Government's good faith in the consultative process, I am also pleased to announce that it has been decided to reverse decisions made by earlier governments so that repatriation coverage under the VEB is extended to some of the previously excluded groups of service personnel who served in the Vietnam war. This will be done by treating these personnel under the VEB as having been allotted for such service. This meets the long-standing concerns of some Defence Force personnel, such as those who made trips to Vietnam on HMAS Sydney, that they were being denied legitimate entitlements under the repatriation system.
The Veterans' Entitlements Bill

Before turning to the particular provisions of the VEB, there are two points I wish to make. The first is that the VEB and the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill contain a number of improvements on existing repatriation entitlements. They include provisions to enable war widow pensioners who remarried or remarry after 29 May 1985 to retain their war widow's pension and other entitlements. There is provision to extend the $12-a-week domestic allowance to include a child who is dependent on the veteran but is not a natural or adopted child. The VEB also standardises the liability provisions for payment of pension on the more generous criteria applicable to World War II veterans. It formalises an extension in the range of medical treatment available to veterans to encompass social and domestic assistance. There are also minor extensions made to service pension eligibility. The second point is that under the VEB no person will lose a pension or benefit he or she now has.
I shall now outline the main provisions made by the Bill.
Compensation Pensions

Part II of the VEB sets out the eligibility conditions for the grant of a disability to a veteran, a war widow's pension to the spouse of a veteran, and an orphan's pension to a dependent child. Eligibility will arise in respect of a veteran's incapacity from injury or disease, or his or her death, where that injury, disease or death is determined to be war-caused. In effect, the VEB maintains the eligiblity criteria applying under existing legislation. The automatic entitlement to a war widow's pension on the death of a totally and permanently incapacitated pensioner is continued by the VEB. Disability pensions are payable on three scales-the general rate, the intermediate rate and the special TPI rate. This pension structure is maintained by the VEB. The extent of incapacity and the rate of pension payable are to be determined in accordance with a `Guide to Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions'. The guide is to apply to assessment of rates of pension after 1 July 1986, although it may be applied administratively before that date. The guide will be tabled in the Parliament. A draft of the guide has been prepared by the Repatriation Commission and copies are available from the office of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to anyone interested.

Part II of the VEB will also continue the effect of the recent legislative amendments to clarify eligiblity for payment of pension at the intermediate or special-TPI-rate. The TPI rate pension was designed for severely disabled veterans of a relatively young age who could never go back to work and could never hope to support themselves or their families or put away money for their old age. It was never intended that the TPI rate would become payable to a veteran who, having enjoyed a full working life after war service, then retired from work, possibly with whatever superannuation and other retirement benefits are available to the Australian work force.

Under the TPI criteria in the VEB, a pension is not payable at that rate unless at the time of determination that veteran is receiving a 100 per cent general rate pension, is totally and permanently incapacitated, and would be continuing in remunerative work but for a war-caused disability and thereby suffers an economic loss. I would not expect many veterans over the normal retirement age to qualify for payment of pension at this rate as there would usually be reasons other than the effect of a war-caused incapacity which precluded continuing in employment. If a person has had the usual span of working life or has retired voluntarily or has left employment for reasons other than accepted disabilities, a TPI pension is not payable. Nonetheless, there is no strict age limit on entitlement to the special rate pension, although it must be clear that not many veterans over the age of 65 years will qualify. Special provision is made by the Bill to cover veterans who are under 65 years of age, are unemployed, and are genuinely seeking to engage in remunerative work.

The VEB will not reverse the Government's decision to abolish future grants of dependant's pension. Successive governments have refused to increase the small amount of this pension. There are greater priorities for expenditure in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio than on this anachronistic benefit. Provision for optional commutation of the existing dependant's pension is made in the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill a sum equivalent to three years pension will be payable if the dependant chooses this option.
Service Pension

Part III of the VEB makes provision for payment of service pension to eligible beneficiaries. Subject to the income and assets test, a veteran with qualifying war service would be eligible for payment of a service pension if permanently incapacitated for work, or at 55 years of age in the case of a female veteran or at 60 years of age in the case of a male veteran. Qualifying war service will involve service such as in a theatre of war. An extension of existing service pension eligibility is made by the VEB for those veterans involved in bomb or mine clearance work after World War II and for some veterans who served in Malaya after 1957. Part II also provides for the grant of rent assistance and remote area allowance to eligible beneficiaries.
Defence Force or Peacekeeping Forces

Part IV of the VEB continues repatriation coverage for existing members of the Defence Force and for members of peacekeeping forces. It had been the Government's intention that VEB coverage should not extend to future Defence Force enlistees. This would not have affected any other compensation entitlements that may be available such as under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government's Employees) Act. While it is considered that in general there is no basis for maintaining repatriation entitlements for peacetime service, the Government accepts that there is a case for continuing repatriation entitlements for new enlistees in respect of any hazardous defence service in which they have been engaged. The Government will also be considering further the development of a new Defence Force compensation package outside the repatriation system.
Treatment

Part V of the Bill enables the provision of medical and other treatment to entitled veterans and other beneficiaries. Part V in large part continues existing entitlements. However, one change that has been made is that all service pensioners with a 50 per cent disability pension-not just World War II veterans, as is the case under existing legislation-will now be entitled to full treatment. As I have already mentioned, the VEB will formalise the provision to eligible persons of social and domestic assistance in addition to medical treatment. Part V also provides for preparation by the Repatriation Commission of a guide to the provision of treatment and for it to be tabled in the Parliament.
VEB Allowances
Parts VI and VII of the VEB make provision in relation to allowances and other benefits and for a veterans' children's education scheme.
Standard of Proof

Part VIII of the VEB makes general provision for decision-making under repatriation legislation. As part of the consultative process of the VEB, the Government made a commitment to consult the veteran community on the future form the standard of proof should take after the expiration of the six-month sunset clause to which this aspect of the May 1985 amendments is subject. This has proved to be no easy task. Lengthy consultations have occurred on the standard of proof clause.

I stress that the Government remains firm in its intention to overrule the O'Brien decision. I refer honourable members in that regard to the detailed reasons given in the second reading speech on the May 1985 legislation. The Government does not accept that a pension should be payable where there is no evidence to suggest a war service relationship to the claimed disability or death. While the ex-service community generally accepts that the O'Brien decision went too far, its view is that a provision should be developed that overturns the O'Brien decision while maintaining the effect of the earlier High Court decision in the Law case.

It has been possible in preparing the revised draft of clause 119 of the VEB to reach a substantial measure of consensus.
