New sub-clause 119 (1) will now extend the generous criminal standard of proof to veterans in respect of any operational service they have had. This involves an extension on the June 1985 legislation as some veterans who served in the Northern Territory during World War II will now also receive the benefit of the criminal standard.

Sub-clause 119(1) will require a favourable determination to be made in relation to a pension claim unless the Repatriation Commission is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there is no sufficient ground for doing so. However, the Commission will be required to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt where, after consideration of the whole of the material relevant to a pension claim, there is no reasonable hypothesis raised and, if raised, there does not remain a reasonable hypothesis of a service connection to a veteran's death or incapacity. Similar provision is made in clause 119 in respect of hazardous service of regular Defence Force personnel or peacekeeping service by members of a peacekeeping force. Clause 119 provides that all other decisions made under repatriation legislation are to be made on the civil standard of proof. To accommodate ex-service community concerns, the new clause 119 makes clear that there is no onus of proof on any person in relation to a claim or application. The process of determining disability and war widows' pension claims is intended to be inquisitorial. Clause 119 also overcomes any suggestion that there is a presumption of entitlement to a pension or other benefit.

Having regard to the many strong representations about the alleged discrimination involved in maintaining a 40-year rule and applying the civil standard of proof to certain war widows' pension claims after that period, the Government has decided not to pursue this proposal. In the light of the flexible and responsible approach taken by the Government, I would expect there to be broad support in the ex-service community for clause 119. The intended effect of clause 119 is outlined in greater detail in the explanatory memorandum.
Other Provisions

Parts IX and X of the VEB relate to the administrative review machinery established by the Veterans' Review Board and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. No substantive change is made in these provisions. Part XI of the VEB continues the existence of the Repatriation Commission and sets out its membership, its powers and its functions. Part XII of the VEB makes provision for trusts, offences, overpayments, delegations and other machinery matters.
Financial Impact

The changes made by the Veterans' Entitlements Bill will cost $1.2m in 1985-86; $20.601m in 1986-87 and $4.389m in 1987-88. The increased cost in 1986-87 relates to the proposal for commutation of dependants' pensions which will provide for one-off lump sum payments from July 1986. These costs do not include those arising from the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1985.

The VEB is one aspect, though a critical aspect, of the Government's strategy to build a repatriation system that is geared to the challenge of providing optimum services to the veteran community as we approach the twenty-first century. Within the constraints in which any government must operate, I believe the VEB will make a substantial contribution to that task. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill sets out the transitional provisions consequent upon the repeal of existing repatriation legislation. It also deals with the consequential matters related to the enactment of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Separate legislative provision has been made for these transitional matters so that the Veterans' Entitlements Act will be more straightforward and readable in respect of its future operations.

The purpose of this Bill is to bring current repatriation administration and operations within VEB coverage. This includes pensions and other benefits in payment, claims not yet determined and other outstanding administrative action. The Bill will also bring all decision making in respect of repatriation entitlements immediately within the VEB. The only exception to this is the guide to assessment of rates of pension which is to apply from 1 July 1986, although it may be used administratively before that date. It is intended that under the transitional provisions there will be no loss or reduction in existing benefits except where there are changed circumstances or fraud. The Bill is also intended to ensure that no one is prejudiced because of procedural differences between the VEB and the repealed Act. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Defence, I wish to look at what is happening to the ANZUS Treaty with the United States of America and New Zealand under the Labor Administration in Australia. As the Committee knows, the ANZUS Treaty is the keystone of Australia's defence relationships. Australia is part of the Western alliance. By `Western alliance' I mean those countries that share the values of freedom, democracy, institutions such as parliaments, free elections and, in fact, liberty itself. We join other countries in the Western alliance, such as Britain, the Western European countries, our Pacific neighbours and others in Asia and South East Asia, in sharing those values.

SPEECH.PARA: As the keystone under the umbrella of the Western alliance we have the ANZUS Treaty and arrangements with the United States and New Zealand. There is the Treaty document itself, which is well known. Tied in with the ANZUS Treaty are a number of other agreements, understandings, interpretations and statements by Ministers and Secretaries of State on all sides that help understanding and extend the operation of the Treaty. Those arrangements, understandings and protocols, if you like, are also fundamental to an understanding and are part of the ANZUS alliance itself.

I wish to look at the Government's position under ANZUS. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has described ANZUS as inoperative. I believe that ANZUS is in a state of crisis and is in fact in a vacuum. The policy of the Government of New Zealand and its proposed legislation on banning United States ship visits are a sell-out by New Zealand of its old Anzac partner, Australia. At the end of the debate on these estimates I want a clear statement from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as to what exactly is the Government's position with regard to a review of the ANZUS Treaty. Why does this Government fail to tell the New Zealand Government where Australia stands and what is Australia's position? I believe that this Government has failed to grasp the fundamental issues and it needs to send a clear message and a clear signal to the New Zealand Government on what Australia believes and what it wants.

Why is this Government not trying to dissuade New Zealand from its current actions, actions that are not in the best interests of Australia nor, I believe, in the best interests of New Zealand but that is a matter for New Zealanders. This is a matter of fundamental importance. New Zealanders clearly need to know that the present New Zealand Government has put at risk not only just its whole defence relationship with Australia but its whole series of relationships with Australia. It needs to be made clear to the New Zealand Government that its ban on the United States naval ships is a sell-out of its old friend and ally, Australia, going back to the days at Gallipoli. It ought to be made clear to the New Zealand Government that if it continues with its current policy the defence relationships and understandings not only are at risk but also need to be totally re-examined and, if need be, abandoned.

The New Zealand Government's policy means that the traditional goodwill embodied in the history of co-operation-I have mentioned Gallipoli-in our defence relationships over a long time in two world wars and other wars since then is at risk. Either the New Zealand Government does not care about Australia or believes that in the long run the Australian Labor Party will adopt similar policies to those of New Zealand. All relationships with New Zealand need to be reviewed. One especially comes to mind. I refer to the $64m that is being paid by the Australian Government by way of unemployment benefits to some 11,000 jobless New Zealanders in Australia. Why should we in Australia have to bear that financial burden?

I come to the influence on the Australian Government of the Socialist Left and the Left in the Government's determination of foreign policy. The Committee might remember, Mr Deputy Chairman, that some 27 Federal ALP members sent a telegram to Mr Lange prior to this Government's backdown on the MX missile issue. You would also know, Mr Deputy Chairman, that the Australian Government will not participate in strategic defence initiative research. There will be no electronic rail gun research to help the United States in its development of the strategic defence initiative. This Government proposes to enter into a treaty for a nuclear-free Pacific. This is part of the totality of measures influenced by the Left and the Socialist Left. Only in the last two days we have had a backdown by this Government on support for United States action in apprehending the Achille Lauro hijackers. That is the scene and it shows the influence the Socialist Left and the Left have on ALP foreign policy.

There has been a new and, I think, more dangerous development in the Government's ranks. A new body has been formed with, I understand, some 41 members. So that is some considerable addition to those 27 members who sent the telegram to Mr Lange earlier this year. Some 41 parliamentarians, including four Federal Ministers of this Labor Government, are part of a group called Labor Parliamentarians for a Nuclear-Free Australia. This is an extension, creeping across factional lines, from the Socialist Left into the Left and maybe the Right.

Perhaps the Minister for Defence can tell us more about this group. I understand that a blue book published by that group is being circulated today to members of the Labor Party. I would very much like to see a copy of it. The formation of this group provides a new dimension to ALP politics. It is a very significant move. It closes the noose on the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister. The Minister for Defence is becoming more and more isolated. He has already had to admit, with his tongue in his cheek, that there would be fewer United States naval ship visits to his State. That is evidence of the influence that the Left has on him and his Party.

I believe that this Government will be forced to back away more and more from our traditional relations with the United States. Obviously, the points that I have just enunciated to the Committee on the power of the Left and the new and growing power of Labor Parliamentarians for a Nuclear-Free Australia are a clear reason for the lack of action by this Government in sending clear signals to New Zealand of the dangers to ANZUS and the foolishness of that country's actions.

The Hawke Government's actions in not pressing New Zealand and in allowing ANZUS to be inoperative can only encourage the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics into the region. Already, a fishing agreement has been reached with Kiribati in the aftermath of New Zealand's actions. A vacuum exists in relation not only to ANZUS but also the whole of the Oceania-Pacific area. Obviously, the Soviets are rubbing their hands together with glee. They want to see ANZUS abandoned. The New Zealand Government's actions and the failure of the Australian Government to send clear signals and messages to the New Zealand Government are undermining the stability of the whole Pacific region, and are weakening the ability of the United States to defend Australia and the region.

Regrettably but understandably, the United States has proposed a review of ANZUS. With regard to that review, I ask the United States to remember the position of Australia, its traditional friend and ally.

It is not in Australia's interests to have a new treaty negotiated. I believe that the new treaty, with the protocols, the understandings and the statements that are used in its interpretation, should be left intact as far as Australian-United States relations are concerned. In a review of the treaty before the United States Congress, Australia could lose the benefits of some of those broader understandings. I believe that the ANZUS Treaty, as interpreted with those agreements, arrangements, what I have called protocols and understandings, as operate between Australia and the United States, should be the arrangements that exist between Australia and the United States if New Zealand does not come to its senses, which regrettably it does not appear to be doing. We can hope only for the return ultimately of a sensible government in New Zealand so that ANZUS can again become the cornerstone of the defence relationships between the three countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Committee is considering the 1985-86 estimates for the Department of Defence, I wish to take the opportunity this afternoon to correct the misconception which the Opposition attempts to create in the minds of people that this Government does not take a serious and genuine interest in the needs of our armed services. In a variety of ways, Opposition spokesmen continually strive to create the impression that their parties have an exclusive interest in caring for the needs of those Australian people who are engaged in one of the three arms of our defence forces. The fact is that it is this Labor Government that has shown a genuine concern for the needs of our service personnel. That concern is in stark contrast with the record of the former Government parties during their most recent seven years in office. I have no reason to believe that their attitude during that period was any different from what it was during their earlier years in government. Their main aim in providing Budget funds for defence was always to direct spending towards those areas which were most obvious and visible to the general public, while consistently neglecting to provide in any real way for all of the needs of the defence forces in the very necessary but often unseen facilities at defence force establishments or the housing needs of defence personnel and their families either on defence establishments or in any of the numerous areas of private housing provided in the general communities adjacent to those defence establishments.

SPEECH.PARA: My impressions as a member of the Joint Committee on Public Works since the Hawke Government was elected in March 1983 are that the history of the former Government in the provision of facilities for serving personnel in the categories I have mentioned has been absolutely appalling. The litany of neglect which can be directly related to the previous Government's failure to provide funding for living and working facilities has been corrected only by the concerted efforts of the Labor Government in our first two Budgets and again in this 1985-86 Budget.

Time and again the Public Works Committee visited defence establishments and inspected existing facilities which were the subject of specific references it was considering. We found repeatedly antiquated buildings badly in need of maintenance and repair, inadequate areas of work space, obsolete equipment, dilapidated, white ant and borer infested houses and general working conditions which constituted a serious threat to occupational health and safety standards. Those former Government Ministers responsible for such a situation have absolutely no conscience when they have the colossal hide to come into this House and level criticism at the present Government on matters associated with the de- fence of this country.
The story of defence housing is starkly told in the forty-eighth general report of the Public Works Committee. Page 5 of that report states:

In February the Committee inspected on-base housing at RAAF Base Darwin as part of its inquiry into a proposal for refurbishment of the houses. The Committee was unimpressed by the standard of the houses and the level of maintenance. On a number of occasions in 1983 and 1984 the Committee observed similar deficiencies in housing at Defence establishments, but certainly not on the scale of RAAF Base Darwin.

As a consequence of the Darwin inspection the Committee took the unusual step of requesting the Department of Defence, the Department of Finance and the Department of Housing and Construction to present a briefing on Defence Housing.
. . . At the briefing the Committee was told that the current Defence housing situation is as follows:
(a) 14,300 (63%) of the total Defence stock of nearly 23,000 dwellings are below 1972 scales and standards of accommodation;
(b) about 12,000 of these below standard dwellings cannot be economically upgraded and should be replaced;

While time will not permit me to elaborate in any detail, a few examples of the many problems encountered by the Public Works Committee during the last two and a half years will starkly illustrate the truth in the claims I have made. In some 14 references that the Committee considered in relation to projects on defence establishments, it is difficult to single out just one or two which might be termed the worst examples of neglect by the former Government. However, I will mention a few of these examples. The first is the redevelopment of the seventh camp hospital at Kapooka, New South Wales, where a new building was proposed to serve the medical needs of the Kapooka army camp. The Committee found the hospital housed in a Second World War building, the condition of which was utterly deplorable with white ant infestation, leaking roofs, bad ventilation and most unhygienic facilities. The waiting area for recruits required to undergo tests on entering the camp comprised an old army tent with plastic sheeting on the otherwise bare ground of the floor.

Similarly, when the Committee inspected the munitons factory at St Marys, New South Wales, where reconstruction of sections of the factory was being considered, we found Second World War buildings refurbished in the 1955-57 era wherein factory workers laboured in absolutely intolerable conditions which were obviously a serious health and occupational safety hazard.

In early 1983 the Committee considered the need to air condition the main inspection building at the School of Transport and Catering at Puckapunyal where the original building had been constructed in about 1976 without adequate light or ventilation. Air conditioning was proposed at the time the building was constructed but was deleted to save money. This has been referred to in some detail by my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) earlier in this debate. The area is in his electorate and naturally he showed his grave concern for that situation, which has been corrected by a decision of this Government.

Probably the worst example of neglect that the Committee encountered was at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, where in 1984 the Committee considered the need for a new 36-bed hospital, extension and renovation of the existing cadet mess, refurbishing of instruction blocks and construction of buildings for cadet accommodation and a new physical fitness facility. Once again, I must point out that in general most of the facilities the Committee considered for replacement at Duntroon were antiquated and generally in appalling condition. Once again, this was due to the irresponsible neglect of the former Government. In fact, on each occasion when the Public Works Committee has considered the need for new facilities, the evidence available on inspection has meant that there could be absolutely no other decision but to recommend in favour of the proposals being proceeded with urgently.

This particular 36-bed hospital at Duntroon has been the subject of recent criticism by the Liberal senator for Queensland, Senator MacGibbon, who saw fit to suggest that the $4.1m facility was unnecessary due to the already adequate provision of hospital facilities in the Canberra area. If the senator had shown only a small measure of responsibility before he launched into such unfounded criticism, he would have taken the opportunity to read the third report of 1984 of the Public Works Committee which addressed the consideration of that hospital in the light of the existing facilities in Canberra and agreed with the evidence given to the Committee by Major-Generals Gration and James, who more than adequately justified the need for that hospital. In explanation and justification of the Committee's decision that the hospital should be constructed, I submit to the House the following brief quote from that report:
The Committee was concerned to ensure that the possibility of making increased use of ACT health care facilities had been given consideration by Defence in developing the 5th Camp Hospital proposal.
The Committee therefore sought to establish the reasons why increased reliance on ACT health care facilities, and as a result the need for a 36-bed Camp Hospital, was considered to be inappropriate.
