TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs for 1985-86. One of the predominant features of those estimates is that there is expected to be an overall increase in expenditure in that Department of 4.1 per cent which, in real terms, is a decline of about 4 per cent. I will come back to those figures a little later. But I note for the record that there is to be an 18.9 per cent increase in general administration, a 32.9 per cent increase in expenditure on the Overseas Property Office, a 29.9 per cent increase in expenditure on postage and telephones and a 22.3 per cent increase in expenditure on aid administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members could well ask: Why are administrative costs in that Department rising so rapidly? The Budget Papers give some indication as to why they are. It is argued in the first place that the depreciation of the Australian dollar led to increased expenditure in that Department. I understand that that would most certainly be the case. But as far as the increase in expenditure on aid administration is concerned, the Budget Papers state that this is due largely to `management upgrading' and `an increase in staff numbers'-an increase of around 68. I fail to understand why the Department of Foreign Affairs Aid Bureau should need an increase in staff numbers of 68 for aid administration when real spending on aid has declined so savagely.

I think a more fundamental question needs to be asked. Why is so much money being pumped into administration in the Department of Foreign Affairs when so little attention appears to have been given to the general direction of Australia's foreign policy? Obviously, all Australians want a foreign policy which has a clear sense of direction, which is balanced in terms of our naional interest and which identifies very clearly our priorities.

I think members of the general public could be excused for being somewhat confused about the general direction of Australian foreign policy. Our foreign policy has all the coherence of a Nunawading how-to-vote card. Certainly it is a foreign policy which is a little hard to identify.

The priorities of our foreign policy should be fairly clear. We should be looking towards building and retaining our close alliances, particularly with the United States of America and other nations of the Western alliance. We should be building bridges with nations in our own region. We should be making a constructive contribution to improved international economic relations and we should, of course, be playing a constructive role in the search for global peace. When we look at the breakdown of the way those various policy areas are being handled by the Government, we see that they are really being handled with nothing more than confusion. I want to give just a couple of examples to demonstrate that point. I do not wish to reiterate the points made by others in relation to ANZUS, although I certainly associate myself with the remarks made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton).

A very good example of the way Australia treats its allies was given on 25 September when the Australian Ambassador to the United States, Mr Rawdon Dalrymple, made a speech, on the instructions of the Government, of really quite staggering proportions. It was a most extraordinary speech and, in saying that, I am not criticising Mr Dalrymple-I know the gentleman quite well-because I believe he is a very capable and excellent ambassador who will do very well in that post. But I criticise the Government for instructing him to make the speech. Honourable members will remember that the Australian Ambassador, in this speech, exhorted the United States of America to attack the French Government on French nuclear testing in the Pacific. Honourable members should not get me wrong. I am not, of course, supporting French nuclear testing in the Pacific; quite the contrary. It is most regrettable that those tests are continuing to take place.

But why did the Australian Government choose the 25 September to call on the US to act against the French when it has had nearly three years since its election to do precisely that. The Government chose a particularly critical moment in a relationship between the United States and France-a moment when the United States was least likely to act on the advice of the Australian Government. Obviously, the relationship with France is vastly important to the United States. France plays a central role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation alliance-it is a member of NATO-and it plays a central role in the whole network of the Western alliance. That relationship has clearly been strained by the Rainbow Warrior affair. It has clearly been strained by trade relations between the European Economic Community and the United States of America. At that time it was also a somewhat sensitive relationship, given the imminent visit to France of Mr Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. One can only wonder why the Australian Government would have chosen a moment like that to make that sort of request. I assume that it was a rather thoughtless administrative mistake. One assumes that the Australian Government did not have any malintent in making that decision of timing. The Australian Government drove a wedge through the Western alliance-a wedge which, fortunately on this occasion, was somewhat ignored by both the French and the Americans. The Australian Government tried to drive a wedge between the Americans and the French-if you like, between the Americans and the Europeans-which is precisely the objective of Soviet policy and has been for many years. So what the Australian Government was doing was destabilising the Western alliance as a result of certain actions, in particular by the French Government, when that alliance was in a somewhat tentative position.

There were further aspects of this ill-timed speech which added some strain in the relationship between the United States of America and the various Pacific nations. I cannot see that that is particularly to our advantage bearing in mind that, not only are those nations of the Pacific very important to Australia-the Government continually reminds us of that-but also we, as a nation, believe in an American presence in that part of the world. That did strike me as being a most extraordinary and quite appallingly timed speech. Fortunately for Australia, it is a speech which, on the other side of the Pacific, appears to have been ignored if not completely forgotten.

The second aspect of the estimates that I would like to look at relates to Australia's aid budget and the way that has changed, particularly this year, but certainly during the period of the Hawke Administration. The Government's talk about the problem of developing countries and its professed concern for the economic plight of that part of the world seem to me to be slightly hollow when, in the first place, as part of its package it introduces a full foreign tax credits system which discourages Australian firms from investing and establishing themselves in developing countries, when the long term solution to the problems of developing countries will rest in the very strong private sector growth and investment. They cannot get the investment; that is one of their problems. The foreign tax credits system is only making that more cifficult. But let us look at the aid vote itself. Before 1983 the Australian Labor Party was promising with great passion that it would bring up Australia's aid vote as a proportion of gross domestic product to the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent. That particular target has been reiterated not only from time to time by the Opposition but also in the report of the Jackson Committee on Overseas Aid. It states:
Australia should continue to aspire to the goal of providing 0.7 per cent of national income as aid and advance toward it as the economy grows--

The Government claims that the economy is growing. I cannot quite see why we are not advancing towards the target. When we look at the figures, the aid vote seems to be moving in the opposite direction. In 1984 it was 0.51 per cent of gross domestic product, in 1985 it was 0.5 per cent, and in 1986 it will be 0.45 per cent. Indeed, for the 1985-86 financial year there will be a 4.9 per cent decline in real terms in aid funds. There are those who argue that even the figure of 0.45 per cent of GDP for 1985-86 is a little phoney because in the aid budget the special subsidy for private overseas students was added, both this year and last year. If one were to take away that subsidy, since it did not exist in the aid vote before 1984, one would see that our aid as a proportion of GDP is 0.41 per cent, which is the lowest level of aid contribution for 20 years.

I understand that the Government wants to reduce expenditure-nobody is a greater advocate of that policy than I am-but the Government has behaved both deceptively and hypocritically on this issue in raising false expectations about its commitment to developing countries and moving in precisely the reverse direction. The Government and many members of the Australian Labor Party are great critics of the United States of America, but I point out that in recent months the United States has announced a further additional contribution to aid finance of $29 billion. The Australian Government appears to be moving in the other direction, in spite of its rhetoric. It is clear that the Australian Government has given up on developing countries. It is clear that its rhetoric is empty and that it no longer has the sort of commitment the Fraser Government had to an improved international economic climate, particularly for those developing countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to speak briefly to Australia's international aid program and particularly to that part of the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs relating to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which appears under the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The particular item I wish to mention is the estimate of $4,700,000 for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, an increase of over $600,000 this year. On reading that item, along with the general comment offered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in relation to the aid program, one would think that this was a particularly generous contribution in the light of Australia's acceptance over a long period of its international obligations, particularly in relation to refugees. The fact is that that is not the case. We have a situation where, over a period, the High Commissioner has received significantly less funds and this is the first occasion on which there has been a rather meagre effort to restore the program to the level of support that has previously been offered by Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I for one want it put on the public record that no matter how much emphasis I place from time to time on the cutting back of government expenditure I do recognise that these budgets and estimates are about priorities. If we have to establish any priorities at all, I believe it is in Australia's own interests that we continue to support the High Commissioner and that we accept the responsibilities for supporting refugees. I say that in the context that Australia at present is reducing its contribution to resettling refugees within Australia. That means that there is a continuing and increasing obligation to provide for the needs of refugees in our region, in countries such as Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines, countries to which Indo-Chinese refugees in particular have fled and, at this stage, are fleeing in increasing numbers.

We recently had the tenth anniversary of the fall of Saigon and the loss of Vietnam. Associated with that, significant additional numbers of people have been fleeing to refugee camps in that part of the world. I was recently in Malaysia and saw an Indo-Chinese refugee camp. One of the things that struck me as I moved around the camp was the number of people who had recently fled to Malaysia from Vietnam. One man in particular had been held in a re-education camp for some 10 years and had only just been released. He had previously been a military intelligence officer and had family in the United States of America, but he had been held in a re-education camp for all that time. Another case was that of a Roman Catholic priest who had left Vietnam because he was asked to spy on his clerical colleagues. He was not prepared to do that, so he was put into a re-education camp. Those are the sorts of people we find in these situations. We are not bringing them into Australia in increasing numbers; in fact we are reducing the numbers we are resettling, and at the same time we have significantly decreased Australia's support for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

I was alarmed when recently I was informed that the support given by Australia, according to the figures produced by the United Nations High Commissioner, as our contribution both to general programs and special programs for his 1984 year, was $9,154,621. Speaking of the 1985 contributions as at 9 August 1985-the amounts at that time were not complete, according to the Commissioner's figures but I am sure as against our appropriations they would have been complete-for both general and special programs Australia's contribution was $4,776,953. Studying earlier estimates, I realised that in 1983 we indicated that we were going to change the basis upon which the funding for the UNHCR occurred. During a hearing of the Senate Estimates Committee this year Senator Teague asked some questions about the funding of multilateral programs and the UNHCR in particular. In answer, Dr Manning stated:

I could only say that there has been in fact, selectively, some increse this year in . . . those votes. The reduction that the senator refers to was regrettably beyond the resources of government in the two years under question.

When we go back through the earlier years we see that the Government was changing the basis upon which funding was to be given to the UNHCR. It was to be funded for one half of the year in 1983-84 and to be made up in the following year 1984-85. When we came to 1984-85 that increase did not occur. It was still funded on the half-year funding of the previous year.

I think the changes that have occurred need to be measured against the Government's rhetoric in this area. The Minister for Foreign Affairs recently issued statements in his own name speaking glowingly about Australia's increased humanitarian assistance-in this case it was about $1m to the UNHCR. He recorded in that case that there were contributions to assist a Cambodian returnee project, amongst other matters. It also involved the allocation of 100 tonnes of rice for feeding programs for Kampuchean refugees. I am not saying that they are not important-they are-but I think the amounts of money we are making available, in comparison to the support we have given previously, are severely wanting. I have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in an advertisement for Austcare, asking the Australian public further to support that organisation and the refugees throughout the world. The advertisement is appearing regularly on television in Sydney. When I listen to it I feel quite remorseful to hear the Prime Minister asking the public to offer its support when I know that government support has been reduced as significantly as it has over recent years. The UNHCR cannot go pleading on its own behalf, but in its journal Refugees, which it circulates, the Commissioner makes this plea about the organisation's funding:

In 1985, UNHCR requires some US$500m to meet the needs both of regular refugee programmes throughout the world, and of the critical emergency programmes in Africa. UNHCR's programmes are not luxurious-if the necessary funds are not found, refugees will suffer. The situation for 1986 looks just as serious. While it is part of UNHCR's duty and practice to be as economical as possible while giving refugees adequate assistance, only a renewed effort of support from the international community can provide the resources UNHCR needs to carry out its task.

I note that in an article appearing in the Far East Economic Review published most recently, the section on foreign relations refers to those refugees. It refers to compassion fatigue, which Asia suggests Australia is suffering from because of its unwillingness to take refugees. The consequence of the reduction overall in the UNHCR budget has been that programs, particularly in Indonesia, but I gather equally elsewhere throughout Asia, including Thailand and Malaysia, have been cut back. The Far East Economic Review refers to the successive UNHCR directors in Jakarta who have been paring back expenses. It refers to running costs for the Indonesian operations having been cut to less than $US1 per refugee per day for food and medicine. That is put in the context of a comparison with Australia's performance. I ask this simple question: Why is it that we have made these significant reductions in the UNHCR budget over time? Is it a reflection on the confidence that Australia has in the UNHCR as a world agency or is it because we really lack some commitment to assist refugees throughout the world?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by thanking the honourable members for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), Isaacs (Mr Charles), Bowman (Mr Keogh), Mayo (Mr Downer), Higgins (Mr Shipton) and Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) for participating in the debate. I think that they all, except perhaps the honourable member for Dundas, at some point of time touched on matters relating to my portfolio, and I will attempt to answer the points made. I thank particularly the honourable members for McEwen, Isaacs and Bowman, who put very well the perspective of this Government on the requirements for upgrading the living conditions and facilities available to service personnel in this country. That is an enormously important aspect of their morale and an enormously important sign of the regard in which the community holds the people who have decided that they wish to devote a considerable portion of their lives to the service of this country. Their remarks were appreciated in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that I did not have the opportunity to thank the Leader of the National Party on the previous night the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) was debated, but the debate ended early and before I had a chance to reply. I thank him for the very kind and appropriate remarks he made about the seamen aboard HMAS Perth and HMAS Adelaide in regard to the efforts they undertook to rescue the crew of the ship Hoelien and also to ensure a successful salvage of the ship. Unfortunately, ultimately, that attempt was unsuccessful. Over the past week or so the community has had an opportunity to see at first hand one of the aspects of the real value of the Royal Australian Navy in the activities of the crew of those two ships and the activities of those aboard the ship Curlewe and associated Fleet Air Arm activities, with the efforts for the search for the Pel-Air Aviation Pty Ltd aircraft that went into the sea off Botany Bay.

Many of the remarks made by honourable gentlemen went to aspects of our strategic situation. I am fortunate to have here the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) who came back from overseas especially for this debate. He is well primed and will make all things absolutely clear in this area when he speaks following my contribution. I will not canvass at great length the matters that were put forward generally in relation to our principal alliance commitments and a number of other related foreign policy areas, although I will deal with certain defence aspects of that. I will try to deal in a little detail with some of the points that were raised about various aspects of the defence appropriation and attempt to answer the questions that were raised.

The Leader of the National Party asked about the rate of progress on Paul Dibb's review and when we can expect a response to it. From my conversations with Mr Dibb and what he has shown me so far, the review is progressing very well. I anticipate that he will meet his timetable of next March and I would anticipate a public release of what it is possible to release publicly in that report fairly shortly thereafter, with the initial Government response and a more substantial Government response probably five or six months after that. Naturally, decisions taken in this interim period in relation to equipment will have very much in mind the sorts of points that Mr Dibb will make to us.

The Leader of the National Party also made a point about the Pacific patrol boat. He went quickly across that point and indicated that he wanted me to say something about it, without fully expressing reservations that he felt ought to be expressed about it. The Pacific patrol boat program has been something of an education for my Department. It has gone through the process of sitting down with a large number of Pacific countries and negotiating with them what they felt to be an appropriate design for a boat for maritime surveillance in their region; a design which they could readily maintain and live with and which would be genuinely useful to them. It has not been a program which we have pursued with any form of arrogant intent and I do not think that we have displayed arrogance in relation to it. Naturally, we have come across problems, when talking with so many nations, about meeting all the points raised by them. After a very lengthy consultative process, in which the design was approved in writing by Papua New Guinea and several of the other partners, we sent a design for tender. It is in the nature of these negotiations, when dealing with such a large number of countries with different priorities, that the views of governments change from time to time. Some views will gladden our hearts; others will cause us pain at different times. Nevertheless, it is an activity that has to be pursued because we are very mindful of the requirement on us to take a greater level of responsibility in the south Pacific area than we have been willing to do hitherto. I note from comments made from both sides of the House that evidently such an intention has bipartisan support. As we do that we will find ourselves in a situation where we will have to be diplomatically sensitive. Those who may find themselves in opposition at times and those in government will have to take a little on trust that we are pursuing an appropriate diplomatic strategy in that regard and that we will in our defence co-operation programs and all its aspects, both in this and other areas, pursue that sensitively. On occasions we will need a bit of diplomatic backing because we will not always be in agreement with those with whom we are dealing. Nevertheless, there needs to be bipartisan support for a sustained Australian effort in that area.

The Leader of the National Party also dealt with the question of the perception of a threat in this region and related it to defence expenditures. I must say that I agree largely with his assessment of the strategic environment in which Australia finds itself from that point of view. He conceded that he did not see any immediate threats to our national integrity, which is unquestionably the case, and he pointed out areas of instability in the region, which he identified correctly. The Government is alert to that. The fact that we believe that we ought to be able to confront those problems, largely without our own resources, as the most appropriate addition or contribution we could make to the general position in the Western alliance motivates a substantial proportion of our defence policy.

Our strategy of defence self-reliance is not a strategy of continental defence in terms of either doctrines to be espoused by the military or ultimately its effect on the relationship with the region. It is a strategy which at least has in part as its motivation the recognition that Australia has to move out of an essential immaturity which I think has afflicted its foreign and defence policies in the past, whereby we anticipate that outside our immediate confines we expect an ally to perform those functions, with occasional supporting noises from us. Our allies, over a period now, have made quite clear to us that they expect us to perform those functions, and whether or not they will come alongside will be dependent upon the extent to which they judge this area to be of strategic significance to them at that point of time. I think that that is a very reasonable position for our alliance partners to adopt. I can only say that as far as we are concerned we are prepared in the Defence portfolio to take on the obligations that that entails.

Comment was made on the size of the defence forces and Defence Force strength, and particularly on a reduction in numbers in regard to the Navy and the Army. As far as I am concerned, there is no question but that in this environment, which is relatively benign at present, the expenditure priorities of this Government go to capital equipment and to facilities. We believe that this is an area which must be addressed systematically for some considerable period if we are to have appropriately modernised defence forces at a period in which we may confront a somewhat less benign environment than we do at present. We are also required to maintain within our defence forces personnel of adequate skills, and that means that they will need to be properly remunerated. So it is to those two areas, the conditions of service personel and capital equipment, that our priorities go.

To a certain extent, therefore, priorities elsewhere will not be as heavily emphasised. One of those areas-I think appropriately so-is manpower levels. As was pointed out, it is true that over this Budget and the two previous Budgets we shall reduce the Navy by some 1,600 personnel. This is simply a realisation of the savings flowing from the decision not to purchase a carrier. This reduction has been phased over five years to permit achievement through normal wastage.

On the question of civilians in the Department, putting aside the complications of functional changes over recent years, the number of civilians in what was Defence until December 1984 fell by some 1,500 over the 10 years to June 1985. This year there will be a reduction of 419 from what was in last year's Budget. So it is not just in the area of service personnel that there are reductions; they are also taking place on the civilian side.

On the question of reductions in the Army, the Chief of the General Staff recently announced where those reductions lay. I must congratulate him on keeping firmly in place what might be called the sharp end of the Army, and on taking the reductions in the logistics area and in areas which could be fulfilled either by contract or by civilian personnel at a cheaper rate and keeping an emphasis in the armed forces, at least at the level of their personnel, on the business end of their activities. That displays an appropriate priority from him.

Contrary to that, in moving towards targets and not reducing targets, we are increasing the number of reserves. I think that over time some of our general intention in this regard was evident in that announcement by the Chief of the General Staff. We want to see the reserves play a more significant role by being integrated into the activities of the regulars and, in particular, into the business end about which I was talking earlier. As a result of that, I think that there will be two developments, one of which we would welcome, I think, and another of which, as Defence Minister, I shall have to watch. One of those developments is that I think that the members of the reserves can be confident that they will be highly valued as part of the defence forces, and that is a useful consequence. The second development or element that I shall have to watch very carefully is the legislative position of the reserves to ensure that they are able to do that. I am not fully convinced that the appropriate legislative position is in place. That is something that we shall be reviewing.

The Leader of the National Party also wanted advice from me on the F18 program and what was happening with that. I put out a very lengthy Press release. I know that the right honourable gentleman does not like me putting out such announcements in Press releases, but I think that he would have found this one comprehensive in answering most of the questions that I could conceive he would have in this regard. As I have just received a note from the Leader of the House (Mr Young) saying that I have spoken for too long and have been extremely boring, I shall not go into the Press release in any detail, except to draw honourable members' attention to it.

The right honourable gentleman also asked for our views on Project Waler. I make just two quick comments on that. Project Waler will not proceed at this time because reviews have concluded that there is insufficient justification for costly unique to Australia developments. Instead, like other nations-for example, the United States of America-Australia will seek to modify its current fleet of M113s. I think that a point of importance in regard to that, at least to me as Minister, is that I have also initiated a study of light armoured fighting vehicles, to consider the relative priority to be given to armoured fighting vehicles like the M113 and to vehicles which are considerably lighter and cheaper than the M113 which might provide the necessary mobility and fire-power but not quite the level of armour, which has very considerable constraints on it if we are looking at the air mobility of our ground forces.

The question whether we were providing adequately for housing was raised. All that I can say on that matter is that in the three years under this Government we have provided 25 per cent more housing commencements than were provided during the last three years of the coalition-1,416 versus 1,127.

Some assurances were sought about the basic trainer. I take on board the points made about that. We expect to reach a decision over the next three to four weeks or so-perhaps a little longer on that program. The comments made about it were very pertinent. The process through which we have gone-I cannot go into detail about what is essentially a tender process-has across the board dramatically reduced the likely cost to the Australian Government from what it would have been had we not proceeded down that course.

I want to cover one or two points on more general aspects of our defence policy in relation to our alliance. The point was made by the honourable member for Higgins that under left wing pressure I was reducing port visits to Western Australia. That is a total misreading of the motives of that particular proposal. As I indicated in the House the other day, but it does not seem to have sunk into the head of the honourable member for Higgins, that proposal is based on an assumption that, particularly in the current environment, we cannot have it regarded or believed by either nations in our region or a substantial proportion of the Australian population that we have a two-coast policy on port visits-port visits to one side of Australia, but not port visits to the other side because we have run away from the political consequences of that. As far as I am concerned, that is not an acceptable position, particularly in the current environment. For that reason, I took up what has been a standing interest of the United States in additional port visits to the eastern States. Whether or not that produces a reduction in visits to Western Australia will depend very much on the extent to which the United States increases or reduces its deployment in the Indian Ocean. That has fluctuated quite substantially over the last three to four years and is largely responsible for fluctuations in the number of ships that visit here. If the United States increases its presence and its activity in the Indian Ocean next year as it did this year, I think, over the figures for last year, from memory it probably will not result in any reduction of visits to Western Australia. If, however, the United States goes back to lower levels of participation, it might do so. The point is that it will be decisions that are taken on deployment patterns in that area that will have the dominant influence on what subsequently emerges.

Finally, on the question of ANZUS, as far as the defence relationship is concerned, I make just two points. First, we have a different approach to ANZUS from that of our predecessors. We have an approach which I think is appropriate to the developments in United States foreign policy in particular since the early 1970s and which has been substantially maintained. We believe that we are not an adequate participant in that unless we can at least move towards a substantial position of defence self-reliance if we are to play any substantial role in this region and not be constantly placing the United States in a position in which, if some problem occurs here, the Americans automatically have to regard what they are going to do for Australia, or whatever, as the only factor that will play in their foreign policy position or attitude that they develop towards that. That is likely, over time, to be of some embarrassment to them.

Secondly, an alliance relationship reflects shared values and also involves exchange. It is a relationship in which it is expected that both sides will gain benefits. In the process of working that out, there is likely to be disagreement between partners. Thirdly, like any proper alliance between partners that ought to at least regard themselves as equal, and approach the relationship as equals, even if that manifestly is not the case when one looks at the military realities, there is, as a minimum position consonant with our national dignity, the fact that we should at least address every foreign policy and defence concern that we have, firstly, from the point of view of the Australian interest and, subsequently, in an attempt to get our allies to address our interest. That is the only approach that, I believe, will produce a satisfactory result in the ANZUS relationship in the long term. It is also the only approach that will keep a reasonably bipartisan level of support in the community for the maintenance of the ANZUS alliance.

We are jealous of our relationship with the United States as far as this Government is concerned. We are aware of the massive contribution Australia makes, particularly to the global central balance through the joint facilities. We are aware that, in that regard, we can approach the American alliance from the point of being a country with something useful to say to the United States and we will not shrink from opportunities to do so when the occasion arises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, thank you for the opportunity to reply to some of the comments which have been made in the course of these estimates debates which affect my Department as much as the Department of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). In passing, I also thank the Minister very much for his acknowledgement, when he rose earlier, that my opportunity to speak would be an opportunity for me to go into considerable detail on complex issues related to some of the matters which have been raised. I thank him for persuading me to believe that there was a clear advantage for me in speaking after him. It is a favour I look forward to reciprocating on some occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Chair, if you contemplate the matters which were raised in the course of this debate on the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs, it seems to me that they fall clearly into two areas. One area substantially concerns the ANZUS relationship and some of the problems which quite evidently have arisen in that area. The other area is fairly limited-our aid budget. This encourages me to arrive at a conclusion, which is simply this: The silence on so many other areas where we are active in foreign affairs is an eloquent testimony of their approval by honourable members. Given that silence, there seems to be an extraordinarily bipartisan level of support for the things we are doing. For instance, one would have thought that if there were any contention in regard to our initiatives in arms control and disarmament, it would have been brought well to the fore and a very sharp edge developed. There has been no comment-ergo, approval.

We have been active in developing a central American policy, although, I freely acknowledge, not without some contention. But we have done it honestly and according to principles. I believe that we have reflected the great values that go to make up Australian society: A fair go, fair dealing, respecting people and respecting countries' rights. Again, there has been no dispute. We have been notable for our initiatives in our immediate region. In regard to Indo-China, for instance, I am heartened to see some evidence of an easing of the conflicting expressions which have, from time to time, been characteristic of presentation from some quarters. However, I hasten to add that one should not draw too much of an optimistic conclusion about that. There is still a long way to go. What has happened could easily fall into reverse, as happens in so many of these areas of grave dispute.

The most notable such area, of course, is the Middle East. There again, as is the case with our own region, we have expressed views even-handedly and have been persistent with our concerns. As was the case with Indo-China, there has been no opposition to our initiatives. In regard to our relationships throughout East Asia and South East Asia, some initiatives were taken in South Asia. Again, looking to the South Pacific or the Indian Ocean, there was no evidence of a debate or of difference. There is no matter of substance so serious as to cause concern between respective parts of the House on any of these great issues. I can say only how much I appreciate the silent but nonetheless eloquent and persuasive bipartisan support for what we have been doing.

I come to the areas where some critical observation has been made by some honourable members who have spoken in this debate. I will put to one side the ANZUS issue as a particular issue and deal with it last. I start with some of the comments made by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I compliment him on his tight, well thought out, cogent presentation. I disagree with the conclusions he has made, but some of the facts he has presented are indisputable. It gives me no comfort to have to confess that it is true that there has been a notable reduction in real terms in the aid budget for this year. However, it must be seen in the context not only of how generous we feel as a result of humanitarian inspirations, which we all share in this House, but also of how these things fit together in terms of our budgetary obligations and, in turn, our responsibilities in economic management.

The Government has been phenomenally successful in economic management in the last three years, including the current year. Our real growth has been the envy of the developed world. We are bringing down unemployment. Retail sales, car sales and activity generally in the economy are increasing. We have been very successful in getting down inflation. Of course, there are pressures in that area as a result of the pressure on the Australian exchange rate. Nonetheless, if one takes it on balance, ours is overwhelmingly a sustained record of success. In that respect, it is dramatically different from what occurred in the seven years of the preceding conservative government administration of this country.

We have to be careful to try to keep the economy on track. That is no easy task in a world which is fraught with all sorts of economic difficulties. A country with an economy such as ours, as exposed as it is, and as involved as it quite evidently is in international trade, cannot immunise itself from international pressures. One of these areas is the external account. We inherited an Australian dollar that was artificially valued for reasons which were quite spurious and damaging to the economy of this country in the medium to longer haul. Nonetheless, that is a fact of life. To artificially contrive it, certain pressures were put on the domestic economy.

We have a floating exchange rate. Accordingly, domestic management, where it affects the external account, can affect the value of the dollar one way or the other. Things we do which flow through the external account will affect the value of the dollar one way or the other. Our aid bill is paid for on our external account. If we are writing money on our external account for our aid bill, indifferent to the state of our trade account, our current account, in certain circumstances we could run into problems. Therefore, we have to be prudent. Some of those circumstances apply at present. I repeat: Our position gave me no satisfaction or comfort at all, as one who freely acknowledges his deep commitment to the principles of democratic socialism. Democratic socialists have a very strong feeling about their obligations to developing countries. I am not saying that we have a monopoly on it. It is to the credit of this country and the Parliament that very largely there has been a high level of bipartisanship about the commitment to aid. However, the point I make is that I received no joy in being in the position I was in. I was not one who fought my presentation at the altar on this issue. I recognised, as a matter of economic responsibility, that I had to take my medicine with everyone else. There were cuts. That is the simple fact. It would have been irresponsible to this community if we had not faced up to that decision, if I had not faced up to that decision, if I had merely pursued my own conceited ambitions and aspirations to get the best I could in every nook and cranny out of the Budget, because that would not serve the best interests of this country. More than that, if it became evident that what we were doing in particular areas affecting the external accounts, like our aid budget, was detrimental to the domestic interests of this country, two things follow: First, the longer term resilience of our economy to sustain genuine and growing commitments in aid would be seriously undermined; and secondly, community consensus would be eroded badly. All these are things which I just have to face. If members of the Opposition wish to make points of that, I understand why they do it. Political point-scoring is part and parcel of the processes here. I will be unapologetic in explaining why we had to do it. If one addresses oneself to the economic forecasts which hop up in Statement No. 2 of the Budget, one sees that there are reasonable prospects for the future. Part of the benefit of those reasonable prospects I see is a progressive restoration of our aid commitment. That is the long and the short of the situation.

I move away from that general set of propositions to more particular ones and respond to the views which were put quite forcefully and quite thoughtfully by the honourable member for Mayo. He referred to increasing staffing numbers and costs in the Foreign Affairs area. I have to say as a matter of melancholy admission that it occurs within one section of my ministerial responsibility, that is, the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. It has not occurred within the Department of Foreign Affairs itself. There is a clear and overwhelming justification for those increases. We are spending something like $1,000m a year on aid. By any measure, that is a lot of money and it has to be spent in an accountable way. We have to monitor it. First of all, we have to make sure that the programs are soundly based and that, according to criteria we set-economic, social and sometimes political-the results we have been setting ourselves in these programs are going to be met. Having decided that, we monitor to make sure that they will be met.

If we do not have adequate staff we will not have good quality preparation and operation in these programs. I have never sought to embarrass previous conservative governments for some serious shortcomings in the area of aid, of which there are quite a number and which would fill up a very interesting matter of public importance debate in this House on some occasion. I have not done it because the Australian Development Assistance Bureau has done its best. It has very fine officers. I am sure that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) will agree with me that they are very competent people. But the facts are that there have been some rather large duds in development programs during the period in which the conservative government was in office, and I guess that there are going to be some more. The thing is to try to make sure that the duds are minimised and that, as much as possible, it is not the fault of either ADAB or the government of the day.

The reason this happened was that ADAB just has not had enough staff. That has been a fact declared by a succession of reports from the Senate, the Public Accounts Committee and, most recently, the Jackson Committee of Review of Australia's Overseas Aid Program. In 1985-86 aid administration costs will be 1.54 per cent of the aid program. That is the second lowest of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Only New Zealand has a lower proportion. It is expected to rise to 1.7 per cent of the program as management changes occur. It will still be one of the lowest proportions of all aid agencies. I make no apologies at all about this. It is my aim to try to increase the numbers of people we have working on staff in ADAB, particularly professional people, and in that regard people who will be out in the field supervising projects. Then we will not have some of the embarrassing duds which have shown up in the Auditor-General's reports over the past several years, nor will we go into a major program like northern Samar.

When I looked at that project and called for the papers on it, I said: `Is this economic? Where is the justification for it?' I discovered not only that it was not economic but the Department of Finance had advised against undertaking it on economic grounds because the return was not there. We are talking not about peanuts but about a program on which tens of millions of dollars is going to be spent. That was approved by the honourable member for Kooyong when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs and was only one of several such programs. So I suggest to the honourable member for Mayo that we do not go too far down that track. I have not sought to embarrass the Opposition on these matters. I can recognise some of its difficulties, although they were self-inflicted. It should have responded to the reports from various parliamentary committees. It should have provided more staff. We are seeking to rectify its neglect. If the Opposition wants to make that an issue, let us make it an issue of contention during debate in this Parliament at some time in the future.

Another matter the honourable member for Mayo raised was the speech by Ambassador Dalrymple less than a fortnight ago in Washington. The views Ambassador Dalrymple put forward, I think, are perfectly respectable and justifiable views. I endorse them. The points have been registered. There is no need for me to labour those points any further. The honourable member for Mayo then moved on to some concern about foreign tax credits. Reflecting I think more the self-interested concern of certain sections of the corporate sector than worries of developing countries, he argued that this was in its own way an undermining of aid support for developing countries. I am not too sure where the major benefits for developing countries go as a result of the tax credit arrangements. It is a purely subjective impression, but I have to say that I think the bulk of them go to Hong Kong and Singapore, which are not quite the paradigms of the struggling developing countries in the world. If we are going to provide aid for developing countries I think there are far more effective ways of doing it than in that indiscriminate manner. For all its shortcomings, the development import financing facility is a better mechanism for providing that sort of assistance. It is only one of many but it is one whose budgetary allocations have increased from about $2.5m, when we came into office, to more than $16m in this year's Budget. So I think that if one focuses on the global picture rather than one particular aspect of it one finds not only that there are better ways of doing things but that they are in fact being done.

The honourable member for Mayo then expressed criticism of the Government on the issue of private overseas students. The circumstances surrounding private overseas students created a great deal of concern for me when I became Foreign Minister. Certain matters were put to me about the program, as though it was going to trundle along in the way in which it had always trundled along. There was no analysis of the momentum behind it, of the direction from which that momentum was coming, of the implicit costs, or whatever. I demanded certain things. I demanded to know what the implicit cost was for the Australian taxpayer. I will tell the House what the implicit cost is this year. It is $97m. By any measure, that is a lot of money. The questions I wanted answered were: Is this a priority ahead of other priorities? What are the other priorities? That seemed to me to be a reasonable discipline that anyone with public sector responsibility handling taxpayers' cash should ask. Who is getting the benefit of this money? How has this program developed? In what way is it regulated? What are the objectives? What are the directions? In a word, it was directionless, and I discovered that about 56 per cent, in round figures, of the total number of students coming here came from one country. How did that happen? Why did it seem to be a very large proportion from one area and very small proportions from many other countries which are of considerable importance to us? One country which I have in mind, which has a large proportion, is extremely important to us. We have very good relations with that country and I do not want there to be any misunderstanding at all about that, but it seems to me that these things had not been addressed. When I inquired it was clear that like Topsy the thing just grew in its own direction because of the attitude of preceding Ministers. I do not need any lectures about how to handle these sorts of programs where public funds are concerned.

The thing that strikes me about any area in which we are spending taxpayers' money is that we receive a lot of advice gratuitously from the Opposition about the need for small government in ways that seem to imply that if one is a moderate or low income earner the chances of sending one's child to university or on to higher education or giving him or her a whole range of things that are pretty important will be diminished and the prospects of one having self-respect in one's retirement will be reduced. That is what small government seems to be to members of the Opposition. Yet the same people never once looked at this particular area with any sense of fiscal discipline or any awareness of the priorities in policy management. That has changed. It has changed because I addressed myself to it, and I make no apologies about that program. Large numbers of people are still coming here and they will continue to come here. We are providing a hefty subsidy for that program, but there must be a limit to what one can do with aid money and very properly that is in the aid budget. I am not sure about the comparisons, but I would have thought that looking at our figure, relative to the size of this country's economy, it is not a bad performance and it stands up pretty healthily against those of other developed countries.

The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) raised some questions about our support for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. He made some telling criticisms. I acknowledge them; they are soundly based in fact. But once again, it is a matter of where we are in economic management. All I can say is that as much as I find it disconcerting to acknowledge that the honourable member is right in pointing to a reduction, I remind him that our highest priority is to try to get our economy back in shape and to keep it in shape. We want to get this country on course so that we have continuing economic growth which will generate more wealth and more opportunities for Australians to have better prospects in the future, a greater sense of security and confidence and to allow us to do things on the external account where we have this large humanitarian commitment. The Opposition has the large humanitarian commitment but it does not have the nous about how it will pay its way. We have the nous and the commitment and as we get things progressively in better shape-it is indisputable that we have been doing that-we can move progressively to restore some of these commitments and move into other areas which I am very keen to do.

Having said all those things, I come to the question of the ANZUS alliance. This is an area in which I find myself rather perplexed by the behaviour of the Opposition. Opposition members seem to regard New Zealand as some sort of small outlying tributary state which should be subject to the dictates of this country. It seems to me that that is national megalomania running rampant. I can assure honourable members now that if they go to New Zealand displaying that attitude-presuming they are in a position where they can be taken seriously, and that is quite distant-they would very quickly get short shrift from the New Zealanders because, like us, they have great national self-respect and they justifiably have great pride in what their country is, what it has done and the contributions that it has made.

I would also like to remind honourable members, particularly Opposition members, of this simple set of facts. Of course the ANZUS alliance is extremely important to us. Our association with the United States is indisputably of great value and importance to us. That is a principle that has been repeatedly upheld in proclamations by honourable members opposite. Let me also say this: Our relationship with New Zealand is equally important to us for a series of reasons that are quite distinctive. The role of New Zealand should never be written down nor should the right of New Zealand to self-respect as a sovereign territory be demeaned in debate in this Parliament.

I shall deal now with those two matters. First, our relationship with the United States. The ANZUS Treaty gives certain undertakings. However, these are not the sorts of undertakings which absolutely guarantee, regardless of whatever circumstances arise, that ample numbers of people will always be on our doorstep with ample equipment and ample commitment to do what we perhaps should have been doing ourselves. That point was eloquently made by the Minister for Defence. There are obligations on us to look after ourselves, and to be prepared to do so. As a self-respecting Australian and an unapologetic nationalist, I find that a highly desirable principle for us to constantly recognise. Nonetheless there are those undertakings and they are very important.

One of the great virtues that I find among the pre-eminent virtues of our association with the United States is the privileged access that we have to advanced military technology. Quality helps to make up for the shortage of numbers in this country. That is a very important asset for us. It is an advantage that not a lot of countries in the world have. We should value it and look after it. We certainly do. The other asset is access to intelligence in its various forms. We play our role in collecting intelligence in certain ways, as does the United States on a far bigger scale because of the resources that are available to it, and we exchange information. For a small country like ours, eyes and ears are very handy to let us know what is happening in the world. There are benefits there. However, there is no reason why we should not be confident in this relationship. There is no reason for docility or servility. I sometimes suspect that, in the cloying manner in which some conservatives on the Opposition benches talk about this relationship, servility and docility are dominant in their approach to this matter. It is a relationship in which there is room for mutual respect which properly should be practised. That is the way in which we proceed in this relationship.

One could look at ANZUS as an insurance policy in which one pays one's premiums. We pay up our premiums regularly and we pay them well. We host facilities in this country with the United States and the Australian Labor Party, particularly in government, has cogently and convincingly argued the case for the presence of those facilities. It has argued that case in the face of considerable hostility and objection to the presence of those facilities in Australia. I believe that we won that argument. The fact is that they are extremely important for a range of reasons. They are particularly important to the United States. We justify that, but the fact that we host them shows beyond any doubt that we are paying our premiums. We are paying them on moral grounds as well as practical grounds. In my view those facilities-if we take Soviet nuclear targeting doctrines at face value, and I believe we must do so-would be high priority nuclear targets in the event of a major exchange of nuclear weaponry. I said that when I was Leader of the Opposition after carefully considering the functions and purposes of those facilities, and I restate it today without any defensiveness at all because there is a powerful moral reason why we should be involved with those facilities. It is related to deterrence and to arms verification. So we are paying up there. We have American vessels using our harbour facilities and B52s using our airstrips.

This country, by its position in the world, is strategically very importantly placed. It is stable, culturally it has many commonalities with the United States and there is a deep and vast friendship between the two countries. In relation to South East Asia and East Asia, Australia is very well placed in the event of any serious problems occurring in the Indian Ocean, particularly the north-western sector of that ocean. It has an important position and these are extremely valuable collateral attributes that we have available to us. So there is no justification for docility or self-abnegating deference in relation to the United States. We pay our way in the supply of strategic resources and in hosting large and profitable investments from the United States. I do not have to make the point any further, it is a two-way business. I do not have to explore the reasons why strategically-for defence reasons and security reasons-it is important for us to have that association.

Let me now deal with New Zealand and how important it is. I have not the slightest doubt in my mind that, in the most unlikely event that this country were to run into trouble one day, New Zealand would be one of the first countries in the world to come to our aid. New Zealand has an enviable record that stands up against that of any other country in the world when it comes to defending what we would loosely call freedoms. Its commitment in the First World War proportionate to its population stands up better than that of any other country in the world. Even more than Australia, per capita it suffered the greatest casualty rate fighting on the Continent in defence of the Western allies.

In the Second World War, New Zealanders fought their way up the spine of the Italian Alps inch by inch in one of the bloodiest commitments of any group of troops from any country in the world. In the Second World War throughout the Pacific region, in Korea and in Vietnam it had a great record. I do not think that we should be gratuitously offensive to the New Zealanders at a time of difficulty like this. We have differences with the New Zealanders. The Opposition says it has differences with them; so do we. We have a different approach on these matters. But we can have differences and still respect people, and I have a great respect for them. They play an extremely valuable role in the South Pacific. That is something I do not want to go into in detail right now because time is running along and I have taken much longer than I intended in dealing with these matters.

The South Pacific is changing rapidly. The island states of the South Pacific are not the island states of 1944 when we entered into the Australia-New Zealand pact, a rather archaic set of provisions in some respects and in some areas. The island states are largely independent and they are now starting to go their own way. Some contact has been made with some countries-I am not just thinking of the Soviet Union; I am thinking of Libya, for instance, but not just Libya-which over the longer term might not be wholesome in our view in terms of what we would like to see as a sort of stable environment for our region. That is something which would worry Australians and it will take careful diplomatic handling.

One of the important countries in the handling of all of these issues is New Zealand. I think that we do a very good job. The contribution of the honourable member for Kooyong as Foreign Minister to events in the South Pacific, as in many other areas, was extremely valuable for this country. We have to continue to maintain the value of that commitment. New Zealand probably does it better in a number of areas in the South Pacific because it has concentrated-not exclusively, but dominantly-to a much greater degree than we have in that region. It will be important to keep that commitment intact.

Having put that sort of gloss on the overview or the connections as I see them, I come to the obvious next point. For us the challenge is much more complex and difficult than it is for New Zealand in dealing with the United States or for the United States in dealing with New Zealand or with us. We have to work out our destiny with the United States and we have to work it out with New Zealand. We have to try to keep New Zealand and the United States, even with their differences, maintaining some important level of harmony, while at the same time having a very good working relationship with both. It is not easy. We have a fundamental difference of policy view with New Zealand. We allow and will continue to allow United States vessels to use our port facilities. We allow and will continue to allow B52s to use our military airport facilities under circumstances which were laid down by a previous conservative government and which we have maintained. We believe that that is necessary for reasons related to our commitment to the ANZUS Treaty.

We do not believe that we can make distinctions about the naval vessels of the United States fleet, because we cannot expect, in any practical sense, the United States to have a series of different fleets-some conventional for this part of the world, some not nuclear-capable for another part of the world and so on. That is not a practical proposition as we see the situation. So we have differences with New Zealand. But we have to manage those differences and we have to manage them successfully. Huffing and puffing in a blowhard sort of fashion in this Parliament is just fine, I guess, if honourable members think it is influencing the electorate. It is fine so long as no one outside this country is taking it seriously and the electorate is not taking it too seriously either. To this point, we have been quite fortunate.

The situation which has developed is not one that we care for. We are doing our best in damage control. I was in Washington on Wednesday and Thursday of last week speaking with United States officials, including Mr Weinberger, the Defense Secretary, and Mr Shultz, the Secretary of State. They applaud the role we have been fulfilling. They look to us quite literally for advice on how we collectively can continue to handle this situation, because it is one fraught with some difficulties for them; not the least being understanding the nature of policies in the antipodes. I am not sure that many people in this country or in New Zealand always understand the nature of politics in the antipodes. It has a distinctive flavour about it, as the honourable member for Kooyong and I well understand for personal reasons. But we help the United States in that regard.

Secretary of State Shultz was kind enough to describe our bilateral relationship as excellent. I spoke in New York with Geoffrey Palmer, the Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand, about the situation, and his description of our role was `immaculate'. The New Zealanders are appreciative of what we are doing. There has been quite a deal of activity by us. It has not always been high key, because that is not always appropriate. I have spoken on this subject with United States officials, especially George Schultz, in places such as New York, Washington, Jakarta, Canberra, Kuala Lumpur and Wellington. The Minister for Defence has been to New Zealand to speak with officials there and he has spoken with them here. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has been to New Zealand to talk on this topic in detail. We have been quite active.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has discussed the matter on a number of occasions with Prime Minister Lange. Incidentally, I think that it was quite unfair and uncharacteristic of the honourable member for Kooyong to say that the Prime Minister had written a letter to Prime Minister Lange from which, when it became public, he sought to scuttle. That is not true. He stood firmly by it and, in fact, released the full details of that letter. We have been quite open.

All I can say is that those are the circumstances and the ingredients. They are the interests that we have and the things that we have to weigh up. They are not helped by the Opposition trying to score cheap points, but we persevere. If the Opposition thinks that our tactics are wrong and that our general approach is tardy and subject to condemnation, it should bear in mind that the United States does not agree. It prefers to go along the course which, frankly, we have largely plotted. We have largely set this course. I repeat that the United States is frequently in contact with us for advice on those matters.

All I have to say is that the situation seems to have reached something of an impasse at this point. When New Zealand introduces legislation which it has forecast it will introduce, we will have to look quite rigorously at what that legislation implies and where it is likely to take us. I know that the United States shares that sort of view. It is quite premature for me to be saying anything more than that at this time. I conclude by saying that we have been doing the best we can by the alliance, by each of the members of the alliance and by this country. While I acknowledge the right of the Opposition to try to score a few points for its benefit in the domestic electorate, I ask it to keep it within reasonable and responsible bounds because what we are handling is the national interest.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
