SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) gave a mysterious answer to what was obviously a dorothy dix question that one of the directors of Qantas Airways Ltd had misused his or her privileges as a director; presumably that person had used his or her travel privileges incorrectly. The Minister, by giving this mysterious answer, was presumably indicating that he was aware of the situation, that he was on top of the job and that he was going to do something about it. I suggest very strongly to the Minister that he has condemned every Qantas director. Every Qantas director is now under suspicion for abusing his or her position as a director of that company.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has a responsibility-he will have an opportunity when winding up this debate on the appropriations for the Department of Transport and the Department of Aviation-to give a complete story as to who that director is, what abuse of directors' privileges has occurred and what action he is taking, otherwise he is condemning, by this implied accusation, every director of Qantas. These are significant people in our society, very responsible people, who are carrying out a most responsible job with our international airline. I say again to the Minister that it is not good enough for him to answer in the way he did this afternoon. He must say who the director is who is being investigated, what those investigations are and what action is being taken so that every other director of Qantas is clear of that general accusation.

In the few minutes available to me I will direct most of my comments to the Department of Aviation because aviation is that part of the total transport area that is receiving most attention at present. That is understandable because of the publicity that has been given to the submissions to the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation-in other words, the two-airline inquiry. I want to restate the coalition policy of the 1984 election which remains the coalition policy at this stage. We believe in the progressive deregulation of the domestic airline industry-in other words, the two-airline policy. This will be done in consultation with the industry in a sensible, gradual and progressive manner and it carries with it the sale of Trans Australia Airlines. Before we lost office legislation had been enacted to turn TAA into a company. That obviously is the first step and that is followed by the sale of shares to the Australian public with special preference being given to TAA employees. I commend the Minister, the Bureau of Transport Economics and the Department of Aviation for the part that they have played in organising the recent seminar on airline regulation and deregulation. I attended that seminar and listened to all the comments for two days. As a result, it has confirmed in my mind the correctness of the coalition policy.

One other aviation matter that has been receiving publicity at present is the increasing competition on domestic routes as East-West Airlines Ltd takes advantage of two areas of flexibility in the coalition Government's 1981 legislation. I am referring to the `no-frills' or special services and also to services outside the specified trunk routes. I refer to a question that I asked the Minister in Parliament recently concerning the very long delay in his making a decision on East-West Airlines' application to import an additional F28 aircraft to augment these services. The Minister said in reply:

In respect of the application to import the F28, on 26 July I discussed that matter with the Managing Director of East-West Airlines. In the matter of that discussion I drew to his attention and that of his colleague present that, in differing items of correspondence provided to me by the airline, it had provided conflicting claims. On the one hand, it said that it had excess capacity. On the other hand, it sought additional capacity. Obviously both versions could not be correct. On that date I asked the airline to clarify the situation. As of this time, this afternoon, I have not received a response.

That was on 19 September and the Minister said that he had heard nothing since 26 July. The following day, East-West Airlines issued a Press release. After making that point about the Minister and his comments it stated in this release:
East-West Airlines has had correspondence or discussions on the matter with the Minister or his Department since the July 26 meeting.

The airline went on in that Press release to detail four separate occasions when there had been correspondence or discussions with the Minister or the Department. I quote the conclusion of that Press release:

Yesterday, September 19, East-West received from the Department of Aviation a six page telex seeking replies to a large number of matters relating to the importation request. An initial examination by the airline shows the requests are largely for the information supplied to the Department on June 12.

We have here a second very serious situation. According to the Press release issued by East-West Airlines, either the Minister was misinformed by his Department as to the contacts that had been made and, in turn, had inadvertently misled Parliament, or he was misleading Parliament because he had said quite clearly in his response to my question that he had heard nothing since 26 July and accused me and the airline of misinformation. I throw the accusation back at the Minister and I ask: Who has been responsible for misinformation? In the light of this very clear and direct indication of contacts and correspondence between the airline and the Department and/or the Minister, someone is not being completely honest and accurate. I suggest to the Minister that, along with replying to my first request that he should come clean on the matter of the Qantas director, there is a second request for him to come clean and say who is misinforming whom. I also suggest to the Minister that he has still not made a decision in relation to an application for an aircraft which was made more than six months ago. It is high time that such a decision was made and I hope that the application is approved.

I wish to deal in the last couple of minutes available to me with the question concerning the six-month investigation into what should be done to upgrade the Darwin Airport terminal. The time for a decision has now expired. As Darwin is one of the international gateways to Australia-it is the international airport of the Northern Territory-I hope, on behalf of the people of the Northern Territory, that the Minister and his Department are about to make a decision. I hope that that decision will include something better than just the refurbishing of the Second World War hangar. No matter what degree of refurbishing is done that hangar does not provide an adequate gateway to northern Australia in the 1980s.

The final point I want to make concerns roads. The Minister has been complimenting himself that the $1,245m available federally this year for road construction and maintenance in this country is a record-the most generous we have ever seen. In current dollar terms it is the same as last year. In real terms it is a reduction of about 6 per cent on last year's figure which, in turn, was a reduction of 3 per cent on the previous year's figure. Contrary to what the Minister has been claiming in relation to roads there is about an 8 to 9 per cent reduction in real terms in the two Budgets that this Labor Government has introduced in relation to the road needs of this country.

In conclusion, I once again say to the Minister that he has some serious answers to give in relation to Qantas directors and to the comment he made concerning East-West Airlines and the information needed to make a decision on the F28 aircraft. An appropriate time to answer both those questions would be at the conclusion of this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 as it relates to the Transport portfolio. The very size and diversity of Australia means that transport will play a significant role in this country. Transport over the years has undergone significant changes. For example, the past 20 years have seen revolutionary changes in shipping arrangements and technology. Likewise, there have been sweeping changes in the ways the waterside is organised and managed. Australia's ability to compete in international trade on terms which will maintain and improve our standard of living depends a good deal on workers in the transport field and their response to change. Recent studies have clearly shown that every additional $100m in exports generates 5,000 jobs in Australia. Until a few years ago it seemed sufficient to rely for our standard of living on our enormous reserves of natural resources, largely agricultural and mineral. This complacency was reinforced by conservative political parties, which did little in office but now talk big in opposition. Now other countries with plenty of similar raw materials are eating away at some of our traditional markets. We need to improve our efficiency, competitiveness and entrepreneurial skills in our traditional and newer markets. The simple fact is that Australia has to earn its way in an increasingly tough world, and it has been our Labor Government that has developed successful policies aimed at growth, the development of jobs and greater equity.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much to be done in the related areas of trade and transport. Our share of world trade has fallen by 25 per cent since 1972, and Australia has dropped from twelfth to seventeenth in ranking among Western exporters since 1970. The transport industry can help us develop, create jobs and sustain our standard of living. The inescapable answer is simply that by becoming more efficient and enterprising the transport industry can be improved. This calls for efforts by governments, management, unions and employees. The Hawke Government has done more than any previous administration to improve our national transport system, and this improvement will continue. We have placed a wide range of industries, in particular the transport industry, under intense scrutiny.

The Government has acted to improve the viability and efficiency of our shipping industry. It has taken special measures to help the Australian National Line overcome past neglect. We have established a task force to report on our overseas liner shipping with the participation of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government has also established a task force to report on shore-based shipping costs. We want to encourage industry to re-assess the efficiency of its own operations. We have made a lot of progress and there are visible signs of improvement, including a more robust and competitive Austalian National Line. The ANL is a valuable national asset that had been allowed to go to waste. This could not be tolerated. It would be hard to see us achieving long term stable growth in Australian shipping without a revitalised ANL. But there is no bottomless pit of money which would allow it to continue to lose money simply because it is the national line. Government enterprises have to count money in the same way as do private enterprises. Yet to turn around in a few short years, as this Government has, an organisation left virtually bankrupt by the economic incompetents who now propose privatisation as the answer can create tensions. Whatever tensions may be created, they would be nothing compared to the tensions and confrontation if those opposite ever had the opportunity to impose their privatisation policies.

I am pleased also that in this appropriation funds are provided for road safety program promotion and research. Too many lives are lost needlessly on Australian roads, but all the promotion in the world will be worthless if in many cases the attitudes of road users are not changed. I am very pleased to be a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety, which has in the past contributed and will continue to contribute significantly to transport safety. I note also that over $1m has been allocated for maritime search and rescue. No one can put a cost on human life and no one would argue with the need for an adequate maritime search service, but I must say that too many people treat the sea far too carelessly. Inexperienced people often put to sea in ill-equipped boats that should never go to sea. In a week or so we will have Sea Safety Week. I welcome this and hope that all interested will take this opportunity to better acquaint themselves with sea safety.

I turn to the importance of the road transport industry in Australia. This importance cannot be overemphasised. Some 70 per cent of all freight is moved at some stage by this industry, but despite the industry's role and importance it has lacked clear national direction. Previous governments have all but ignored pleas for help from the industry. It was not until the Hawke Labor Government came to power that a Federal government was prepared to take a comprehensive look at the industry and implement measures not the least of which was the commissioning of the May National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. The May Inquiry was given a big task. It had to consider questions of road safety, trucking efficiency, financing and the effects of government regulation and competition from rail. A year after appointment, in September 1984, it had met the task with a mammoth 509-page report to the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). The report has been the basis for a number of legislative changes already announced by the Minister. Last month he introduced the new `fast track' legislation based on the May Inquiry recommendation. The legislation involves the introduction of Federal registration of interstate trucks and licensing of interstate operators. The Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee, including governments, industries, unions and users, will be established within the Transport Industries Advisory Council. As the Minister said in this House, it is landmark legislation making the trucking industry more equitable and more secure. It is imperative that the industry be reformed because, as I said, 70 per cent of all freight is moved at some stage on roads. I add that trucking has had one of the highest rates of bankruptcies in Australia.

I support the Government's road policies. In my electorate of Throsby work is proceeding on the Berrima-Mittagong by-pass of the Federal Highway. One area to which I would like the Minister to give particular attention is a new road linking the southern highlands to the coast. With recent and planned developments at Port Kembla, including the building of a grain handling facility, it is imperative that an adequate road should link this major port with the southern highlands of New South Wales. A committee of the Illawarra regional organisation of councils is examining the feasibility of a new link at Johnsons Spur. I trust that the Minister will listen sympathetically to my representations for this to be an export development road. Without an adequate infrastructure the port of Kembla will not reach its full potential as a major export port, and the key to this must be a new road linking the port and the southern highlands. As I said before, this road will carry export grain and wool and it is imperative that it become an export development road.

My final point refers to the Australian National Railways Commission. I strongly support the Australian National Railways. I must say that my admiration increased recently when I travelled on the Ghan from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but I do believe-

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity you didn't go all the way to Darwin.

—No, there is no rail link to Darwin. We will have a good road to Darwin under this Government, which is more than we would ever have had under the previous Government. The Opposition screams about the rail link. The folly of the Liberals talking about a rail link! They had their choice. They are going to have an improved road link. They have got an excellent rail link to Alice Springs, and they will have a good road link too, so they must not talk nonsense about a rail link to Darwin. As I said, my admiration increased recently when I travelled on the Ghan from Adelaide to Alice Springs. I believe that much more could be done to promote the tourist potential of the ANR.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that a Tasmanian should rise to speak on these estimates of expenditure and receipts because Tasmania is affected by the decisions of the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) who in a sense controls the destiny of the economy of Tasmania to a very large degree. The estimates of expenditure receipts show airport concessions to be the second largest amount of income that comes into the Department of Transport; it was just over $43m for 1985-86. The report of the Auditor-General drew attention to significant administrative deficiencies within the Victorian and Tasmanian regional offices of the Department of Aviation. We have had the Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, so it is interesting to see how the Auditor-General treats the Department in the Tasmanian and Victorian regions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General said that one of the major deficiencies was that `the regional office was not reconciling the monthly financial statements with the audited annual financial statements and there was uncertainty as to which section in the region was responsible for this section'. The Auditor considered, as do all the people on this side of the Chamber, that this reconciliation is important. Omission of the reconciliation could result in lost revenue. It is interesting to note that the regional office has accepted the criticisms levelled at it in this regard. What I would like to know from the Minister is whether the failure of the regional office to conduct such reconciliations on a monthly basis results in losses being incurred. I hope that the Minister will address that in his summing up.

The report of the Auditor-General highlights another accounting deficiency in the Victorian and Tasmanian regional offices. Cost investigations were not performed for all concessions on a regular basis. Amazing as it seems, some concessions have never been investigated, while many others have not been investigated for two years. Once again, the office has accepted the recommendations of the Auditor-General in this regard and, once again, the question must be asked whether the failure of the regional office to investigate adequately the concessions on a regular basis resulted in any lost revenue. The Minister must come clean and inform the Chamber whether the accounting procedures of the Department of Aviation have been updated and streamlined in order to avoid potential financial losses. The Minister has spoken in support of the Bosch report. Considering that the amount of $43m is the second largest item in the Department of Aviation accounts, perhaps the Minister ought to be addressing more attention to this point. One of the other interesting items in the last Budget was the amount of money to be spent for the upgrading of the Launceston airport. We have just heard about Darwin being the gateway to the north of Australia; Launceston airport is the gateway to Tasmania. It relies heavily on its tourist traffic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which airport is that?
—Launceston. Honourable members might be aware also that Launceston airport is the third largest air freight terminal in this nation.
—Launceston?

—Launceston. The budgetary allocation for work in the Launceston airport upgrading was $80,000. On 7 October the regional director for Victoria and Tasmania announced a further $350,000 to be allocated to the Launceston airport for upgrading of the runways.
—Your pressure achieved that?

—Undoubtedly so. That announcement was made in an unorthodox manner. I have written to the Minister and I am still waiting for his reply to confirm that those funds will be applied, because we are very concerned with what are called alligator cracks in the runway. If those cracks are left unattended concrete pieces or bits of pavement can be injected into jet engines. That can be a safety concern, and I know that the Department of Aviation is very concerned with safety. The simple fact remains that the Launceston airport still requires some $2m to be spent on the upgrading of the runway. This estimate was made by the Department of Housing and Construction, from which the Department of Aviation seeks engineering advice. I would like to know from the Minister when this will be done, because our community has an airport action committee which has been crying out for attention for some two years. We are now finding that the Minister is finally agreeing with us, but he is doing it in such a way as not to admit that he was wrong and is letting his departmental advisers carry the can for him. I do not think that that is a very good situation at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Independent Air Fares Committee. The estimates show an allocation of $60,000 for the purchase of a new computer. I find this interesting because also in the allocation for that Committee are consultancy fees. Given that the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation is inquiring into the two airline agreement and the whole of the airline industry-the Independent Air Fares Committee could be vitally affected by its outcome-I would have thought that an allocation of $60,000 for a computer at this stage would be unnecessary. I would like to hear some explanation as to why it is necessary for that money to be expended at this stage. I note that the cost allocation review conducted by the Committee was done by consultants. Surely, the need for computer services could also be contracted out.

Some comment was made about the two-airline agreement by the shadow spokesman. Launceston and Tasmania are suffering at the moment from the cold shoulder that the Minister is applying to East-West Airlines. Whilst this is not the time to talk at length about that, I will say to the Minister that Tasmanians are very concerned about his neglect of their need to be able to have other operators operating on trunk routes, whether they be providing trunk route services or special services which would be possible under the provisions of the two-airline agreement.

Reference is also made on page 72 of the explanatory notes to compensation and legal expenses, which in 1985-86 is $1,850,000. It is interesting to note in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) that the total for all departments for compensation and legal expenses is $64.5m; a massive amount of money. I did not have the opportu- nity to speak on the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department, but that is an exceptionally large amount which deserves some closer scrutiny. Page 76 refers to the air fare subsidies paid for western Queensland having been cut out. Of course, the air fare subsidies to Tasmania, which were just short of $6m, have been cut out also. The question may be asked: Why is it that this Government hates Tasmania so much?

Page 58 shows that the item for incidental and other expenditure is up by 14.1 per cent to almost $2.5m. Public relations expenses amount to $240,000 and it is stated, in brackets, that this is for a film unit. I wonder why this is necessary. I thought that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism was in charge of all of these sorts of things. Why is it necessary for the Department of Aviation to have a film unit? Another interesting item is the occupational health and safety item, which last year was $10,000 and this year is $100,000. There is no explanation as to why that is so. The item that really caught my attention was the $35,000 for chaplaincy services. I know that the Department from time to time may need some terrestrial activity or support and I know that when Dick Smith spoke to us last week there was some concern that the Department might need some guidance from on high, but can the Minister explain why it is that $35,000 is allocated for chaplaincy services?

Page 49 shows the allocation for meteorological services to be almost $16m. It is proposed by the Department to cut back the meteorological services in Hobart and Launceston within a four year period, so there will be no meteorological interpretation services anywhere in Tasmania. I find this totally unacceptable, and I have been waiting for the Minister to give me details of exactly what is happening. I am aware that meetings were held recently. Some community interest considerations ought to be looked at before that decision is made final. I hope that the Minister will give consideration to making details known to us tonight as to exactly what is happening.

I note that the Qantas Airways Ltd dividend has gone up from just under $7m to $20m this year, which is laudable. I wonder why the Qantas dividend flows through the accounts of the Department of Aviation. I would have thought that that would be inappropriate and in some senses is inflating the Department of Aviation's accounts to a degree that it ought not to be.

Some comment ought to be made quickly about the Tasmanian freight compensation scheme. Of course, we are pleased that that scheme has been approved by Mr Justice Everett and put into place. I have some examples which I do not have time to cover now, but the Minister said that he thought that this scheme would be good because it would allow medium to small operators to continue. However, I have two examples, which I might have another opportunity to enlarge upon, of where it is clearly shown, especially in the case of producers of onions and the residents of Flinders Island, that people are suffering under the changes. I have also written to the Minister about that matter, on which I should like some explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later this month in Canberra there will be a forum dealing with the problems that we face in our national infrastructure. It has been claimed by the organisers of the forum that total government investment in infrastructure has dropped from 27 per cent to 21 per cent over the past 15 years. Of course, Labor governments have been in power for only 5 1/2 of those 15 years-indeed, 5 1/2 of the last 35 years-and even those opposite will not quibble with my assertion that the Whitlam Government was not miserly when it came to urban and regional development and infrastructure in general, and it can be clearly demonstrated that the Hawke Labor Government has also been doing its share to redevelop our infrastructure. Therefore, if we face a backlog in our national infrastructure-and we do-it is very easy to demonstrate where the cause and fault lie. They lie clearly with the Liberal Party and the National Party, which held power, as distinct from government, for about 30 of the past 35 years. I raise this issue tonight in this debate because sea, land and air transport are major components of our national infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), has done a very fine job in the portfolio since March 1983, a mere 31 months ago. I say that in very sincere appreciation of his role and his tenacity and commitment to Australian transport. We can see the fruits of that commitment in the Australian land transport program. The ALTP is a major component of the budget of the Department of Transport, and so it should be. Roads and railways are vital to our economy, whether it be in the development of internal and external trade, communication, or even defence. They are also vital in employment development. As in all infrastructure areas, the employment multiplier in roads is usually ignored by the small government dries sitting opposite. For every $1m spent on roads, it is estimated that 50 jobs are created directly or indirectly. That is a fairly sizable number in view of the amount that we spend on transport.

An efficient and extensive road transport system provides construction and maintenance jobs, jobs in materials and machinery industries, jobs in towns and jobs in other areas such as tourism, fuel, communications, and the automobile industry. About $1 in every $7 spent in this country is in some way spent on transport. This Government's transport program is a key generator of jobs in our economy. In a couple of weeks time we shall see this Government having created half a million jobs since its election to office. That is a very proud record. But when the dries and the big noises in big business and the two-bob capitalists complain about government spending, they always manage to forget that their extreme wealth and their industries depend upon expenditure in areas such as transport and roads, and especially in the industries that I have just mentioned.

Let us look at road programs under this Budget and, for comparison, in earlier years. The major change this year has been the introduction of the ALTP. There are very significant differences between the ALTP and road funding under the old Roads Grants Act. The ALTP is a very comprehensive road and rail program which will integrate land surface transport in Australia for the first time in our 200 years. That is something to think about. In particular, one important factor is that it guarantees an earmarked share of fuel excise to road funding. The ALTP excise will be paid into a trust fund. This program of funding is guaranteed as a minimum for five years, and, on top of that, the program's budget is and will be linked to the consumer price index. There is the guarantee to municipal councils and State governments in this Australian Labor Party Government's commitment and determination to rebuild our land transport system. It is a very gutsy step which former Liberal-National Party governments would never take. In fact, they backed away from it continually.

This program really hits the ball fairly and squarely into the court of the States and local government, to back up their words with similar action and similar funds. The ALTP will give councils and State governments the confidence that they have long sought to plan, to borrow and to invest in order to do their share of transport funding. While we are talking about State governments doing their share, I think it is about time that those State governments which come to Canberra every year demanding money started to take some of the hard economic and fiscal decisions themselves, such as this Government has had to do.

The Australian Labor Party Government would like to bring in surplus or zero sum Bud- gets, but we realise only too well that in winding back and repairing the economic ineptitude of the Budget barbarians of the former Liberal-National Party Government, we cannot further compound the damage already done to our road transport system and infrastructure. It is about time that the State governments, some more so than others, got their acts together and accepted the hard decisions that the Australian Labor Party Government has had to make. It is about time they spent all the money that is appropriated to them in any one year. There is no excuse for not spending road funds in Australia. Yet some State and municipal governments cannot organise themselves sufficiently to do so. Then they turn around and complain when they do not get every dollar they ask for. State and municipal governments have revenue raising powers of their own, yet they continue to complain that Canberra does not give them enough money. They expect the Federal Government to raise taxes and revenue and commit itself to a responsible deficit, yet clearly they are not prepared either to go into deficit themselves or to raise their own taxes and charges. In other words, if the other two spheres of government want to be treated as equals, as they deserve to be, they will have to be prepared to accept the odium that often goes with it.

In the seven years of Liberal-National Party government, road funding was cut in real terms by 23 per cent, while the motorist was progressively bled at the petrol bowser. Some honest members of the Opposition will now acknowledge that in many rural areas especially, bitumen roads were ripped up and returned to gravel roads during the latter years of the Fraser Government because bitumen roads could not be maintained to a safe standard because of a lack of funds. That is further evidence of the Budget barbarians. This Government is not in the business of bitumen band-aids. We are determined to tackle the road and transport infrastructure problems as reconstructive surgery. We are doing the job properly and State and municipal governments should have the grace to admit it.

State politicians claim record amounts of funding for roads but forget to mention that a record $805m was provided this year under the ALTP by this Government. When they protest about not having enough money under the ALTP, they conveniently forget the $23m increase in Australian bicentennial road development funding from $417m in 1984-85 to $440m in 1985-86. Therefore, in 1985-86 the Federal Government will provide $1,245m to the States and Territories for the building and maintenance of roads. This is a record high in dollar terms and returns us to the 1977 level. Almost half of this funding has been directed towards the construction and maintenance of the 16,000-kilometre national highway system which links all mainland capitals. It links Darwin to Adelaide, Brisbane to Cairns and Burnie to Hobart.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes through my electorate.

—It is a good electorate and it has a good member serving it. By 1988, the Australian Government will have spent over $5 billion-not $5m-to bring the national highway system to a high quality all-weather standard. The 1985-86 road budget is 82 per cent more than was provided in the last full year of the Fraser Government. In Victoria, for example, from 1981-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government, to 1985-86, total funding for the national road system has increased by 81 per cent. For arterial roads the figure is even better; it has increased by 102 per cent. For local roads it has increased by 60 per cent. That makes an overall increase of 84 per cent in only four years. That does not include the great increases for road safety and transport research in this period. The charge is often levelled at the Federal Government that so many billions of dollars are collected in fuel levies and excises and so little is returned, especially to States such as New South Wales and Victoria which are the most populous. It is true that as the most populous States Victoria and New South Wales contribute more revenue in most ways than less populous States. It is reasonable and generally recognised by Victoria and New South Wales that this cannot lead to a dollar for dollar return. I close by saying that if life and government were so simple, and if we expected to get that full return, we would not need Ministers and government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the bicentennial road development grants program. However, first I say that the speech by the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), who has just resumed his seat, was most insulting as far as my State is concerned. From the position of receiving an unjust allocation of road funds, South Australia has fought to get justice in that allocation for a great number of years. The allocation we are considering tonight does nothing to justify the bias in funding against South Australia. It is insulting to say to my State that we have not done our part in providing funds for South Australian roads. In fact, work on national highways in prior years has proceeded solely from South Australian funds, so deficient have Federal funds been to build national highways in my State.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member who has just resumed his seat and who used such florid language in praising the allocation of the funds we are considering tonight that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has indicated that this year these funds have been reduced substantially compared with last year. In the introductory remarks of the document I have before me, which provides information on funds for the Department of Transport in the Budget, the Minister says that gross outlays in 1985-86, including recoverable expenditure, will be $1,463.5m. In overall terms this is a decrease of $135.3m, or 8.5 per cent, on expenditure in 1984-85.

On other occasions the Government and this Minister have been pleased to point to the economic factors indicating an increase in economic activity. Yet, the Minister comes to this House and says, as he did earlier in May as he says in this confirmatory document, that the allocation is down significantly by 8.5 per cent at a time when inflation is running at about the reverse of that figure. So, in real terms, one is talking about a reduction in the road program of something like 17 per cent. Yet the honourable member has the audacity to refer to previous figures and indicate that this is something of an advantage to Australia.

It is significant to refer to taxation on petroleum in Australia. The figures I have been given show that in the last financial year $4,202m was collected from the crude oil levy. This year it is estimated that $4,368m will be collected from the crude oil levy. The amount collected from the excise on fuel last year was $2,207m. This year it is expected to be $2,343m. One finds that the percentage allocation to the program this year, involving $1,463m from the total collection of the crude oil levy and excise on fuel of $6,711m, is 21.8 per cent. This represents a return to the users of roads in this community of 21.8 per cent.

Last year, when expenditure on the program was $135m greater, the sum collected was $6,409m and the percentage allocated for this purpose was 24.9 per cent. Based on those percentage collections from excises, which perhaps the Minister might like to think of as more finite to the purpose of a reallocation of excise, one finds that this year there is an allocation of 62.4 per cent of excise on petroleum products, whereas last year there was a 72.4 per cent allocation. So there has been a very significant reduction in relation to capacity.

The Minister may argue that the South Australian allocation has to bear the economic pruning which the Government went through in this exercise earlier in the year. But why does it have to bear such an inordinately large share of that pruning? Why cannot it take its ordinary share along with other expenditures in the community? Why should transport be expendable in this way? I referred earlier to the bad deal South Australia gets-the very raw deal indeed-under the bicentennial program. On a previous occasion in this Chamber I said that the bicentennial program was entered into with a great deal of patriotism, and that on our 200th birthday we would see in Australia a refurbished road system-a system we could be proud of, which would be an economic base and that we would have something substantial to show for our 200th birthday. I have always agreed vehemently with that concept. It was a program that was put in place by the former coalition Government. In regard to my State inherently we had a bad allocation of funds-a bias against my State.

I reiterate the figures which I have upgraded for tonight's short debate. South Australia had 8.7 per cent of the Australian population as at December last year. We get 8.6 per cent of the distribution of the ordinary road grants, and I suppose one could say that at least that has a relationship to something in our South Australian community's population. Although I would argue on historical and developmental grounds that it ought to be greater, at least one can say that there is that connection. But when one comes to the allocation of bicentennial road funds, one finds that South Australia gets 7.2 per cent. Now, however, there is a more significant figure with which to compare that, and that is the fuel consumption in South Australia is just in excess of 9 per cent of Australia's fuel consumption. Although the collection from South Australia is made on 9 per cent of Australia's fuel, we in South Australia get back 7.2 per cent. Therefore, simply in relation to population, 7.2 per cent allocation to 8.7 per cent of population, we shall lose $37m over the entire program, but in relation to what we provide we lose just under $50m.

I put it to the Committee that, under the Commonwealth Grants Commission consideration and adjudication in Australia, South Australia is not considered to be one of the strongest economic communities in Australia. This is why we get the subventions we do under the financial assistance grants. There is no earthly reason why the State of South Australia should be subject to this continued deprivation of its rightful return in relation to the collection of excise in South Australia on a 2 per cent basis on every litre of fuel used.

There is one major aspect that is absent from Government programs, and that is its refusal to take up the policy of the coalition parties, which were previously put clearly in government, to build the Alice Springs-Northern Territory rail line. This is a project which must proceed, and should have proceeded long ago, on the basis of the promise made to my State when the Northern Territory became an Australian Territory-a promise which was made then in the early years soon after Federation. But it is a promise that should be fulfilled now not simply because of the promise to South Australia but because of the promise to the Australian people to defend its interests and to defend our northern perimeters.

Recently an expert study has been conducted by the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre at the Australian National University which gives cogent and overwhelming reasons as to why this project should be proceeded with. It says quite clearly in its findings that the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, on which this Government negated its obligations to the Northern Territory and to the defence of Australia in building that line, did not take into account a proper appreciation of the defence needs of this country. We have a denial on three points-first, the defence needs; secondly, the failure of that inquiry to deal with the fiscal drawbacks that would have come out of the construction of that railway; and, thirdly, it accepted, as the study showed, an inordinately low figure for road maintenance costs which it uses as a comparative figure. Therefore, I say in my brief remarks that under this Labor Government South Australia continues to be disadvantaged. The Bannon Government subserviently accepts that low-grade position, and South Australia is simply subsidising the other States of Australia in this program by something like $50m, and it ought not to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable members who participated in the debate this evening for their contributions and I apologise to the Committee for my absence earlier on urgent matters pertaining to my responsibilities. The concluding words of the last speaker, the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), highlight the dissension within the Opposition ranks. Here this evening he was saying that we should be spending a billion dollars on a railway that cannot possibly fund itself, while the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is hectoring us on spending less. It does not do the honourable member for Boothby or his Party any service to be posturing on that issue when they had years and years to construct that project had they thought it was one of merit. They did not, and that is the reason they did not proceed with it themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that there is no point in trying to debase the Hill Independent Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory. It showed that the construction of that line would be a major misallocation of resources. It is a fact that the defence implications were taken into account on advice of the Minister for Defence. That advice still stands. The bottom line is this: If it is a project that is going to be as remunerative as some quarters of the Opposition suggest, certainly under its policy of privatisation it is a project that the private sector will want to build. This Government will not participate in the absurdity being put forward by the honourable member for Boothby. It does not warrant public investment.

Let us again put it in perspective. We are told that from South Australia's viewpoint there is a major steel production involvement. The amount of steel to be used in the project would be equivalent to 2.5 per cent of one year's production at Whyalla. It will do a lot for Whyalla! It will do very little, but it will cost the taxpayer an enormous amount. Most of the employees involved in the construction would be from the Northern Territory. The service would be provided, were construction of it to be commenced, several years later than the date of completion of the national highway link between Adelaide and Darwin. With the proposal being followed by this Government, the South Australian economy will have access to the Northern Territory and to the Top End markets earlier than it would under the project which is the subject of the posturing from some sectors of the Opposition.

I have heard before from the honourable member for Boothby that speech of his about road shares, road relativities and the amount of money being given to South Australia for roads. I think that was about edition No. 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —You take no notice though.

—I take no notice of it because the honourable member's colleagues took no notice of it. He had seven years to convince members of his own Government that there was some substance in that assertion and they did not believe him. Surely he does not expect me now to believe him when his colleagues did not believe him. Another point is that the existing system of relativities between the States for distribution of road funds, as I understand it, was last determined under the honourable member's Government in 1977. We are just continuing the shares that his Government determined, but looking to the future. Currently four of the six States believe that they should get a greater share of Federal road funds. None of the States is offering to take a lesser share of the existing road funds. The only way through that is for us to set up-we are in the process of selecting people for it now-an independent review of State road relativities for the sharing of road funds. Honourable members will recall that in the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act there is provision for the making of a determination arising from the review before March 1987. To try to relate the collection of fuel levies and fuel excises to the actual distribution of road funds to a State is a nonsense. It does not work out that way, and the honourable member is well aware of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn quickly to the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the matter he raised of chaplain services expenditure. The amount of $35,000 is in line with an agreement reached with the various capital city airport management committees that the Department assist in the provision of chaplain services. Their services are recognised as important to the welfare of employees of all aviation industry groups at airports. That service is being provided as an essential humanitarian service. I hope the honourable member is not suggesting that the service be withdrawn.

The other matter he raised was in respect of Launceston Airport and the expenditure of $330,000 on the maintenance upgrading of the strip. He did ask me about this matter personally. He drew my attention to the $80,000 announcement I had made earlier. I am pleased to tell him that the $330,000 incorporates the $80,000 and arises from the undertaking I had given on several previous occasions. That undertaking was that there would be regular inspections of the runway and if maintenance was required that maintenance would be carried out. We are doing exactly that. Later inspections have shown that additional maintenance is required. That work will be undertaken in furtherance of the promise I gave and will be carried out before the end of the year.

The honourable member for Bass also raised the matter of business concessions, whether they are investigated regularly and whether there has been a loss in revenue. They are investigated on a regular basis. The honourable member will be aware that, with the coming development of the Federal Airports Corporation and the much higher emphasis on commerciality in the management of airports, certainly that area will be looked at again more closely to try to ensure that, in line with government policy, we put greater emphasis upon passenger service, passenger convenience and maximising the quality of service that we provide to the travelling public. Within that comes the provision of commercial services and the opportunity to ensure that airports are managed in a commercial fashion, that the return to taxpayers is maximised and the best value for money is obtained for taxpayers.

The other matter he mentioned was in respect of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. I say to him that that new scheme is the result of a comprehensive, exhaustive and impartial inquiry carried out over the course of many months. The scheme is now in operation. There will be a review of the rates of assistance before 1 July next year, in time for next year's Budget, to see how the system is working and what the effect of changes in the freight rates will be. But separately from that I have also established a review authority as a means by which appeals against some provisions of the scheme can be examined. That is also under way. He also mentioned the matter of the Bureau of Meteorology services. I will deal with that matter in writing.

I turn quickly to the matters raised by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). He said that Federal Government funding is required for the new road linking the southern highlands to Port Kembla. The honourable member has been assiduous in his representations on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about us? Don't we ever write to you?

—When does the honourable member stop writing to me? Does he ever stop writing to me? The problem is that the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), says this Government must reduce expenditure. When he says `reduce expenditure' he means reduce road expenditure as he did when he was Treasurer. Honourable members should remember that when he was Treasurer Federal road expenditure was reduced by more than half a billion dollars. That was the performance of the present Leader of the Opposition. We are not going to have a bar of that, not a bar of it. We have reversed that. We now have a massive increase in Federal expenditure, the greatest road construction and road building program ever seen in the history of this nation. We are not going to be thwarted by the claims of the Leader of the Opposition. All I can say to my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Throsby is that I am very much aware of the needs of that region of the State and of the electorate he refers to, but he knows that that road is an arterial road. We do not have power to initiate expenditure in respect of that road. That road is an arterial road for Federal funding purposes and if it is placed on the schedule for consideration of approvals by the New South Wales Minister it will get prompt consideration. We do not have the power to initiate projects for arterial roads under our Federal funding arrangements. It is an important road and there is trouble with it. I am very much aware of the conditions to which the honourable member refers.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) referred to my answer to a question in the House this afternoon in respect of the Board of Qantas Airways Ltd. That matter is under consideration. It is obvious once again that the left hand of the Opposition is not talking to the right hand because the information he accused me of not providing was provided by one of his colleagues in the Senate earlier today. I do not propose to say any more about it at this stage, regardless of the interjections.

The roads expenditure of $1,245m was mentioned by the honourable member for Murray who complains that it is not a record. I cannot count for him, but $1,245m is more than $1,242m. Beyond that I cannot say any more. The amount being spent by this Government is the greatest in history and roads will continue to be a major priority of this Government. If the honourable member wishes to join with the Leader of the Opposition in his campaign to reduce road expenditure, he can go ahead and do so. He will get absolute opposition from every organisation in this country that sees roads as a priority and he will also get opposition from his own colleagues in the National Party of Australia because they keep writing me letters and asking me to spend more on roads. In the interests of road expenditure in this country, I suggest, with the best will in the world, that he sit down with the Leader of the Opposition and reach agreement to support expenditure on roads. I also suggest that he ask him to cease his campaign for cuts in expenditure on roads. If the honourable member will do that I will have something very complimentary to say about him, but if he does not I hope he will not come in here whingeing to me about what has not been done for roads. We are giving roads top priority and they will stay that way. The other matter that was raised by the honourable member for Murray was that of Darwin airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Burke and Wills Highway?

—Well, ask the honourable member for Murray about the Burke and Wills Highway. He is a National Party member, so why not ask him? Why ask me? Why did he not ask his own shadow Minister? There is no point in asking me about the Opposition's responsibilities. All I can tell the honourable member is that he had a National Party Minister who was responsible for roads for year after year and all the problems that we now have with roads are his responsibility. Honourable members can thank the Opposition. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) is one of the guilty men. Honourable members can thank him for the situation. Honourable members should call a special meeting of the National Party--

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman: I take great exception to the Minister pointing at a member of this Chamber. He should speak through the Chair. While I am on my feet I might add that it was I, as a member of the National Party, who introduced the bicentennial road program.
-Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Gwydir will resume his seat. The Committee will come to order. The debate is now in the winding-up stage.

—I am winding up, Mr Deputy Chairman. I believe that roads are one of the most important priorities in the transport system of this country. I wish that the National Party members of the Opposition would call a special meeting at which they could sit down together and work out a considered concord. It is very difficult when I have to meet councils and tell them the priority for roads and admit that back in the Parliament the National and Liberal parties want to cut expenditure, including expenditure on roads.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. That is an untrue statement. We have not made any such statement. All we have said is that the Minister is not being accurate in his statement that this is the highest expenditure ever on roads. In real terms it is a reduction in expenditure.
—The honour- able member for Murray knows that that is not a point of order.

—The honourable member for Murray has said publicly that the policies of the Opposition are those that were put in the 1984 election campaign and that they will continue until there is a revision. That policy provided for the abolition of specific purpose Federal funding for arterial roads and local roads. No amount of points of order or denials will get away from that fact. We will not have a bar of that policy. We will continue with the program we have under way-the greatest program ever seen in this country to improve our roads system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Darwin Airport matter is proceeding. It is under consideration and review, as I have said.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the railway line?

—I would be interested to hear the Leader of the Opposition express his support for the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. To date he has not supported it but when he does it will be a very interesting situation. I again remind honourable members that it is no good their appealing to me in this way because I know that they are not telling me the truth. The Leader of the Opposition says that the real policy is to cut expenditure, so I suggest that honourable members sort it out.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter that I want to mention was raised by the honourable member for Murray. It was in respect of East-West Airlines Ltd and the answers I gave to questions he asked a few weeks ago. Those answers were accurate. If he wishes to continue to believe some of the misinformation provided to him, that is his option; but the answers that were provided were accurate. They stand. Subsequent to the answer being given in respect of East-West's application to import a fifth F28 aircraft, the information East-West was asked to provide on 26 July has been provided. It is now being assessed and the matter is under consideration. That is the position. The answer I gave then is correct.

I commend honourable members for their participation in this debate. I reiterate that under this Government we have seen the greatest improvements in national transport services since Federation. That improvement will continue and transport will continue to be a major priority of this Government.
