SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At first glance the figures for primary industry look quite good but on closer analysis we come to the conclusion that the Hawke Labor Government has continued to discriminate against farmers and their families. When we deduct the $104.6m rebate of wheat growers' levies-I will explain that; it is the repayment of moneys that should have been repaid to wheat growers last year-we find that primary industry outlays amount overall to only $338m, which is 26 per cent less in dollar terms than the figure for 1974-75, 26 per cent less than it was 10 years ago. When one compares that with increases over the same period of 414 per cent for social welfare, 560 per cent for labour and employment and 658 per cent for public debt interest repayments, one can see that government policies are contributing to the great decline of farm incomes and farm welfare and the ability of farmers generally to withstand the enormous crash for so many of our commodities that has occurred on world markets.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the really critical things that this Government did was hold up last year the repayment of $104.6m that was owing to the wheat growers-it was their money-to reduce its Budget deficit for presentational purposes. It did that despite the heavy indebtedness of wheat growers. They were funds on which interest could well have been earned and saved. Against that background, some 130 farms which were surveyed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics showed an average debt load at the end of June 1984-over 12 months ago-of $53,700 per farm business. The average wheat farm business owed over $91,000 at the end of June 1984, and the situation would be far worse today. Western Australian wheat growers, on average, are in debt for about $147,000.

The Wheat Finance Fund repayments could have been made much earlier, but the Government chose to bleed the wheat growers to solve some of its budgetary problems. When we exclude the repayment of those levies, the total outlays to rural industries are up by a token $12.2m, or 3.8 per cent. However, the total Federal outlays for this financial year will rise by $5.33 billion, or 8.4 per cent. Outlays to manufacturing are up by 33.1 per cent. Mining outlays are up by 26.5 per cent, but for agriculture they will go up by just 3.8 per cent-about half the rate of inflation.

On any analysis, there is a case for positive discrimination in favour of the rural industries. All Australians benefit from the export earnings of our farmers, which represent between 40 and 50 per cent of our total export income. Never has there been a time when Australia has needed more exports or foreign exchange to help overcome some of its balance of payments problems and the problems of meeting the interest repayments on a gross foreign debt of about $70 billion.

No sector of the economy receives less effective assistance from the Government; yet time and again our farmers are squeezed. The latest tax package discriminates against them and small business people more than it discriminates against anyone else. The current level of net farm income is totally inadequate to service the $6 billion of accumulated debt resulting largely from the extended drought, government financial management and low world prices. Farmers are being slugged with the highest real interest rates in the Western world. These rates bear no relationship to world trends. Last month the commercial banks' prime rate stood at 18.5 per cent in Australia. When we add on the loan administration costs and all other costs, it would have been 20 per cent. The prime rate stood at 12.5 per cent in the United Kingdom, 9.5 per cent in the United States of America, 10 per cent in Canada, 7.5 per cent in West Germany, Holland and Switzerland, and 5.5 per cent in Japan. How on earth can the farmers and the small business sector of this country continue to compete on world markets with a burden of that magnitude?

I see two main reasons why interest rates are out of kilter with the world economy. First, the Hawke Government's Budget deficits and monetary policies are forcing up interest rates and thus attracting foreign capital-much of it for speculative purposes-and easing some of the pressures on the balance of payments deficit. This latest cunning Government strategy is propping up the dollar, which has been so badly undermined by flagging world confidence due to a number of factors including this Government's crazy wages policy. Secondly, the prices and incomes accord is preventing adequate discounting of wages and salaries despite the falling exchange rate and our falling production of wealth.

Our whole system today is being propped up by borrowings. Our children are going to pay an enormous price. We sit here in a great deal of comfort because we happen to have inherited a golden opportunity from our fathers and grandfathers. But what sort of legacy will we leave our children? We will leave them debt, and a lot of it.

Wage increases forming part of the increase in gross domestic product are giving an artificial boost to the national measure of economic growth. Australia's poor overall trading performance, mining and agriculture excluded, and the increasing balance of trade deficit mean that our fully indexed wage increases are not being funded by net increases in real wealth. They are being funded by increased borrowings, both here and abroad. Nobody can deny that. So, to put it in simple terms, we are living on our children's future. It will be our young who will have to pay for our wanton undisciplined greed. The only solution will be a massive increase in export earnings and the production of our farms and mines offer the best hope, especially our farms.

I see that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) is in the chamber. I know that he has fought a courageous battle for high technology. I know that the Department of Trade had all sorts of great schemes to try to encourage this development. However, the danger in that approach, of course, is that such development would take place at the expense of those established industries that have the capacity, so long as the macro-economics are right, to increase export earnings. There is a case for discrimination in favour of agriculture. Instead, it is being discriminated against. We are heaping intolerable interest rate pressures onto a highly capital intensive sector with returns to capital of less than 2 per cent.

The agricultural industries cannot be expected to cope with Labor's anti-rural discrimination. I do not particularly blame the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I think he is doing his best. I do not know that he has fought as hard as he could have. But he is fighting against an attitude. There has been an accumulated ripoff from farmers of $442m in three Budgets. Too many Budgets have introduced savage anti-farmer tax changes, creating an adverse macro-economic environment for farmers. The main feature of the appropriations to agriculture and the pastoral industries is the degree to which the industries fund their own research and development programs. The wool industry has gained enormous benefit from its 8 per cent contribution of gross returns to the market support research promotion and floor price schemes. I must say that I think the Minister has endeavoured to focus attention on this important area of research and promotion. I give him full marks for it because these activities are absolutely fundamental to the long term future of our agricultural industries.

Other industries are commendably raising their input to such research programs but this should be not only to their benefit but also to the benefit of Australians generally as these industries are largely export oriented. I am sorry that there is no provision in these estimates for the sugar industry. I hope that the Minister will succeed next week in his negotiations with the industry and the Queensland Government and at least reach some agreement in order to try to help that industry through a very difficult time. I also hope that he will succeed in getting agreement with the dairy industry in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks in this debate to the appropriations of the Department of Primary Industry. In recent months the nation has witnessed an almost unprecedented upsurge of militancy among farmers. It began in Victoria among dairy farmers and, as honourable members would be very much aware, spread to other centres including Canberra. I do not think anyone would deny that very serious problems are affecting the primary sector. In fact, it would be correct to say that there are more uncertainties facing farmers today than at any time since the Great Depression. Those uncertainties are multiple in character and they relate to markets, foreign country pricing policies, internal cost pressures, climatic conditions, overproduction and a lack of price flexibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that in Australia at any time there is a drought. In fact, my own area around Ballarat is drying out very quickly. The situation is becoming quite desperate in areas of the Mallee to the north-west. All these factors are recognised and they generate a great deal of frustration and anger. They have also led farmers to look for scapegoats rather than the underlying causes. Because of this, they have chosen a convenient scapegoat in the Government. It is unfortunate that many of their leaders who have their own political agendas, namely party political at that, have grasped the opportunity to divert the attention of farmers from the real problems and direct their energies towards attacks upon the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin).

It is not long ago that farmers were proclaiming this Minister for Primary Industry as the most effective Minister for Primary Industry in memory. What has changed? Certainly not the Minister. He is working just as hard and just as effectively as he has ever done. He is striving to help the various commodity areas to become more market conscious and cost effective. He knows the story of cost pressures and he also knows that measures that are aimed at short term goals will not help the industry in the long term. The growth in demand for short term palliatives rather than the development of procedures for ensuring long term stability in the industry is of little assistance to that industry.

I suppose that short term palliatives and ad hoc decisions have characterised the response of previous governments to problems facing primary industry. Today we are witnessing the result. Some commodity areas are just not prepared to deal with the extremely difficult circumstances that they are facing. This is particularly evident where unfair market pressures from the European Economic Community and the United States of America are felt. For so long the conservative governments of this country have failed to grasp the significance of the realities of our geo-political position to economic development in this country. They stood flat-footed instead of taking aggressive action to develop new markets in the Asian region. Therefore, while we have some markets in that region they should have been far more developed than they are.

No one in this country should be unaware of the marketing problems facing Australian farmers. Our farmers are further hard pressed by the policies of the EEC and the United States of America because of the domestic market disparities. The EEC has a domestic market of 300 million people and the United States has a domestic market of 240 million. Australia has a domestic market of only 15 1/2 million, yet our production potential far outstrips Australia's capacity to absorb any further significant output. This places the Australian farmer in most sectors at a serious disadvantage because he has become export dependent, whereas the European farmer is more protected by the domestic markets and, of course, the iniquitous production subsidies that result in the dumping of residual produce. Honourable members would know that this has most seriously affected the markets of smaller nations as well as those in the Third World.

Australia's farmers, as producers, have no peers in the world. They are generally ready to adapt to new and improved technology, new crop varieties and improved farming methods, but they suffer from the problems that I have outlined. They also suffer from a number of other cost-producing factors. In recent years, there have been high levels of world production in a number of commodity areas, such as dairy products and sugar. This world glut has added to the downward pressure on prices. So while farmers face cost increases, they face also a decline in real terms in returns. Between 1983-84 and 1984-85 the decline was 17 per cent in real terms. To be sure, this was not evenly distributed but it has been affecting all sectors. This year, it will be higher.

Many farmers have found that their farms have become too small for an economic return and they have been faced with the further problem of having to increase their capital investment requiring long term borrowing. Others have had the added burden of short term borrowing just to keep going. In recent days, it has become clear that the pressure of debt repayments has become too great for a number of these farmers. The prospect of failure and bankruptcy is looming for many farmers. These are critical issues facing our farmers. Solutions are just not in sight and they will not be easy to find.

The Government believes that primary industry can be assisted in a number of ways. It believes that the farm sector must be seen to be an integral part of the Australian economy. This must be a prima facie position. Unless this is done, it will result in a distortion in the relationship between the various sectors of the economy-a greater distortion than that which exists. In many respects, this is what has happened over the years. In some instances, this has tended to assist primary industry in the short term only because the benefits have receded over time as measures taken in an ad hoc fashion by previous governments have tended to work against the interest of primary industry.

It must also be stated that primary industry has tended to suffer from the action taken by other industries. The legacy of this lack of economic planning is distortion, inertia and resistance to structural change in the industry. The Government had to try to get the economy moving and this it has done very effectively. At the same time, both in the context of interest peculiar to primary industry and interests derived from the inter-relationship of all sectors of the economy, the Government has aimed at ensuring that each sector has a future. As the Minister has said, the costs to farmers are crippling. This is largely because farmers are price takers and not price makers. Other sectors are able to pass on the effects of rising costs through rising prices, but farmers cannot do that. The Government has taken certain action to help farmers cut their costs. Honourable members will be aware of the return of the full rebate on the diesel fuel excise for fuel used for primary production and also the replacement of tariffs on wheat harvesters with a bounty.

The Minister also announced an increase of $10.2m for rural industry research, bringing the total to $68.6m, and the government contribution for wool promotion has been increased to $29.6m, an increase of $3.6m. The reduction in meat inspection costs to farmers because of cost absorption and new inspection arrangements will total $24m for 1985-86. The Government has also recognised that part of the problem facing primary industry has been overproduction and in many cases non-viable farms; so the Government has provided $16.83m for rural adjustment and an extra $6m for the dried fruits and wine grape industries and the northern prawn fishery.

The Government is concerned to ensure that we gain maximum opportunity to develop markets. For this reason an agricultural attache is to be appointed to Tokyo, a particularly important region for the development of markets. The Government has also decided to take certain budgetary measures for new forward projecting programs and to increase funding for existing measures now. The allocation of $40,000 for the study of agriculture to the year 2000 is one such measure. I want to indicate what the Minister has said about this measure, for it bears out what I have said about the Government's long term commitment to primary industry. He said:

The Report will assess major issues and their implications for the development of Australia's rural sector and canvass appropriate policy responses by Government and industry. The production of the Report will be instrumental in providing a longer term perspective within which to frame future agricultural policy.

Likewise he has established a Rural and Provincial Affairs Unit within the Department of Primary Industry in recognition of the fact that outside the metropolitan area problems exist that do not have parallels in the metropolitan area and that issues that affect the nation are manifested in different ways outside the cities. This unit will provide information for government consideration of the broad range of issues affecting Australians living outside the capital cities.

The national soil conservation program is to be increased by $652,000, to $4,652,000 in 1985-86. This is a far cry from the lack of interest shown by our predecessors. While saying that, I cannot help but suggest that those who are using farmers for their own party political purposes, and they include those who organise the various marches and demonstrations, ought to recognise that the farmers are hardly well served by the Opposition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no marches in Queensland.

—That is true. Not only that, but also there is little evidence that they would help farmers in the difficult times that lie ahead. I want to make it quite clear that this Government is firmly committed to the interests of primary industry. It has to be because primary industry is such an important sector of Australian life and it contributes such a major component of our import revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another Budget and Appropriation Bill that consider it expedient to reward those who contribute little real wealth to Austalia's export income and penalises those still involved in productive activities. The principle of reward for effort has just taken another beating. With this Budget and Appropriation Bill the Government has pushed the cake firmly in the direction of the city and city based industries and away from the country and rural based industries. Since March 1983 the Labor Government's policies have shifted. One can argue about the figure; I think our spokesman for primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), suggested some $442m. If we want a quantitative figure, some $648m has been taken away from the rural sector, the rural areas, of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We must realise that our export industries form the basis of our standard of living. Last year agricultural and mining exports contributed 75.2 per cent of our total export earnings, and this legislation is the reward they have had from this Government. It is not good enough for a government to allow services, allowances and infrastructure to be reduced in the highly productive rural and mining areas of Australia. I am not against reductions, but these reductions have been made to our primary producers at a critical period in our export markets. If it were not for the fact that the value of the Australian dollar has fallen by over 20 per cent on a trade weighted basis, the Government would have seen much more than peaceful rallies outside Parliament House. We all know that devaluation has been essential to maintain our competitiveness on export markets, but that competitiveness does not show up too well with the release of the trade deficit for the month of September, which was recorded at something like $216m, up $122m from August; nor does the Budget Papers projection of a trade deficit of something like $10 billion plus for the year give us much comfort.

The occurrence of the devaluation is nothing of which the Government should be proud. If it had managed to improve the cost effectiveness of its own infrastructure, reduce the overall level of spending, reduce assistance to favoured secondary industries, and reform the wage fixing system, devaluation would never have reached these levels. Despite the immediate benefits of devaluation, farmers and primary producers are now feeling the delayed impact reflected in rising farm costs. Devaluation has been a double-edged sword. It gives with one hand and takes away with the other. It should never have been used as an excuse for not addressing the real costs this Government has allowed to be put on to the average farmer. The reduction of input costs for our farmers is crucial in maintaining our export markets.

It is against this background of the Government's negative priority for rural matters that I want to explore the changing export outlook for Australia's produce. The damage that the European Economic Community and the United States of America are doing to world markets and themselves, through their internal agricultural policies, is common knowledge. We have specifically felt the impact on our sugar, wheat, dairy and meat industries. Both the EEC and the USA are up to their necks in farming subsidies and they are finding it very difficult politically to reverse that direction. It is estimated that this year the United States Government will spend the staggering figure of $20 billion on subsidies, price support and other agricultural programs. The EEC spends around $55.5 billion all up on its farmers. The average effective rate of protection for a wide range of agricultural products in the EEC is almost 160 per cent. In comparison, at the height of the recent drought crisis, the effective rate of support for Australia's agricultural products was 16 per cent.

Subsidisation has the effect of unrealistically maintaining land values by isolating the farmer against market prices. The EEC and the US have unwittingly promoted inefficiencies and overproduction. If this Government had slightly more foresight it would realise that its recent tax package will create the same circumstances in Australia that have led the US and the EEC down the path of subsidisation. The Government will force the farming community into an intolerable situation. When the predictable occurs these measures will structurally change capital investment throughout Australia. As private investment dries up in rural Australia, so will the ability of our farmers to remain viable. Against this background, the Appropriation Bills we are debating tonight must be seen in the context of the proposed changes in the taxation system. All hounourable members appreciate that about 23 per cent of Australian farmers require off-farm income to sustain their farming enterprises. Most other sections of business can offset income ensuring that unprofitable business may be supported by profitable business in the same group of companies.

In the past, we have benefited from the enthusiasm and long term economic view of the so-called Pitt Street farmers. I assure honourable members that we owe much of the excellence of the Western Australian wine industry to this very group, which has had the financial resources to develop long term farming enterprises. At the same time, it has provided an influx of funds to rural areas. It is also important that we consider the cost of farm labour. Since 1972, when the then Prime Minister Gough Whitlam declared that the Government should be a model employer, the Government has generally paid a higher wage than private enterprise could afford. To redress this imbalance private enterprise has generally offered fringe benefits to employees. To tax these fringe benefits at the employer level will place an impossible burden on business and farmers to maintain their employee's remuneration packages. It will have little effect on government as the employers will adjust their accounting practices accordingly.

As an example, the Western Australian State award for a farm worker with a trade certificate is $240.70 per week, based on a six-day week. If the farmer did not provide a house and subsidised food and petrol how would he attract workers? The farmer cannot pay any more. His average net weekly earnings are only about $135 per week. In what sort of predicament do these arbitrary changes to the status quo place the farmer? It is important in this debate that we understand what motivates a farmer in trying to improve his situation. Traditionally, an individual might start work on a farm, become a share farmer or dealer in rural produce, purchase a small farm, upgrade it and sell it to purchase another farm and so on until a viable property has been purchased.

At one stroke this Government has stopped this method of becoming a farmer. It has destroyed incentive at each turn, and the attitude which ferments new ideas and creates new business opportunities will wither under its new capital gains tax. All these changes work in the opposite direction to what is needed if our farm exports are to remain competitive during the difficult times ahead. During the shake-out between the European Economic Community and the United States, Australian farmers will suffer unless their input costs are substantially reduced. The United States again has recently developed, as we all know, a special export enhancement scheme as a direct consequence of the EEC's common agricultural policy. Middle Eastern countries, such as Algeria and Egypt, will derive much of the benefit of this scheme. About a third of our wheat exports go to the Middle East. We are quite vulnerable in this type of confrontation between those two great trading groups.

The significant conclusion which can be arrived at from all this is that it is in Australia's interest to demonstrate to the EEC that we can develop policies which are less costly. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has undertaken a study of the effect of the common agricultural policy on some key indicators within the EEC. The policy has the effect of lowering wages, reducing manufacturing exports and, in net terms, contributing to unemployment. The United States is experiencing similar problems although its political system will ensure that the reality of its policies are faced much sooner. From all accounts, a bumper crop has been predicted by the United States Government, which will result in lower commodity prices.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join this debate and to have a few words to say about the importance of the primary industry sector in this Budget. I begin by making my contribution in terms of the reactions from certain sections of the community, both before and after the Budget was delivered. The Four Corners program which went to air the night before the Budget featured an interesting debate between the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) facing a group of farmers. During that program the reporter asked Mr Ian McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation, what the Budget must contain in order to satsify the needs of the rural sector. Mr McLachlan said:

SPEECH.PARA: The budget must get rid of some taxes on fuel and here I'd like to reiterate that we're not interested in a subsidy because the removal of the tax by no definition amounts to the subsidy and some tariffs and taxes on agricultural chemicals and on agricultural equipment.
He went on to make a comment about the fact that he would be absolutely horrified if the Government were able to sneak a capital gains tax into this Budget, and concluded by saying:
. . . quite frankly, all we would like to see from the budget is to get rid of some of the impositions on us.

I will turn to the capital gains tax in a moment. I refer to the key points mentioned by Mr McLachlan, representing the farming sector, and the responses to them in the Budget. First of all, honourable members would be aware that the Budget provided for a full rebate for the diesel fuel excise for fuel used in primary production, which is an extra saving to producers of about $35m for a full year and reduces the price by about 2.4 cents a litre. The tariff on imported harvesters was replaced with a bounty, at a cost to the Government of $14m a year. I might add that the tariff was put on by the previous Government. The Government is awaiting a report, to be delivered in February, from the Industries Assistance Commission on chemicals and plastics, which is likely to lead to a reduction in the price of agricultural chemicals through the removal of tariffs on imported agro-chemicals. So the farmers have been given another year's reprieve from the threat to remove fertiliser subsidies-contrary to the interim findings of the IAC-at a cost of $55.6m in 1985-86.

The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) mentioned capital gains taxation. I do not pretend for one moment that there is a great enthusiasm in the bush for the imposition of capital gains taxation, but I put to the House that by and large the reaction in the bush has been somewhat muted to the decision of the Government as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House. In fact, some of the reaction, particularly from some of the more conservative elements in this House, can be described quite fairly as selective indignation. The tax was indeed modest and it applied from a prospective level only, rather than retrospectively. The real concern in rural Australia was with retrospectivity on capital taxation. If honourable members talk to farmers within their electorates, they will find that that is the issue about which they were really concerned.

One of the more important initiatives announced in the Budget was that the Government had initiated moves aimed at marketing Australia's primary products in a more effective manner. There is a $7m program for the meat and livestock industry to encourage the use of objective meat export trade descriptions, longer term export market studies and national reports on product descriptions. There is a $3.6m increase in the Government's contribution overall to the wool industry, taking that level of promotion to $29.6m. Outlays on rural industry research funding, as mentioned by my colleague the honour- able member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), were up significantly by $10.2m to $68.6m.

I refer briefly to some of the editorial responses to the Budget after it was delivered in this House on 19 August. The comment was made in the Australian Financial Review of 21 August that the Government has increased its overall assistance to the farming sector by 37 per cent, or $116m, and spending on specific assistance programs for farmers has almost doubled under the Budget, making the farmers the most assisted sector of the economy. No one in this Government is trying to pretend that that is not an important area which needs help because it is a very important aspect of our overall economy. As so many people here have commented, the importance of the agricultural sector to Australia's national wealth is certainly not disputed in any way. While assistance given to farmers grew by 37 per cent, total industry assistance funding increased by only 5 per cent. I think that indicates some level of support by this Government for the rural sector.

Some other comments were made in various editorials throughout the nation following the Budget. The schemes to market and promote Australia's meat and wool will attempt to arrest the downward trend in prices that farmers receive. Everyone is aware of the tremendous cost-price squeeze that exists in the rural sector. But, again, this is nothing new for the agricultural sector. Ten or 20 years ago people were concerned about farm costs and the relatively small income that was coming off the farm. I remind honourable members, in contrasting farm costs under this Government with those under the previous Government, that whilst under the Fraser Government between 1976 and 1983 farm costs rose, on average, by about 10 or 11 per cent, under this Government those costs have been severely restricted and the rise is down to 6 per cent. Yet some of the comments we hear from the other side of the chamber indicate that those opposite are certainly not prepared to acknowledge this support.

The Minister for Primary Industry gave a rather interesting speech to the National Press Club a week after the Budget. I think it is worth while reflecting on some of the points that he made. These points have often been overlooked by the political opponents of this Government and people who, for one reason or another, refuse to acknowledge the Government's positive contribution to primary industry. The Minister said that the 1985-86 Budget is good news for three main reasons. The first reason that he gave was that it sets the right macro-economic policy to encourage growth and minimise costs, including farm costs. We cannot have it both ways. There has been a tremendous call in the community for the Government to reduce the size of its spending. Yet, on the other hand, as soon as any attempts are made to reduce government spending in a responsible way there is immediate criticism, because every single industry and interest group can put up a special case as to why it should be quarantined from such a restriction.

The second reason that the Minister gave concerned the provision of a set of initiatives designed to help those primary industries most squeezed by reduced returns. The Government has made some very genuine attempts to assist some industries in Australia that are in absolutely dire straits. The sugar industry is one significant industry that is in a tremendous amount of trouble at present, yet we have seen up north the political opportunism of the Queensland Premier in playing cheap politics with the lives of sugar farmers in that area, thereby jeopardising any genuine assistance that can be provided to those people.

The third reason that the Minister gave was that the Budget continues the Government's institutional reforms and support for the basic resources needed for farming. This is a fact that is certainly not disputed in any way. This Government's decision to float the Australian dollar was an important one. The fact that during 1984-85 it meant something like an extra $500m to the farm sector is very often neglected in some of the comments that are made by farm leaders throughout the community. It seems to me in light of some of the criticism that is made of the Budget by members of the agrarian socialist party who occupy the benches opposite, and indeed by some of the farmer leaders in Australia, that their memories are indeed short. They are not prepared to give credit where credit is due and to be selectively indignant about any reasonable decisions that are made by this Government in response to the genuine problems facing primary industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Committee debate is on the appropriations for the Department of Trade, the Department of Resources and Energy and the Department of Primary Industry. I want tonight to focus my remarks on the appropriations for the Department of Primary Industry. Before doing so, I turn briefly to the Department of Resources and Energy. I remind the House that on 7 May 1985 I placed on notice question No. 934, which still remains unanswered and which was aimed at getting some information out of the Government about the direction it was taking on the question of resources and energy, particularly in the area of water resources. I asked the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, which water resources projects had been initiated in 1984-85. I asked for some details about them and then I asked which water resource projects were in progress in 1984-85 and I sought some information about those projects. That question, as I said, remains unanswered, and it remains unanswered, I suggest, largely because in the area of resources and energy-particularly in the area of water resources-there has been not just too little action, but no action from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Some community employment program projects have been directed to the area of water resources. The Forward Estimates from the 1984-85 Budget to the 1987-88 Budget reflect a fall in the money allocated for water resource projects. The fall would be even more rapid if the figures were considered in real terms and some allowance was made for information. I remind the House that when Senate Estimates Committee E was considering the estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick asked Mr Manderson, with regard to the River Murray Commission:
Could we have some brief indication of the nature of the works involved? If this cannot be done verbally, a written statement would suffice.
Mr Manderson said:
The main item-
the main item, if you please-
involves remedial work at Hume Dam and the installation of a post-tensioning system . . . estimated to cost $11.1m.
A little later Senator Sir John Carrick asked:
And the remainder of the estimate?
Mr Manderson said:
The remainder of the estimates for capital works refer to the replacement of cranes used in the operation of the Commission's locks and weirs.

I am not underrating the importance of that replacement work. I merely make the point that in the area of resources and energy, far from there being new projects, we have projects which involve nothing more than the replacement of existing facilities. The Government cannot afford to pretend that the good water that is currently available to the majority of Australians as the result of a series of good seasons will continue. Unless this series of good seasons is used to equip us for the sad inevitability of a coming drought, we will be even less able to survive the next dry spell than we were the disastrous drought of 1982-83.

I turn to the Department of Primary Industry. Much has been made tonight of the beleaguered state of Australia's primary producers. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has already eloquently revealed the fact that the average debt on a wheat farm is $90,000. I make the point that that debt has been accumulated not by a wheat farmer who was keen to be acquisitive-as would be portrayed by Government members-but by a wheat farmer who was forced to go into debt in order to survive. The other point that has been made by the honourable member for Gwydir and the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) is that no one receives less from the Government than farmers, the rural people of Australia. I reinforce that point by quoting the mouth of the President of the National Farmers Federation-that the farmers of Australia would be prepared to forgo even the little that they receive from this Government if they could be relieved of the enormous burden they carry on behalf of the rest of Australia in the form of tariffs and our centralised wage fixing system and in the form of the in-built costs that they cannot escape. I invite honourable members to find another group which is prepared to forgo what the Government offers. The members of this group have made that offer, if they could be relieved of the burden they carry on behalf of the rest of Australia.

I gladly concede to the Minister for Primary Industry that it is difficult to be precise when referring to the figures for the primary industry allocation because, as we all realise, the allocation under the Primary Industry portfolio is a complex one. I want to use the figures that Senator Walsh used when he was addressing the Senate Estimates Committee. Senator Walsh said--

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be right.

—I am pleased that the Minister sees these as accurate figures. Senator Walsh said that the Department of Primary Industry's expenditure for this year would be $765.3m, but on the figures that he gave, levies paid by farmers will earn the industry $455.4m and the export inspection charge will generate a further $121.9m, making the effective appropriation $213.3m. Does the House realise that the clients-those who receive the services of the DPI-pay 72 per cent of its expenditure? What other group in Australia picks up that proportion of the cost of the service given it? More than that, this group picks it up on top of the tax burden that its members already pay as citizens of the Commonwealth. Those people, of course, are not the so-called filthy rich. In fact, in 1985 both the ratio of prices received to prices paid and the real value of prices received by farmers in the Australian community will be the lowest since 1965.
—Since when?

—Since 1965. In spite of that, they are picking up this enormous proportion of the allocation that the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) have made so much of this evening. In the brief time I have tonight I turn to what is a mystery to me-the Export Inspection Service. The Budget Papers reveal that in 1982-83 the Export Inspection Service cost $67.9m to administer. In 1985-86 it will cost $102.5m, an increase of 50 per cent in four years. Of that Export Inspection Service, 90 per cent is for meat inspection. Over that period in which the cost of export inspection has risen by 50 per cent, the amount of meat exported has decreased by one third. The Minister may well say that there are complications there because the States administer some of the funds, and I accept that, but the point is that that cost is still being borne 50 per cent by the farmers of Australia and the other 50 per cent by taxpayers, many of whom, of course, are farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: When he was in Opposition, the Minister rightly demanded, and got, prompt action to the meat subsitution scandal. The action was decisive in order for the Parliament to protect the overseas image of Australia's primary producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't do the same at Mudginberri.

—Today we face a dithering approach to, as the honourable member for Wannon has said, the disastrous Mudginberri dispute, the ongoing dispute of meat inspectors, wharf stoppages, airport stoppages, and now the threat of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union to reclaim the fines which it has been ordered to pay by the court. In fact, the AMIEU is treating those court fines with contempt and emulating that BLF character, Norm Gallagher.

SPEECH.PARA: As recently as this week on the question of meat inspection charges Mr Bill Bodman, Acting President of the Cattle Council of Australia, urged the Minister to stand firm. Mr Bodman said:

The producers, who pay 50 percent of the cost of operating the Export Inspection Service will not have a bar of paying one cent to those inspectors for the period during which they refused to obey the Minister's directions.

The honourable member for Calare has made much of the fact that this Budget was an appropriation for farmers. Too little has been made of the simple uncomfortable truth that farm income has fallen by 22 per cent, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, on the estimates for the Departments of Trade, Resources and Energy and Primary Industry, has revealed many of the very important weaknesses in the effective administration of these departments, and of the important roles that they play, by the present Government. I want to devote just a few moments to the trade aspect. It has such severe implications for our economy, our prospects in terms of realisations on the important products that we must market overseas, and the consequential effect on primary producers and other sections of the community-not the least being manufacturing industry-flowing right back to the whole gamut of employment and the virtual structure of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) seems to have been, since his appointment to that office, almost obscure in that role. In fact, there have been fewer statements, there has been less activity, and undoubtedly there has been less interest on the part of the Minister in his important role as Minister for Trade than in other activities. One finds him making statements on education and on youth affairs as though this was the dominant part of his responsibility-and this in the face of the disastrous figures we find in respect of our terms of trade. Figures just released show us that the long awaited turn-around in Australia's trade performance expected from devaluation of the dollar has again failed to materialise. The September figures show a balance of trade deficit of $216m-an increase of $122m on the previous month's figure. What does this reflect? The figures tell us that there is a fall of 7 per cent in imports, and that it is offset by an 11 per cent drop in exports. Seasonally adjusted, exports fell by 7 per cent while imports actually increased by 3 per cent. This spells disaster, a disaster of the kind that this country just cannot face.

It is urgent and imperative that the Minister for Trade and the Government take a stronger role and that they recognise that passing the buck from one Minister to another is just not good enough. In primary industry matters concerning important trade issues, we find that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is the front runner, and yet it is not his direct responsibility. The responsibility of the Minister for Trade is to be out there leading in terms of the negotiations and the day-to-day activities that are necessary to promote the trade of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you think he is now?

—That interjection is very interesting, because the Minister for Trade has devoted less time to the task that he is undertaking now than any of his predecessors in the last two or three decades. It is lamentable that we just do not get responses from the Minister, in terms of statements in this House, public statements or anything else that adequately equip us for what we are observing at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just take for a moment the consequences of this. We now owe about $70 billion, and that figure looks like soaring to $103 billion by 1988. Of course, the cost of servicing that debt is enormous. It is soaking up about a third of all our export earnings, and taking away any prospects of a growth factor in response to our trading success as it reflects back into the overall economy. Interest payments gobble up the combined export earnings from coal, non-ferrous metals, iron ore and so on. But when we think of the contribution that primary industry makes to our export earnings, it is clear, of course, that it is in that area in particular that a greater effort is required.

I turn to what is occurring in respect of the European Economic Community. I believe that the Minister for Trade accompanied the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industry on their last mission to Brussels; but there was no real initiative, no positive action and no response on his return to this country. In fact, in the main the response was left to the Minister for Primary Industry. Apparently he is expected to shoulder a dual role and, in the process, he is expected to try to explain away the lack of success in promoting exports in all of the fields that are so vital and important. The remarks by those who have spoken this evening reflect very clearly the fall not only in the level of exports themselves but also in the actual financial return. This is not good enough if we are to maintain a growth factor in this country, which is imperative if we are to avoid real disaster in the months ahead, and certainly in the next two or three years, in the face of the economic climate that we see on the horizon.

It is important for another reason. Perhaps the Minister for Primary Industry is engaging in some of the responsibilities in this field at the moment, but I refer to the battle that is coming up in terms of the EEC and the United States of America on what has been announced by the United States on the very vexed question of the trade problems that confront countries such as Australia and the United States regarding the realisation of important primary industry products and so many of the vital areas that concern us. I refer to the sugar, beef, dairy produce and the fat lamb industries and the smaller industries which are of great consequence to those engaged in them. Unless we see a turnaround in the attitude that is being adopted by the present Government in this respect there is no doubt at all that we will face very serious consequences.

There is one matter that is very pertinent in this respect and I believe it is relevant in terms of the debate tonight. I refer to what is nothing short of abdication of responsibility by the Minister. But let us look at another aspect. If we are to promote trade it must be done by those who are equipped to do the job. Just a few months ago the Minister for Trade announced the appointment of David Combe as Trade Commissioner in Vancouver. The Press release stated:

Mr Dawkins said that the Trade Commissioner Service needed people with good promotional and representational skills such as Mr Combe possesses. The Government reached the conclusion that Mr Combe's widely recognised talents and experience would be an asset and that he should not be barred from such an appointment for reasons that have been the subject of public inquiry and have been satisfactorily dealt with.

I have no dispute with the fact that that was the outcome of the inquiry, but what I do take issue with is the fact that this appointment was made at a crucial time in the promotion of our Trade Commissioner Service around the world. It impinges upon the important aspects of recognition of that Trade Commissioner Service. I believe that it was a very unwise appointment, a very inappropriate appointment, at that time and remains so. If we have lack of confidence in the Trade Commissioner Service, it means that along the line there is lack of confidence in Australia's export effort.

I conclude by saying that our responsibility in trade is second to none, yet we find this very poor record in the last six or nine months as far as the Government is concerned. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industry, who I suppose is the only hope on the horizon, will have some influence in persuading his colleague to shoulder more of the responsibility. Certainly, it is lamentable to find the situation which exists today in this very important field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the Australian water resources program. It concerns me that more Commonwealth expenditure is not going towards this important developmental area. Not long ago the report of the Department of Resources and Energy entitled `Water 2000' envisaged a program that would take water development in Australia to the year 2000 and beyond. It appears from the estimates we are discussing that there is no possibility we will complete that program and be able to incorporate the new works that it is so necessary to undertake in Australia. Only this morning I read the 1983-84 report of the Australian Water Resources Council, which indicated that the only works that could possibly be completed before the turn of the century were the works that are presently being undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has a very important role to play so far as water resources are concerned. Under the Constitution, the States have certain resources and the administration available to carry out not only development works but also maintenance works, that is, works relating to water resources and the application of water on the farm and in other ways. The Commonwealth has the funds and the ability to encourage the undertaking of national schemes. Referring to the Burdekin Dam and other national schemes, I am delighted to see that $20m is being allocated for water resources in that area. However, under the estimates before the House not a penny is allocated for urban and domestic water and sewerage works.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—For urban works, domestic works. I might be wrong and, if I am, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) may be able to point out where. It is important for the sake of primary industry that we continue to have a very virile water resources program. Our continent is particularly dry; we are subject to droughts and floods. I believe that the great bulk of Australian people want to see more of their taxpayers' money go into productive works that are for the benefit of the nation. Too much of our funds is being diverted from important development issues to non-productive works and schemes. I could mention various departments, but because of the time factor I will not do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Government. When we were on the treasury bench I do not believe that we measured up to our responsibility in regard to water resources. It is essential that these works be undertaken. I know that environmental questions are asked about them. That is natural, and I agree with it. There are people who say that, because of environmental factors, water resources works should not be undertaken, that they might be a waste of taxpayers' money. But for the economic development and growth of this country it is essential that more national development works be undertaken and that we give the States every possible support. If there had been a natural economist on the Endeavour when Captain Cook came to Australia, this country would never have been founded. We cannot afford to adopt that attitude. We must continue with practical water resources schemes.

That is the background to the measure that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) and others have spoken about this evening. Primary industry will make demands. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics maintains that by the turn of the century there will be a need for 25 per cent more water conservation in Australia to meet the demands of agriculture. At our present rate of water resources growth, only 8 per cent or 9 per cent more water conservation will be available. We do not want to see a diversion of the resources we have from one essential form of agriculture to another important form of agriculture; so this issue becomes very important.

I was very disappointed, as I am sure was every honourable member on this side of the House, that our bicentennial national water resources program, which envisaged an expenditure of $640m, has been scrapped by the Labor Government. Where would one find a better way to celebrate the Bicentenary of Australia than by spending it on water?

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am pleased that the honourable member for Charlton agrees with me, because it affects his area in regard to not only the agricultural scene but also the domestic supply of water. A few years ago the Commonwealth said that it would assist the States with domestic supplies and sewerage. We talk about privatisation. In the United States of America one finds large water resource schemes being carried out by private enterprise.
—Where?

—California. One sees them there and in other parts of America. There people and companies are induced to come into the agricultural area to develop water schemes themselves and to sell water. If a government cannot carry out these schemes in an advancing and developing country like Australia, why can we not have the foresight to attract other people to develop the water resources of this nation? The trouble is that Labor members think too much of other socialised issues that will not assist the productivity of this great country. In common with the honourable member for Wakefield, I want to stress the great importance of water resources to Australia. Water is like blood in one's body. If we do not have the water, we will not be able to meet our commitments to agriculture in the decades ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly on estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy, I want to relate the sphere of interest of that Department to the major change in basic economic strategy in Australia that has occurred in the last two years. It was discussed recently in the journal Syntec. In the latter 1970s a strategy for development and growth in the 1980s was constructed based on investment in commodity mining and processing. The rising price of oil would lift the value of Australia's abundant supply of oil substitutes, especially coal and natural gas. The prices of the commodities that we exported would grow faster than the prices of imports, so a steady improvement in our terms of trade and increasing real incomes could be confidently anticipated. On this basis the country could run for a period larger and larger current account deficits associated with maximising borrowing from abroad, both for the new development projects as such and for the infrastructure-roads, power, harbours and so on-necessary to support them. The cost of such borrowing would be more than met in the accelerating export returns that would accrue from the array of developments.

SPEECH.PARA: It was this, the so-called resources investment boom, which provided the main thrust to development, the engine of growth in the economy under the previous Government. I submit that it was a very effective one-until in 1982 the onset of world recession and the deepening drought in this country, as well as the significant wage push of 1981-82, brought on the deep recession of 1982-83.

What I want to draw the attention of the Chamber to is the fact that from the date of accession of the Fraser Government at the end of 1975 to the cyclical peak in economic activity around September 1981 the number of jobs generated in the economy was upwards of 530,000. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief table prepared by the Parliamentary Library that sets out these figures.
