TALK.START.PARA: —The process of this growth in jobs was a bit slow over the years from 1976 to 1979, when the primary task of the Fraser Government was to bend the economy back into shape after the destructive Whitlam years. Thereafter, it accelerated and, as is clearly seen from the figures, over that period of the Fraser Government from its inception to the cyclical peak around September 1981, some 530,000 jobs were generated in the economy-and the unemployment rate at that latter time was 5.6 per cent compared with the unemployment rate of 8 per cent today.
—What was the period ?

—The table has been incorporated. The honourable member can take his time and have a look at it. Turning to the Hawke Government, the same table shows that the increase in jobs from March 1983 to September 1985, which includes the recent surge, is in the order of 470,000. That is, of course-and I think this is the point that the honourable member was making-a much shorter period. On the other hand, the Hawke Government benefited from riding the `bounce-back' from the 1982 recession following the breaking of the drought and had the advantage, especially in respect of getting inflation down, of the Fraser Government's wages pause, as well as sharing in the upswing in the world's business cycle.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I want to stress this point. The frequent taunting of the Opposition by Government members to the effect that the Hawke Government has created, to use their quaint phrase, more jobs since 1983 than the Fraser Government generated in its tenure of office has no basis in fact, as will be seen from these figures, and, indeed, is false and misleading. As I have said, up to that cyclical peak towards the end of 1981, and largely over the two to two-and-a-half years preceding that, there was generated under the Fraser Government upwards of 530,000 jobs. That figure is comparable with what is now happening. Of course, the economy this time has not so far attained its cyclical peak, but I suggest that may not be too far off. So I say to Government members opposite that I will certainly join them and cheer when, and if, the resilient Australian economy generates 500,000 jobs since the Government took office. But I warn Government members that there will surely be a cyclical peak. The resources development strategy that I have referred to has run foul of a secular slow-down in commodity prices, stemming from the effective world market adjustment, largely unanticipated, to the high oil price and the threat, indeed, at the moment of an oil slump with all its ramifications for other commodities, and from the marked slow-down in inflation in the world's dominant economy, the United States.

As an alternative strategy, the Hawke Government appears to have opted for a devaluation-led process of `efficient import substitution', as the respected journal Syntec put it. My fear is that, with this Government's policies resulting in costs and prices in Australia rising well ahead of those of our major trading partners, that strategy will not be sustainable through 1986. At some time, maybe sooner than later, economic activity will peak and so unhappily will the employment gains. In summary, with resources development as the main engine of economic growth, and following a period of repairing the damage done to the economy during the Whitlam years, employment-the number of jobs generated-increased under the Fraser Government by upwards of 530,000 to the cyclical peak in about September 1981. Under the Hawke Government employment has risen by in excess of 450,000 jobs, assisted by the good start given by the Fraser Government's wages pause and the breaking of the drought, and, as I have pointed out, with a changed or changing engine of growth. The cyclical peak has not yet been reached, but I warn the Government that, with its policies, that is not too far down the track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable members who have addressed these various estimates. Most of the members spoke about the primary industry portfolio, a few spoke about trade and others on resources and energy. Most speakers tonight focused on some of the concerns and protests of the rural community, but not much was put forward by way of new solutions. We were interested to hear the reading of Syntec by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). He referred to economic history and cyclical peaks. It followed the Opposition's general theme of doom and gloom.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of new solutions in the farm sector, I am not very much attracted to some of the themes in the honourable members' speeches which reflect some idea of a nostalgic revival. Whatever government is in power, the main thing that any government can do for the farm sector-I must keep emphasising it-is to get the economy right and to make Australians more internationally competitive.

While I can appreciate the fact that people are putting pressure on this Government to get the economy right more quickly and that there is an urgency about it, by and large we are doing very well. Part of the reason the farmers are so upset at the agro-political level is that they cannot really quite handle a Labor government that is giving non-inflationary economic growth. Jobs are being created; we are holding inflation down roughly to about five per cent or six per cent; the floating of the dollar has made this country face economic reality such as nothing else has; we are cutting the deficit; we are getting the profit share up; and in terms of our tax on the rorts and the taxation system, we are fundamentally changing the direction of investment in this economy towards more and more productive areas. For example, we have got the deficit down to about 2.1 per cent of gross domestic product. It was about five per cent. This is a record drop this year of about $1.8 billion. The prices and incomes accord is giving us a decent wage situation. One anticipates a wage increase at the next hearing of about 3.8 per cent and at the next hearing an increase of about 2.8 per cent.

That is a lot better than some of the people opposite, the gloom and doom merchants, would endorse. The United Kingdom has squeezed out a 7.5 per cent wage increase with the monetarism of Mrs Thatcher. It has an inflation rate of about 13 per cent. In the United States of America also, conservative economics-really populist economics-is being practised. Against other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, on all those measures, we are doing well economically, even on interest rates. I will get on to that matter in a moment. We are doing everything possible to provide the climate for getting the economy right for stimulating international competitiveness.

There are problems with trade, interest rates and the balance of payments. I will get on to those matters in a moment. I will address very quickly the comments made by honourable members opposite particularly because everything that was said from my side of the chamber was pretty sensible. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the Deputy Leader of the National Party, said that the figures are down. All I can say is that it is nearly impossible to get comparability one year to the next in the primary industry portfolio. Figures go in and out. For example, in the last Budget there was still a carry-over of the moneys being pumped into the rural sector for the two drought subsidy schemes-one on fodder and the other on interest. That has now gone out of the Budget estimates this year and that is why the figure is down. There are quite a few items like that with programs that are ending, so one can never get strict comparability. In terms of the additional money we are spending, the other day in Townsville the Cabinet agreed to providing money for the sugar industry. Hopefully, that money will be spent in this year if we can get the Queensland National Party or the industry up there to agree to ways and means of getting the money. Part of what the honourable member was saying was, in a way, that there should be more subsidies, but I do not think that was exactly his intention. I do not think that anyone sees any point in getting into the business of competitive subsidisation when one is up against estimates of subsidisation of anything up to $40 billion in the United States and up to $60 billion in the European Economic Community. As he said, the emphasis must really be in other areas.

Other areas that are causing problems at present for the farm sector are fuel costs and interest rates. We know that; but in terms of the economic measures we have in force, some of the problems are unavoidable and in other areas we are taking action so that there is compensation. On fuel cost increases, in terms of the import parity pricing policy and its interaction with the floating of the dollar, there was effectively a more than sufficient offset for the increase in the fuel price in the May period.

It is also pretty important for us to analyse the situation so that we can find new solutions and thus proceed in government on a more consistent path, rather than trying to hark back to a more glorious age. I think there is a great need to analyse the problems rather than just simply focusing on them and saying: `Look, there is a lot of debt around; that is necessarily bad'. Debt is not necessarily bad; it does not necessarily reflect the fact that it is all about economic or farm hardship.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like AIDS-it's all right if you do not have it.

—The honourable member would know about AIDS up on the Gold Coast, I suppose. If one looks at the farm sector in terms of indebtedness, one sees that for the sheep only sector of primary industry 33 per cent of that sector has zero debt. Similarly, 41.7 per cent of the beef only sector has zero debt, as have 24 per cent of the sheep-beef sector and 21 per cent of the wheat sector. I will not bore the Chamber with all the figures, but if one goes through the list one finds a very large proportion with little or no debt. For example, in the beef only industry, 57 per cent have zero debt or up to $10,000 debt. There are still significant numbers in the farm sector with no debt. There is also a substantial level of liquid assets. Some figures point out that the farm sector is still a net lender to the rest of the economy. If that is true-and there are figures to substantiate it at present-farmers are actually gaining from higher interest rates. Across the board the debt-capital ratio is about 8 or 9 per cent. From the information we can get from public sources and also from the private sector and banks particularly, we can honestly say that there are sections of the rural sector that are facing particularly difficult financial circumstances, but the situation should not be generalised for the rural sector as a whole. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics calculates that there has been an increase in real terms of rural indebtedness over the period from 30 June 1984 to 30 June 1985 of between 3.8 per cent and 4.8 per cent. That is not particularly large and discussions that we have held with the major trading banks and pastoral houses indicate that the increases are due in part to the buoyant situation in the sheep and beef industries, rather than rural hardship. I just wish to make the point that indebtedness is not necessarily a measure of farm hardship at all.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a lot of emphasis on Australia's external debt and no one is downplaying that. The Commonwealth debt has increased throughout 1985, due mainly again to the devaluation of the Australian dollar. About 60 per cent of that debt is held in Australian dollar terms; therefore the devaluation has effectively put up the debt. There is about $12 billion of Commonwealth debt, but we have official reserve assets far beyond that. The really big increase is in private debt, which has gone from $6.5 billion in 1980 to $42.3 billion in 1985. I am quoting here from Budget Paper No. 1. A lot of that debt is associated with resource projects, such as the North West Shelf project. In other words, it is true investment for return. We need to make some of those qualifications. There is a lot of total public and publicly guaranteed debt in non-monetary enterprises. If one looks at all of these things one sees that part of that is an accumulation of the resources boom that was not, and part of it is associated again with investment by such authorities as water boards and so on. Australian lending overseas amounts to about $2.9 billion. One of the ways we may be able to get out of some of our problems is for there to be more foreign investment and we will be looking at those sorts of questions.

Interest rates are worrying the farm sector at present. Interest rate determination is not simple. A complex set of factors impact on interest rates and these include, typically, the stance of monetary policy, inflationary expectations, the relative balances and supply and demand for funds, the current account deficit on the balance of payments and hence the amount of capital inflow required from overseas, overseas interest rates, adjusted for expected currency movements, and the total flow of funds through the financial institutions. At present we have a tight monetary policy. Inflationary expectations have increased and the current account deficit on the balance of payments has continued to widen. Technically, this is partly due to the J curve effect of the currency depreciation. All these factors have tended to push up interest rates.

The reason I believe we have put in place an economic setting-we are not putting in place negative forces in terms of interest rates-is that the prices and incomes accord will restore inflation to a downward path, 5 to 6 per cent, and inflationary expectations will adjust to this. Hopefully, in time the currency depreciation will narrow the balance of payments deficit and I will refer to that in a moment. The trilogy will reduce, and is reducing, government demand for funds and overseas interest rates will fall as the United States economy adjusts and the United States dollar also falls. So there are positive aspects in terms of interest rates. I accept the fact that there is criticism but I think it reflects urgency and a move to do things quicker. But one simply cannot turn around economies very quickly. I believe the Government is doing a very good job in getting the economy to move.

The honourable member for Gwydir also raised the whole question of export earnings and that is one of the very big problems for this Government, or any government, at this time. The whole problem is that about 80 per cent of our export earnings are in primary commodities, either agricultural or mineral. How we get more dollars for those commodities, given the nature of world markets at present, is the real problem. The honourable member for Gwydir has already conceded that he does not really mean subsidise. We face buyers' markets wherever we go. The industrial nations certainly have the heave and the economic power to make sure that they keep down the price of our mineral exports. Of course, the big industrial countries, the EEC bloc, North America and Japan, also indulge in agricultural subsidisation and protection.

Once most of our pleas, in terms of agricultural products, to the people we sell to, particularly the EEC, were all the time concentrated on access. We have swung around to now trying to identify the policies and principles and the inherent bad policy in agricultural subsidisation. More and more this Government is trying to emphasise the fact that the whole problem of agricultural commodity trade needs to be internationalised. A lot of the effort being made by my colleagues in the Government is about this internationalisation, trying to get agriculture to the top of the agenda in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and on the Multilateral Trade Negotiations round, and there has been a lot of preparation for that.

The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) touched on services. To my mind, he failed to differentiate between the farm sector and the rural sector. He tried to draw a rather artificial division. People are critical of the tax cuts because they have been gained in Liberal Party demonology by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. People ought to realise that the ACTU has gained tax cuts for farmers and people in rural Australia as well and that welfare benefits are not just for people in the city. We are spending record amounts on transport and this is not spent just in the city. We are not using devaluation for an excuse. We are trying to so something about reducing input costs.

I will not go into a great discussion on the recent tax package. I would be happy if the Opposition, rather than focusing on causes for squealing, were to focus occasionally on the principles behind the Government's policies in this regard, because they relate to problems that the Opposition was trying to grapple with. Most of the Opposition's attack so far has been directed at the effect of the package on the restaurant industry rather than the fact that overall in the tax package the Government is trying to get a fairer and more equitable system. We are trying to stop the enormous leakage in the tax system. We are trying to clean out the rorts and the shelters.

I well remember that the Australian newspaper engaged in a great campaign in 1977-78. It invited people to join the tax revolt, and everyone did. That cost us about $4 billion in unpaid taxes. Yesterday Mr Maher was whacked into gaol. On that scheme alone something like $460m was retrieved. That scheme meant that we all paid more tax. When the Government is trying to get rid of tax shelters and trying to do something about these things, some recognition should be given to the fact that tax shelters and the people who can transform income into capital gains so easily and pay no tax are the reason for and the motivation behind the Government's proposals.

We are trying to ensure that people pay less tax and the offset in the tax package is that marginal rates will go down from 60 to 49 per cent, and there are other adjustments. Sometimes honourable members opposite ought to look at the principles. Do they want rorts? Do they want shelters? Do they want people to avoid tax? Do they want the honest people to pay more tax? That is what it is all about? The capital gains tax proposed for the farm sector is extremely prospective. The complete stock of agricultural land and its ownership will be preserved in perpetuity while it remains within a family. Any capital gains incurred after 20 September will take at least two generations to take effect.

I shall address the comments of the honour- able member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). He was talking about resources and energy and the taxation burden on the farm sector. To look at the figures, the income tax paid by the farm sector is not very high compared with the rest of the producing economy. Of course, indirect tax due to the high level of inputs, particularly fuel, in some parts of the farm sector is particularly high. The honourable member for Wakefield also focused on the great Meat Export Inspection Service mystery within the Budget estimates. The reason the allocation is up by 50 per cent is that the Victorian Meat Export Inspection Service is being incorporated. We have saved something like $18m or $22m this year in various ways. Now that we are taking over New South Wales and Victoria the cost of domestic inspection will be borne by consumers rather than by producers.

I will not get on to Mudginberri. The honourable member for Wakefield touched on some of the trade union and industrial relations questions. I simply point out that I have yet to meet a farmer who fully understands the tally system. Often, some of the comments of honourable members opposite indicate that they do not understand it. The tally system in abattoirs applies to the people on the slaughter floor. That system actually saves the abattoirs money inasmuch as after the slaughtermen retire, having killed for the day, the rest of the people in the plant work on afterwards. If the slaughtermen finish early, it means that overtime will not be paid to all those other people. The whole tally system is pretty complicated. For people to think that somehow marvellous things would happen if the tally system in the Northern Territory were wiped out is really just a little misplaced. There needs to be a proper analysis. Two of the export abattoirs, Alice Springs and Sourey, were on contract, and they went broke. About 60 per cent of the cattle in the Northern Territory are normally shipped out. Transport costs up to $60 to $90 a head. The cattle are then slaughtered under the tally system. So it is not quite as simple.

I think there was some reference also about the whole problem of growing transport costs. This problem is focusing more and more in Newcastle where I think that the dispute that took place last year or this year on rosters was pretty deplorable. People ought to focus on the in and out loading capacity of the Newcastle loading facility. They ought to focus on the way ships are handled, the problem of loading inasmuch as the potential cannot be achieved and, more importantly, the co-ordination between the Australian Wheat Board and the New South Wales State Rail Authority is as deplorable as are some of the unions' actions.

The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) got onto the question of trade. I am pleased to relate that my colleague the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) is presently on a journey to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Iraq, the United States of America, Japan and India and he is certainly doing his job very well. I have suddenly discovered that I have a fan in the honourable member for Page. The only discussions that I have been engaged in have been with respect to sugar and beef and they were for reasons of timing and the fact that the then Minister for Trade, the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), was engaged in other trade matters. I am generally the Acting Minister for Trade when the Minister is away. I think we all accept that Primary Industry and Trade should work very closely together at the bureaucratic and ministerial level. We have been promoting major initiatives such as the steel and wool initiative with China, the setting up of the Australian Trade Commission with agricultural trade people in Bahrain, Singapore and Tokyo. These sorts of measures are all helping our general trade effort.

The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) spoke briefly on water resources. He said that we need a lot more water for developmental purposes. In other words, he is saying that we probably need more irrigated agricultural products. I do not think we need any more at present. There certainly is still potential for irrigation in this country with some of the broad acre crops such as cotton and course grains. I think perhaps we need to orientate towards smaller projects. Irrigation does not really solve droughts. We do not want more Ords. While we may need a lot more water by the year 2000 I do not think the allegation can be made that the Government is spending much less on water resource projects than did previous governments. In this year we are spending something like $67.3m compared with $62.7m last year. The major expenditure at present is, of course, on the Burdekin Falls dam project.

Finally, I would like to comment on what the honourable member for Lyne had to say about the former Prime Minister's $640m mad election bribe about water resources. This was one of Malcolm's give-away promises to take back later, like his tax cuts. What we are doing about tax is giving real cuts. That will be part of our efforts in respect of international competitiveness. We are interested in stopping the tax rorts and tax shelters that honourable members opposite would do nothing about. I can quote McCabe, Lafranchi, Costigan and all of the other people. Honourable members opposite did nothing about that. What we are trying to do is to get a more basic and equitable economy. We are trying to get the economy right. We are putting in place the framework that will give us more international competitiveness in all of the areas about which I have just spoken.
