SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which comprise an amount of $272.804m for this financial year. In addition, it is worth pointing out that other departments have further expenditure of some $209m which is covered by two appropriations. It is also significant to point out that the Department, in the introductory page of its explanatory notes, has made this point:

SPEECH.PARA: The amount proposed for departmental administration represents an increase of $0.970m or 3.99 per cent over the amount spent in 1984-85.
I am rather intrigued to note then this statement:
. . . and reflects the continuing effort of the Department to minimise its administrative overheads.

Having increased its overheads, it is rather interesting that the Department should then talk about minimising them. Nevertheless, that is rather pinpricking in terms of the totality of the expenditure for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which is really the subject I wish to address tonight.

The Labor Government was elected for its second term with a policy based upon supporting an Aboriginal policy which promised more funding, national land rights, greater self-determination and, of course, the more obvious but, nevertheless, very important elements such as improved health, accommodation, equality of opportunity and so forth. I think it is worth pointing out, however, that the proposals for expenditure for this financial year are essentially the same as we have seen in place, to a greater or lesser degree, for the last 17 years-in fact, since the Commonwealth assumed direct responsibility for Aborigines as a result of a national referendum, one of those very few referendums which were successful, back in 1967. The point I wish to raise on this occasion is simply that over that period we have spent an absolutely enormous amount of money on Aboriginal assistance-in fact, some $4.5 billion-and we are talking about a population which is no more than 300,000. We do not really know exactly how many Aborigines there are, but it is somewhere between 160,000 and 300,000.

The issue to which all parties have to direct themselves-I emphasise all parties-is that a coherent and comprehensive approach to the problems of Aboriginal welfare must be essentially bipartisan. It is absolutely unacceptable that people within this Parliament or elsewhere should pick on a small number of Australian citizens and somehow take out on their hides the political guile and spleen which has so often been demonstrated in this Parliament. It is a matter of great regret to me that, with the introduction of the Hawke Government on the Australian political scene, the substantial measure of bipartisanship which had previously been in place has passed from us.

On the wider picture there is a very real risk that, if we are to proceed as we have for the last 17 years, simply directing funding at a general range of programs which have not changed very much over that period, we run a major risk of creating, if we have not already created, in the minds of a significant number of Australians who are not Aboriginal the perception of a state within a state; or if I may use a term which I do not mean to be used in any other sense, a form of administrative apartheid, a tendency to try to create a bureaucratic system which covers every facet of the perceived needs of a specific section of the Australian population. We have done this to a large degree. In fact, it could even be argued that the very establishment of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs ensured that that attitude of mind would progress. Over a period, with the normal growth of programs in the best Parkinsonian principle, we have today a substantial number of programs which run the risk of being duplicated not only between the Commonwealth and the States but also between the Commonwealth departments.

An examination of the programs covered in the Department's estimates for this financial year bears out that point very clearly. In the Commonwealth field alone, for example, in addition to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs we have the proposed Aboriginal Housing Authority; Aboriginal Hostels Ltd; the Aboriginal Development Commission; the National Aboriginal Development Committee; the National Aboriginal Education Committee; the National Aboriginal Health Organisation; the secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care; we hope to see in due course, when the Government gets around to it, the new National Aboriginal Conference, as it disbanded the old one; the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Services; and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I assume that the trachoma programs, while they are of tremendous importance, would also be put in that category.

I mentioned initially that in addition to the expenditure of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs we also have further expenditure of some $209m in what I would frankly call parallel State bureaucracies. If we look at expenditure on Aboriginal health, State Departments of Health are involved as well as the Commonwealth Department, the National Aboriginal Health Organisation, the trachoma programs and of course the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We have a similar situation in the field of education, as was pointed out in today's Canberra Times. It referred to the bureaucratic chain around Aboriginal education and to the involvement of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Department of Education, and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Even the National Aboriginal Education Committee believes that the problem plaguing Aboriginal education could be solved by giving the Department of Education sole responsibility for the Commonwealth's financial contribution. So the problem is very real indeed. I think that that was demonstrated more clearly than ever in the report of the Miller Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs tabled in this House quite recently. It noted that the present level of accountability in the area of expenditure of funds for all Aboriginal-type programs was in many cases questionable. It stated that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations of Australia at the moment `remain the most disadvantaged people in Australian society'. The report continued:
. . . a continuation of the present arrangements, even with considerably more financial support, is unlikely to change significantly the economic status of Aboriginal people in the coming decades.

The problem therefore surely is that the continuation of this Labor Government's policy on Aboriginal affairs, such as it is, is based on the belief that that policy must be seen in the context of the effect which white people have had on the Aboriginal population which in turn has resulted in a significant degree of Aboriginal dependency on the remainder of the Australian population. During our earlier time in Papua New Guinea we heard of the cargo cult mentality that built up. I think on the one hand there is a risk that we are trying to establish policies and programs directed at achieving real equality of opportunity-that is not an easy thing to do, and I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) would agree with me on that point-but on the other hand there is a major risk of building up in the minds of many Aboriginal communities the perception that equality of opportunity somehow is going to come from without, that it requires a minimal involvement of those who are at the receiving end of the various expenditure programs.

As I have said, we have to look back on the last 17-odd years and, being absolutely honest with ourselves, admit that irrespective of that vast expenditure of some $4.5 billion on such a small number of people, whatever our good will may have been we have been less than successful. That comment can be applied to both sides of this Parliament. In fact, as the Miller report also noted, a staggering 71 per cent of the total national Aboriginal income is derived from government, and this income is mainly as a result of social welfare payments. It also demonstrated that the level of unemployment among Aboriginal communities is massive compared with any comparative group of Australians in any other element of our society. Consequently in the estimates of expenditure for this financial year we see the Government posturing in many ways. Only some $15.6m, or 16 per cent of Budget moneys allocated to Aborigines, has been allocated to Aboriginal advancement programs in 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the appropriations allocated to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I wish to draw attention to the problems associated with a small but powerful political and criminal element amongst the Indo-Chinese refugees. I first came into contact with the violent activities of these people when representations were made to me several years ago by a man who had been almost knifed to death by three Vietnamese assailants at the Nunawading migrant hostel. The man complained to me because he continued to fear for his life and because he believed that the local police were not investigating the matter seriously. I am glad to say that my own inquiries ascertained that the police were doing their best to identify the attackers but had been impeded in their inquiries because the Vietnamese and Kampuchean migrants who had witnessed the attack had been intimidated and threatened by the assailants and were too cowered and frightened to give evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear that the reason for the vicious attack was that the three Vietnamese migrants concerned were extracting illegal payments from their fellow Indo-Chinese ostensibly for the provision of transport from the hostel to a number of farms where the migrants were working as fruit pickers, and the assailants knew that the man they had attempted to kill was aware of their criminal activities. I am particularly concerned at the fact that by, using the same murderous strong arm tactics that they learnt in the back streets of Saigon, this small minority of thugs are able to intimidate and frighten the majority of the law abiding Indo-Chinese migrant community into abject silence about their illegal activities.

The Department has advised that the number of refugees coming out of Indo-China this year will be about 6,000 and that they are mainly Vietnamese who do not come directly from Vietnam but from Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta. These people are coming to Australia under our refugee and special humanitarian programs, and are keen to come to Australia because it is a country where they are encouraged to live in freedom and express their views without fear of political or physical intimidation. I am concerned that our security arrangements are not sufficiently vigilant in protecting the Indo-Chinese community against criminal and political thugs who are entering Australia posing as potential law abiding citizens.

Having attended a ceremony in Victoria at which a number of Australians, including myself and my wife, were celebrating the 10th anniversary of the ending of the Vietnamese war, I can vouch for the violence of some 100 Vietnamese who attempted to prevent us from leaving the hall at the end of the ceremony. If it had not been for the presence of the Victorian police, we would have been unable to leave the hall in safety. In any event it was quite a frightening experience to have to pass through the barricade of protecting police who were holding back the jeering and gesticulating hate-filled faces of the demonstrators. Nevertheless, none of the previous incidents I have mentioned would have prompted me to make a speech on these matters as I am well aware that there is thuggery in all elements of our Australian society. However, my particular concern is over a Four Corners program which I saw on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television on 5 August. (Quorum formed) I was describing certain parts of a Four Corners program which I saw on ABC television on 5 August. The program described the harassment of Vietnamese Government officials by local Vietnamese who are now living in Canberra. Jeeny Brockie, the commentator, said:

In March this year, another Embassy official was punched while waiting with his Ambassador on the steps of Parliament House in Canberra. There were no arrests. Present at the demonstration at the back of the crowd was this man, Mr Nguyen Huu Chanh. This statement later tendered by the Embassy to Federal police named Mr Chanh, not as the assailant but as one of the instigators.
The program recorded the statement of an unidentified onlooker who said:
I heard distinctly the following abuse and instigating words of Nguyen Huu Chanh: `Let us beat them to death. Son, today is the last day of your life. Either black son or red son you will die'.
Nguyen Huu Chanh then said:
I didn't say anything about killing him there that day, because if it had to be done, then I have many ways to do it. It would not be done as openly, as illegally, as that.
Jenny Brockie told viewers:

In April Mr Chanh attended a demonstration outside the Vietnamese Embassy in Canberra. A tape of the demonstration given to `Four Corners' by the Embassy contains some violent threats. A large contingent of police was on hand to control the crowd which called for the closure of the Embassy. The refugees also wanted the anniversary of the fall of Saigon declared a day of national mourning. One of several speakers then decided to read out the number plates of embassy officials' cars.
Nguyen Huu Chanh said on film:

When I read out these number plates their hearts pound and their balls shrink. When you see those cars smash them up if necessary, burn them if necessary, kill them if necessary. Kill them, exterminate them.
Jenny Brockie said incredulously:
But you're suggesting that people kill other people.
Nguyen Huu Chanh replied:

As for communists, if we can stop their activities, at any time, at any opportunity, we will do it. When we have a chance to kill them to avenge my people, then that chance will not slip by. We always respect the law, but if they act first we must take action.
Jenny Brockie then asked:

Do you understand that it's against the law in Australia to incite or encourage any offence, anything that would be considered an offence? You are suggesting that people be killed. You are calling for people to be killed.
Nguyen Huu Chanh replied:

We know it's illegal but we ask you, if you were in our position standing facing an enemy who had killed our parents, plundered our property, abused our people, what would you think in my position? If my countrymen don't oppose the communists then the communists will expand idenfinitely. I must be ready to sacrifice myself.
Is the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) ready to sacrifice himself?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Nguyen Huu Chanh continued:

SPEECH.PARA: If that is seen as a criminal act then I will feel proud of the crime to save my country.

It seems to me to be incomprehensible that people such as Mr Nguyen Huu Chanh can make statements inciting fellow Vietnamese to kill communists and, by implication, Australians who are perceived to be supporting the Vietnamese Government, without some action being taken against them. More than 70,000 Vietnamese refugees have come to Australia to find housing and jobs and to provide an education for their children. They deserve, as all Australians deserve, to be protected against the vicious hatred and incitement to violence which is preached by political agitators such as Mr Nguyen Huu Chanh and, also, Mr Le Dang Can, the editor of a Vietnamese community newspaper, the Belle of Saigon. The Four Corners program reported that an article in the newspaper called for an end to timidity in the fight against communists and stressed the need for their elimination. That is indicated in this extract from the newspaper:

We are bound by a law of a free nation, but we should find loopholes. To achieve success is the important thing. The term `non-violence' does not correspond to struggle against the communists. To struggle means to sacrifice; to sacrifice means to shed blood.

Four days later, more than 200 angry Vietnamese besieged a church hall in inner city Sydney. Windows were smashed and bricks were hurled into the hall as a small group of left wing Australians tried to watch a film about Vietnam. Members of the audience fled the building in fear. In Melbourne angry refugees disrupted another left wing meeting. At about the same time in Sydney another meeting of sympathisers with the Hanoi regime, mainly attended by non-Vietnamese, was the subject of a furious attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make only a brief comment on the speech of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I am sure from my own experience of Vietnamese refugees living in this country-the more than 70,000 to whom the honourable member referred-that nearly all of them, with virtually no exception, similarly would deplore any incitement to violence, as we do. I would hope that the occasion of one over-excited extremist would in no way be taken to reflect on the Indo-Chinese community which has settled in Australia and is contributing so much to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise also to speak on the estimates for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I have been concerned for a little time about the drift in the debate on immigration, particularly as it has taken place in this chamber. When I saw the Budget and saw the estimates of expenditure for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I was similarly a little concerned about some of the cuts in programs. I was astonished today when the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), in answering a question on the subject of the Hawke Government's new initiatives, referred in glowing terms to the programs the Government has in place and what the Minister referred to as new programs. In fact, nearly everything he mentioned was in no sense a new program; indeed, not even a Hawke Government initiated program.

I believe it is important that we have bipartisanship in our immigration debate, but I do not believe that bipartisanship is mindless me-too-ism. The Minister cannot have it both ways. He has come in here on several occasions and answered questions from his own side, whether initiated by the back bench or not, used that opportunity to attack falsely Ministers of the Fraser Government and policies of the coalition when in government and in opposition, and then proposed as his own or the Hawke Government's policies which are nothing of the sort. If he is going to take that line on such spurious grounds, he will find the bipartisanship on immigration falling apart at his feet.

I refer particularly to those matters that were mentioned today. The quid pro quo in bipartisanship is that credit is given where credit is due. As I have indicated, the Minister was asked a question about the new initiatives the Hawke Government had undertaken to ensure an equitable share of access to programs and services for migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent initiatives, too.
—Yes, a very good question and one which I was hanging on for the answer to, because I expected it to be as disappointing as it was. The Minister said in his answer:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this Government has taken initiatives to ensure that some affirmative action is taken to overcome the disabilities suffered by migrants.

People interested in issues affecting migrants would agree with the desirability of that. The Minister went on to say that the Fraser Government had `totally ignored the needs of migrants, and particularly of those migrants with a non-English speaking background, who have special disabilities'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a shameful thing to say.
—As my colleague the honourable member for Mayo said, it is a shameful thing to say; it is not true. I will refer to that in a moment. The Minister, going on to blow his own trumpet, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will go through the list of things that our Government has done.
This is the list of things the Hawke Government has done:
We have made information available to migrants in their own languages, provided translation services, migrant resource centres and facilities for learning languages and so on.

I do not know what the `and so on' is, but I shall refer to those particular items one by one. Certainly this Government makes information available to migrants in their own languages. It provides translation services and funds migrant resource centres and some facilities for learning languages, but none of those are Hawke Government initiatives. A number of them go back a number of years and were funded generously by the Fraser Government. In fact, the specific migrant resource centres, to which the Minister referred, were initiated by the Fraser Government.

The Budget figures show the priority that this Government gives to migrant support programs. I will refer very quickly to a number of items. We are told in the Budget Papers that the inflation assumption is 7 per cent, so we take it that increases of 7 per cent are just increases for inflation. I will refer to some of the important programs and the Government's attitude towards them. I am sure that the migrant groups in our community are well aware of these figures. I am sure that they are well aware of the facts and the reality of what has happened to programs under the Hawke Government and are in no way blinded by the rhetoric that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs treated them to in Question Time today.

For example, under the item for assistance for migrant resource centres, we find that there has been an increase of approximately the inflation factor over the estimate for last year. It is very good that the funds are being maintained but it is not exactly anything to blow our trumpet about. On the other hand, voluntary agencies and community groups who are funded or assisted with funds for expenses associated with refugees have suffered a reduction in funds in money terms of 2.4 per cent and a reduction of 12.6 per cent against last year's estimate. This year they will receive $546,500. If they had received an increase just to cover inflation they would have received $600,000. As to the programs for initial settlement orientation activities-one would think they are very important in helping new settlers arrive and a very significant contribution to our immigration programs in the terms in which the Minister spoke today-funding this year has been reduced by 39 per cent against expenditure last year. This year those programs receive $90,000. If the appropriation had been increased merely for inflation they would have received nearly $158,000.

The contribution from the Federal Government to the National Accreditation Authority for translators and interpreters is to be reduced by 14 per cent compared with the amount spent last year. Funding for accommodation and services for refugees and migrants at migrant centres and flats has been reduced by 20 per cent as against the amount actually expended last year. Funding for language services has increased by 7.9 per cent. Funding for the adult migrant education program has increased in a very welcome way, but if it had increased by the inflation factor it would be several million dollars higher than it is. Migrant welfare organisations will receive an increase of 12 per cent over what was spent last year. If one takes that item together with the item for assistance to voluntary agencies one finds that the appropriations even out, so there is a shift of emphasis. The Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, an important voice and organ for migrant groups in Australia, has received no increase at all. If it had received an increase just for inflation its appropriation would be not the $85,000 given to it but, in fact, $91,000.

But the really outstanding figure in this table of figures is that which relates to grants to trade unions for activities to assist migrants in industry. Now that was an initiative of the Hawke Government that the Minister did not think to mention today. What is the story there? The appropriation for this year as compared with last year has increased by 62 per cent. That gives us an idea of the Government's priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent, excellent!

—One could make a case for that being excellent but, in fact, these moneys are essentially going towards subsidising trade unions to sign up migrants. In certain circumstances that may be a worthwhile activity, but if it is only a means of recruitment, a means of gaining even more access to financial resources, it needs a rather better justification. It is very difficult in any event to see how trade unions in Australia need a 62 per cent increase in funds when support for refugee programs, for example, has been effectively reduced. The final figure, and a very telling one, is that relating to expenditure for the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, which has been reduced by 24 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: So much for the new programs. The Minister today referred to the fact that he will acquire reports from other departments on what they are doing. I think that is a worthwhile initiative and I hope that the Minister will get some very good action out of it, but a reference to the Notice Paper, to questions on notice and answers given to them, tells a different story.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak mainly on one aspect of education. But I cannot let the occasion pass without referring to a speech made earlier in this debate in regard to Indo-Chinese refugees and their alleged attitudes. Whilst obviously I do not support the encouragement of violence, one must think about what those people have undergone, the way in which they were persecuted and many of their relatives were killed. It would be ridiculous to assume that such people, when confronted by their persecutors, the people who have killed their relatives, would not, at least by word of mouth, utter some threats against those people. Obviously, there is nothing they can do about it and nothing they ought to do about it. But it would be ridiculous to assume that they would be happy about visits to this country by Vietnamese officials, and that they would not express some disgust.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to honourable members who have views that are different from mine on this issue that in my electorate there are refugees from Indo-China and from some of the South American countries such as Chile. If a participant in the current Chilean Government visited this country, I would say that the Chilean refugees currently in Australia would express similar views, vis-a-vis the Chilean officials, probably with the support of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) who spoke earlier.

Let me deal with a particular aspect of education that concerns me. We speak often in Australia about having a highly-educated community. It is said that people ought to be getting into technological and scientific sorts of occupations, rather than the sorts of things that many people are involved in now. One of my greatest concerns with regard to education is the lack of numeracy-the lack of people who leave schools and universities, as I will attempt to show the Committee, without real numeracy skills. I think that cannot be solved at the university level. Obviously, it must be solved at the primary and secondary school level. I shall deal most specifically with New South Wales because that is the State about which I know most. In New South Wales, in order to gain entry to a university or other tertiary institution, a student's mark in the higher school certificate is considered. The mark is taken from the ten best papers from a score of 500. In other words, if a student gets a mark of 250, it is in effect 50 per cent. For the benefit of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) a score of 300 equals 60 per cent, et cetera.

Let us look at what actually happens. I would have hoped that one would assume that the people who are going to become teachers of mathematics in a secondary school would have fairly highly developed intellectual abilities which are reflected possibly in the marks they gain in their higher school certificate. The reasons for the different figures required, of course, are not necessarily the fault of the universities, although it is to some extent; it is because of the number of people applying to enter courses. To enter the Bachelor of Human Movement Science course at the University of Wollongong, which concerns dancing I assume, the mark required is 319 out of 500. In order to enter the Bachelor of Education course to teach secondary mathematics, the required mark is 246-less than 250, or 50 per cent. The mark required to enter the Bachelor of Human Movement Science course-dancing-is 319; the mark required to enter the Bachelor of Education course, which concerns physical and health education-in other words, teaching people how to run-is 321.

I refer honourable members to the situation at similar universities. At the Sydney Institute of Education, a Diploma of Teaching-Bachelor of Education for primary schools requires a mark of 268. To get the same degree in mathematics at the secondary level requires a mark of 246. At the Newcastle College of Advanced Education, to get a Diploma of Teaching-Bachelor of Education in mathematics requires a mark of 240-ten points below a pass mark. A Diploma of Teaching-Bachelor of Education for secondary maths at the Mitchell College of Advanced Education requires a mark of 240. However, to get an Associate Diploma in Recreation requires a mark of 324 and if one wants to go for leisure studies it is 316, whether it is full time or part time. I do not know whether it is part time leisure studies or a part time course in leisure studies. The point I am trying to make obviously is that the situation is ridiculous.

At the Riverina College of Advanced Education, a Diploma in Computing (Wagga), which must be a special kind of computing, requires a mark of 220 out of 500. That is to become a computer operator. What do we expect from our kids at school if we are going to expose them to mathematics teachers at the secondary level who themselves got marks, but did not get passes, at the 220 levels or the 240 level-levels which to me quite clearly indicate that in the vast majority of cases, and there obviously would be exceptions, they have not really shown an ability to understand the subject themselves? Those teachers are let loose onto our kids.

There are many similar examples. However, I do not want to bore the Committee with them because I promised the Whip that I would take only five minutes. I do think that it is an important issue. It is not peculiar to New South Wales. I quote from an article in the Sunday Mail in Brisbane:
No place shock for TE students.
I do not know how they score there. It probably is out of 3,000. The article continues:
Physical education, 900 score, a tougher task than physics, 840 score.

For physical education one has to have 60 more points than one requires to teach physics. I am sorry that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), my colleague from Parramatta, is not here because he probably thinks physical education is one of the most important subjects to teach. As a nation we are much more likely to be able to compete with the rest of the world if we have people trained in science, mathematics or some sort of ability to think logically rather than the ability to do exercises. I think it is probably not basically a question for the Federal Government.

We can approach this matter in two possible ways. One way obviously is to get more people interested in becoming maths teachers rather than dancing teachers. Therefore, the level will rise. But that is probably not possible because the teachers those people themselves had who taught them physical education and dancing were probably better than the teachers who taught them maths. We have a vicious cycle there. The second way is possibly for the Federal Government to decide not to pay for tertiary education courses for people to become maths teachers who have not got more than 220 points out of 500 at the higher school certificate level, or only to do so in very, very exceptional cases if potential students can show that there was a good reason for their getting that sort of low mark. I do appeal to honourable members to think about those sorts of issues and how we can make our young people more numerate. Hopefully, that is not only a question of science and numeracy; but to my mind numeracy leads to the ability to think logically about all kinds of issues, including the issues that we ought to be considering in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining this debate on appropriations, like the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) I wish to make some preliminary remarks concerning the comments of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I think that all of us are increasingly disturbed at the propensity of some honourable members in both this House and the other place to name persons almost like the dropping of confetti at a wedding. In doing so, we are facing an increasingly cynical public, who believe that we abuse the privileges of this Parliament so easily and without foundation. Tonight we had a classic example of that when the honourable member for La Trobe seized on a Vietnamese refugee who, in a moment of weakness, spoke in very exaggerated language. I also saw that Four Corners program. In no way were those remarks, I believe, meant to be taken literally, nor were they meant to be taken as representative of the Vietnamese community in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Prospect said, many persons from South East Asia have suffered in a way that very few of us in this chamber-God willing-will suffer in our lifetimes. Such people can be excused exaggerated or flowery language. After all, we have only to think back to the comments made yesterday by a Minister of this Government when he used exaggerated, threatening language on the floor of this chamber. I quote from the Hansard report of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) addressing the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman):
If you ever do that to me again, I will smash you in the face.
We know that Hansard contains the polite version, because an expletive was deleted. However, that expletive was sent out by Australian Associated Press.

My point is this: At times of stress, in particular, persons will resort, in moments of weakness-on many occasions, unforgivable weakness-to threatening language. I wish to say no more than that on this matter, but I think that the comments of the honourable member for La Trobe were racist, because he did not make it clear that they were not meant to slur all Vietnamese refugees of a certain political persuasion.

Turning now to the debate, I wish to direct my comments to the Department of Education appropriations and to one specific aspect of that Department which is causing concern to me and many Opposition members. I refer to the 50 per cent cutback in the participation and equity program. This cutback was announced in the May mini-Budget. Sadly, the mistake that has been made, and this is increasingly clear, is that the cutback was to both secondary schools and technical and further education. I do not believe that the secondary school system properly utilised PEP funding, and there is a very good case to be made for a significant reduction, almost approaching abolition, of funding for PEP within secondary schools; but the TAFE component of PEP has worked very successfully, particularly in rural areas. The more isolated the area, the more successful the TAFE program. Indeed, I say as an aside that many of the secondary schools in the isolated areas of Gippsland and other parts of Australia utilised what little PEP funding they received. Therefore, I am appealing to the Government to look again at the across the board cut in PEP and to recognise the valuable achievements of the TAFE components of PEP.

I should like to draw on three examples from my electorate of Gippsland. The first is the East Gippsland access program, which is directed towards isolated unemployed youths and a number of Aboriginals. The problem is that this program extends into areas such as Buchan and Omeo, and even Bonang and Mallacoota. I would not hold it against any member of this Parliament for not being familiar with such names, given that they are small areas, but they are very important. The unemployed youth in those areas have literally nothing to assist them first in obtaining a job, and then in acquiring the skills, competence and discipline necessary to hold on to that job.

The second program to which I refer is the Sale access program which is directed towards unemployed youth aged between 15 and 24 years. Sale is a large regional centre which has a population of well over 10,000 people. Yet it has no unemployment program for those youths not engaged in traineeships or work study programs other than the access program. I have inspected that program, and others in my electorate, on numerous occasions and I know the work that is being achieved.

The third program, which is in South Gippsland, based at Leongatha, is the affirmative action program for unemployed youth. This program is also aimed at youth between the ages of 15 and 24 years. Again, one has to look at the geography. This is an area which is separated by distance and a lack of public transport from, if you like, the Princes Highway belt-which includes the towns of the La Trobe Valley, Moe and Warragul-which has at least some support systems for unemployed youth. Consequently, if the Government is not able to assist unemployed youth-I and those involved in those programs do not believe they will be picked up by the traineeship programs or the work study programs; these TAFE programs seek to assist the unemployed youth who will not fall within the niche that the Government seeks to create in its traineeship program-the problem will be about where those people will go. The Gippsland Regional and TAFE Board had its funding cut from $500,000 to $231,000. Sadly, the Board had no choice but to make a decision to reduce all Gippsland TAFE programs by 50 per cent rather than list programs in priority, one against another.

One of the problems has been that the Government has taken far too long to issue directives and guidelines to TAFE as to how the funding should occur and what principles ought to be enacted regarding the reduced funding. It was not until approaching late August that these principles were forwarded to the State TAFE boards. That created a great deal of uncertainty. That uncertainty is compounded because if these TAFE programs in isolated areas fall away with this reduced funding, as they most certainly will within the next few months, we will lose the workers, the teachers, as well as the structure that has been painstakingly set up over some years now. If those people leave the area we will not be able to attract them back. The great tragedy is that these programs are working well. A government which approaches a problem in such a broad way and paints all those involved in PEP funding with the same brush is making a grave error which will have the most significant consequences for rural Australia.

What is needed, therefore, is to restore funding for the TAFE component of PEP, particularly in country areas. The Government needs to differentiate between TAFE and secondary schools. They are very different, with different objectives, accountability and efficiency. After all, I understand that TAFE administration costs are only one per cent of total costs. The problem with PEP funding in the large secondary schools, particularly in urban areas, was that they would be funded simply by way of Consolidated Revenue and the funds would be lost. A number of high schools throughout the more isolated parts of Gippsland have taken great advantage of PEP funding, but those schools truly are a minority. What I am saying is that one can generalise and say that the Gippsland TAFE programs have been of tremendous benefit to unemployed youth who, at present, have no other source of training and, frankly, will not have any other source of training whatever program the Government has on its drawing boards.

TALK.START.PARA: -Before calling the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), I would like to correct a statement by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) regarding the remarks made by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) yesterday. The remarks made by the Minister were accurately recorded in Hansard. The statements that were issued by the media were incorrect. I call the honourable member for La Trobe.
—Mr Chairman, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In the previous speech, delivered by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), he said that I did not make it clear that I was not casting a slur on the entire Vietnamese community. When he made those remarks he was talking about a speech which I delivered in this chamber about half an hour earlier. That was a complete misrepresentation of what I said. In fact, I referred to a small number of political agitators. I made it quite clear that the 70,000 Vietnamese refugees in Australia are member's of a law-abiding community who have come here for peace and should be protected against violent people. It was the honourable member's Party that wanted to refuse to allow Indo-Chinese refugees to come to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a series of estimates tonight. I make a few comments in regard to the responsibility of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). The success of Australia's migration program over a long period of time, I believe, has been due to the fact that there has been a large degree of bipartisanship in the broad parameters of our programs. I draw the attention of the House to the introductory comments of one of the reports of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia which speaks of a broadly based, bipartisan policy on immigration, multiculturalism and community relations. The Minister, of course, understands that that does not mean that there is complete agreement on every aspect of migration programs or on the way in which ethnic affairs programs are dealt with. It would be non-constructive if the Opposition did not criticise or offer alternative ideas or for the Government, in response, to take for granted the things said by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are dealing with particularities, some of which I would like to bring to the attention of the House and the Australian people. I regret to inform the House that I believe that, despite valiant efforts by the current Minister, much of our current program appears to be a selection process by administrative delay. I know that the Minister is aware of these problems and that he has used his best endeavours to overcome them, but much more needs to be done. It is an unsatisfactory set of circumstances whereby delays of inordinate length can take place for applicants for migration, for change of status or for any other of the processes in migration programs.

Some of the details of current programs warrant careful scrutiny despite the Minister's obvious enthusiasm for his portfolio. In regard to the welfare services area, I was distressed to receive a Press release from the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales indicating that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has either removed or put to one side 12 welfare officers in the migrant service unit of the Department, which officers have been supplying a valuable service to various ethnic groups in New South Wales. The move has left depleted some important communities in regard to their access to and understanding of welfare services in the Department of Social Security, health services and others.

I would like the Minister to explain what has happened because, if this is an example of so-called mainstreaming, he had better check to see whether the departments that are going to supply direct services for migrant communities are well-equipped to deal with the flood of inquiries they will require. I thank the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) for the questions he placed on notice in regard to the linguistic skills of officers within service providing departments and their capacity to deal with migrant inquiries or non-English speaking inquiries. The results of those questions were quite appalling. It would be unfortunate if there were a move to mainstreaming or casting off of migrant services and welfare services of the type about which I have been speaking if departments could not meet the demands and inquiries they would face. I predict that unless urgent action is taken they will not be able to meet those inquiries. There are few departments which have within them more than one or two foreign language speakers who are properly accredited and can give the service that is required. I do not think that in those circumstances one can depend on telephone interpreter services to meet the needs of those who are seeking over the counter the services of departments.

I think the Minister is well aware of the complications that may arise from the new system of applying for migration to Australia. The single form approach which has been adopted has created in the Budget an extraordinary increase in the size of administrative costs at overseas missions. I believe that that large predicted cost arises because of the anticipated exceptionally heavy work loads at foreign missions. The form will place outside the knowledge of the Department within Australia details of applicants. This cuts off the link between people seeking to have family reunions and their relatives seeking to apply through foreign missions. It will be somewhat confused and daunting when long delays take place for which there are no apparent explanations.

The Minister is also aware of the confusion that has been created with departure taxes. The current proposition is, as I understand it, that the departure tax for Australian citizens and residents will double to $40 and departure tax will not be paid by visitors and tourists. The mini-Budget cost cutting exercise in moving departure taxes across to airlines to administer will create confusion if it is introduced on 1 January. So many problems have not been solved with this proposal that the Australian community is bound to suffer. The unfair way in which these taxes will apply-and, once formulated, what sort of taxes will apply-will be most unfortunate and damaging to the community.

The fees imposed by the Minister for applications for migration, changes of status, temporary entry and other factors in the migration area make it a very expensive exercise to deal with in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Fees of up to $200 will be charged for change of status on work related grounds and a fee of $100 will be charged for applications for migration. That is to some extent preying upon those who are seeking to make a better life for themselves. It is a revenue gathering exercise which the Minister claims will provide additional services to the community. I cannot find anything in the Budget Papers to indicate that the Department will hang on to that money and provide it directly across to other services, or whether it will become part of general revenue.

The current debate on the Special Broadcasting Service and whether it should be subsumed into the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is causing grave concern around Australia. It is my view that the ABC has not proved itself capable of running its own show, so why should it take on this additional responsibility? The SBS has a good reputation, has operated in a comparatively cost-effective manner, and the current debate needs to be put to rest in a proper way. I believe that putting the SBS in with the ABC is not an answer to the Government's current problems.

I conclude by saying to the Minister that I believe that the decision with respect to the representative of the South West Africa People's Organisation, compared with some of the decisions made accurately in legal terms but not too thoughtfully in terms of common humanity, is one that many groups will find hard to understand. Special decisions to vary conditions applying to visitors who must undertake to abide by certain provisions within Australia were taken by two Ministers. That type of decision will encourage those who wish to preach subversion or terrorist activity to think that they will have some sort of ready access to Australia if they are abusive enough. I do not think that is good enough; nor is it consistent with proper ministerial discretion to be humane to all individuals. Currently a couple of deportations have caused concern. They were legally applied, but a special decision for SWAPO agents is hardly thought of by most communities in Australia as a fair decision.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a few contributions in relation to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I promised the Leader of the House (Mr Young) that I would be brief, but I want at least to acknowledge those contributions. I say to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) that I hope that when he makes such contributions as he did this evening he will make it clear that the actions of just a couple of people, although they are unacceptable actions of violence, are not portrayed in such a way that they inflict on the whole community a reputation that is undeserved. That applies to Vietnamese violence in our community. There is not much of it. We have to understand that the lives of so many of these Vietnamese have been sadly disrupted and obviously they are very resentful of those who have so disrupted their lives. Nevertheless, that is not an excuse for violence. We carefully monitor them. My Department and I spend a lot of time consulting with the leaders and making sure that they understand why certain people are visiting this country, whether they be students from North Vietnam or wherever they come from, so that they will not take part in violent activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) gave us a list of ups and downs when it came to the various parts of the settlement program which is the responsibility of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I remind her that for a long time now the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters has had a policy applied to it by respective governments of moving to being self-supporting, and when an organisation moves to being self-supporting, of course, its appropriation will be reduced. I welcome the fact that she is taking an interest in this area of immigration and ethnic affairs, but there is a lot to learn. If she wants a briefing from my Department, as the new shadow Minister and the previous shadow Minister did, I will make sure that she is given the benefit of such a briefing as the chairperson of her Party's immigration committee.

Had she had such a briefing she would have understood that the reductions in the expenditure on migrant centres is related to the reduction in the number of refugees. We can have differences over whether there ought to be a reduction in the number of refugees, but obviously when a policy decision like that is taken we will have a reduction in the expenditure on the places where they go to live. More than that, of course, we are going into a rationalisation of these migrant centres, getting away from-the communal living and making sure that in future hopefully there will be independent living units so that we can persuade people to stay longer in these migrant centres while they go through their programs of initiation into this country.

Lastly, I make no apologies for the reduction in expenditure on the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Much of the expenditure in the last few years has gone on mega-research projects which could have been done in a much more effective and efficient way by university departments. I would be happy to make sure that the honourable member for Moncrieff learns more about the rejuvenation of AIMA this financial year. I believe it will be a much more effective organisation and at last the community will learn about it.

I tell the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) that the 12 welfare officers who are being moved within the New South Wales regional office of my Department will not, in any way, affect services to migrants in New South Wales. Those services will continue to operate at the same level as they have in the past. There is a change in status within the existing average operative staffing level and administrators in the New South Wales office assure me that it will mean a more effective office. It is nothing more nor less than a redeployment within the Department and has nothing to do with the so called mainstreaming. `Mainstreaming' is a jargon word which I hope to get rid of. It relates to services for migrants in other departments of government. Because that word is misunderstood I hope the honourable member will join with me in not using it and talking about equitable access to the services and programs of government instead. I hope that he will support the initiatives that we are taking to make sure that the programs and services of other departments are maintained to see that there is affirmative action for migrants so that they will get equitable access to those programs and services.

The honourable member was pretty good at finding areas where we can spend more money. I assure him that I too would love to have extra funds in order to be more generous in certain areas. But I come back to the overall thrust of the Government's policy in making sure that we continue with the magnificent economic recovery that is taking place. Part of the need has been to reduce relatively government spending so that there is less pressure on the capital markets of this country. That is being achieved and jobs are being created. I understand from the rhetoric of the honourable member's colleagues, if not his own, but I think he would indulge in this from time to time, that his Party wants to reduce government spending by $2 billion. I therefore suggest that the honourable member become a little consistent in this matter and tell us where we might save money in some of these programs, rather than suggest where we should be spending it. I assure the honourable member that the sponsorship change is working well. I have reports from all round the world that our overseas offices are not being burdened by the change in the methods by which sponsors are bringing their relatives to this country. The departure tax rumours to which he gives credence are totally unfounded. We were waiting for decisions on the tax package before putting into effect what was announced in the 19 May statement, but he will find before 1 January next that good administrative arrangements have been made.

I do not believe that the increase in fees is excessive. We have to recover costs in many areas. This is particularly so in some of the expensive areas of immigration. The honourable member mentioned the Special Broadcasting Service. It does not come under my control but under the control of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). The matter is causing grave concern. We will be making decisions in government as soon as possible so that rumors about what might happen will not continue to circulate. I believe that what the Government will decide will be totally acceptable to the migrant community.

The honourable member also mentioned controversial visitors and representatives of the South West Africa People's Organisation in particular. I believe that in this liberal democracy of ours we should be able to let in almost anybody who wants to come to this country. We should be able to match such people argument for argument. However, we draw the line, and I think the honourable member does too, where terrorism is blatantly supported. I do not believe that anybody we have had in this country recently blatantly supported terrorism as the only means of achieving their objectives. For example, the SWAPO delegate who came here for a particular conference did not cause much concern during his time here. I thank all honourable members who took part in this debate and I trust that we will have other debates on the important subject of immigration on a future occasion when it is not so late at night.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Progress reported.

(6) Will the Government adopt the Royal Commission's recommendation that the United States Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organisations Statute, with its sweeping provisions for the annihilation of illegally procured profits be adopted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) the Government has every confidence that the additional resources supplied to the Australian Taxation Office and to law enforcement authorities are being used effectively in the fight against crime. Futher steps are being taken through the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill currently before Parliament to widen the powers of the NCA to provide broader access to taxation records and strengthen the fight against organised crime as well as tax evasion. The charter of objectives and priorities of the Australian Federal Police which was tabled in the Parliament on 10 September 1985 has also been revised to give greater emphasis to the investigation of drug trafficking, organised crime and major frauds against the revenue.

(2) No. SP bookmaking is essentially a State matter. Commonwealth and State Racing and Police Ministers met on 7 February 1985 to discuss the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on SP bookmaking. The Conference endorsed the concept of a co-ordinated approach between the States and a review of relevant legislation to provide uniformity. The Commonwealth does not favour amending the definition of ``relevant offence'' under the National Crime Authority Act specifically to include illegal SP bookmaking, given that the States have not increased the penalties for such offences to the level prescribed therein (3 years' imprisonment).

(3) I understand that the Conference of State Racing and Police Ministers proposes to refer the matter of co-ordination of intelligence on illegal bookmaking to the Australian Police Ministers' Council for consideration.
(4) This is a matter for individual States.

(5) As noted by the Acting Prime Minister and Attorney-General on 18 December 1984 and repeated on 21 May 1985 in my Statement on the Government's response to the Costigan Royal Commission Final Report, the Government rejects as a means of combating criminal activity the policy of public exposure of persons suspected of criminal activities. There is no place in our legal system for guilt by accusation or denunciation. This would contravene fundamental civil rights.

(6) The specific style of legislation embodied in the American Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organisations Statute is not appropriate for our situation, given the constitutional differences between the United States and Australian systems. However, proposals for uniform forfeiture of assets legislation similar to the forefeiture provisions contained in the United States Statute have been drafted by a joint working group of officials from the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG). The Government is currently considering the form legislation should take.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 107 (1) (c) of the Social Security Act enables unemployment benefit to be paid for a period when a person is unemployed and capable and willing to undertake, and taking reasonable steps to obtain, suitable paid work. A person in full-time vocational training and/or study would not generally be regarded as unemployed but may be eligible for an education or training allowance, subject to requirements such as course appropriateness and study progress.

The Government proposes to progressively reorganise education allowance and unemployment benefits for young people, to remove financial disincentives to participation in education and training for those from low income families. It also intends to ensure that constructive options in education and training are available to all young people. Part of this long term strategy is the introduction of traineeships which will provide appropriate remuneration, rather than unemployment benefit.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: List of Gluten Free Food Information

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he update the gluten-free commercial food list (a) in 1985 and (b) annually.
(2) Will he ensure that the list is made widely available to the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Currently, my Department is updating the 1982-83 edition of the List of Gluten Free Food Information. It is anticipated that the revised list will be available at the end of this year or early 1986 and, provided resources are available, it will be updated annually.

(2) In the past, my Department has made the list freely available to the public on request. However, in recent months officers of my Department have become concerned about the increasing self-prescription of restrictive dietary regimens such as the gluten-free diet.

Restriction of dietary intake by exclusion of an entire group of foods, such as those containing gluten, can result in inadequate intakes of some essential nutrients. For this reason, and especially in children, it is important that a correct diagnosis is made before the start of any kind of elimination diet. Appropriate management should ensure that nutritionally adequate food sources are used in place of the foods avoided. A qualified dietitian should provide help with food selection and meals following diagnosis by and referral from a doctor. Also elimination of gluten-containing foods from the diet of either children or adults before diagnosis may make eventual differential diagnosis both difficult and more time consuming for the patient.

For these reasons it is now the policy of my Department to provide the List of Gluten Free Food Information to doctors, dietitians, Coeliac Societies and individual members of the public with a medical or a dietetic prescription. With this policy a patient with a genuine need, that is with, eg., diagnosed coeliac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis, will have access to essential information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Attorney-General set out the current guidelines for the grant of legal aid to people involved in cases arising out of commercial or business transactions.
(2) When were the guidelines promulgated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Legal aid is provided principally by the independent State and Territory legal aid commissions and by the Australian Legal Aid Office (ALAO). The ALAO currently operates in New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Each legal aid commission has its own policy that is relevant to the granting of assistance. It would be appropriate for the honourable member to seek relevant information from each commission concerning the availability of assistance in cases arising out of commercial or business transactions.

As to the granting of aid by the ALAO, the Office does not have a specific formal policy applicable to cases arising out of commercial or business transactions. As with all applications for assistance, the Office is required to have regard to all relevant circumstances in determining whether it is reasonable to provide assistance. This includes having regard to the nature and extent of any benefit that may accrue to the applicant from the provision of assistance or of any detriment that the applicant may suffer if the assistance is not provided and, in the case of a proceeding, the likelihood of the proceeding terminating in a manner favourable to the applicant. When assessing applications for aid in connection with disputes arising out of matters that are essentially commercial or business transactions, in the context of assessing the `reasonableness' of the application, the Office will not ordinarily approve a grant of assistance unless there are special circumstances, such as where the applicant's livelihood, or family home, are placed at risk. The Office gives a low priority to commercial or business disputes so as to ensure that legal aid funds are spread as widely over as many cases as possible, and directed to those persons most in need in the community.
(2) Guidelines dealing specifically with the availability of legal aid in connection with cases arising out of commercial or business transactions have not been issued by the ALAO.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Penrith City Council: Acquisition of Land

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did lots 1 and 4, DP542402, part of the former Royal Australian Air Force Barracks area in High Street, Penrith, New South Wales, become the property of Penrith City Council.
(2) Was the price paid for the land by Penrith City Council $1,725,000.
(3) Was this the value placed on the property in a valuation by the Australian Taxation Office dated 23 March 1983.
(4) Did the New South Wales Valuer-General give the value of the property at 26 January 1981 as $1,850,000.
(5) What was the reason for the fall in the value of the property over that period.

(6) Was an offer for the property received before the sale to Penrith City Council by (a) Mr F. Hodgkinson, a member of the family of Mr F. W. Young who was one of the owners of the land when it was resumed in 1941 or (b) any other person; if so, for what amount.
(7) Did he advise Mr Hodgkinson in a letter, dated 6 September 1983, that he had decided not to exercise his discretion to offer the Hodgkinson family a chance to purchase the land.
(8) Did he subsequently give as one of the reasons for not exercising this discretion the fact that the Commonwealth had made substantial improvements to the land since acquiring it.
(9) Did the Australian Taxation Office valuation of 23 March 1983 state that the improvements added no value to the land.
(10) What is the reason for the discrepancy between the valuation and his letter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Contracts for the sale of the land were exchanged with Penrith City Council on 13 April 1984 and the sale completed on 11 May 1984. NOTE-The property sold to Penrith City Council comprised Lots 1, 3 and 4 DP542402.

(5) My Department does not have details of the method and basis of the New South Wales Valuer-General's valuation assessment of the property as at 26 January 1981. It is understood, however, that the Valuer-General's valuation is based on a ``ratable value'' as opposed to a ``current market'' value. The latter was the basis of the Commonwealth's valuation.
(6) (a) Yes. No amount specified. (b) Yes. No amounts specified.
(8) Yes, this was one of a number of reasons contained in the then Minister's response.
(10) The Commonwealth's valuation was assessed on the basis of the highest and best use for the land, that is `general industrial'.
While the existing improvements did not add any value to the land for industrial use, this does not mean that the improvements had no value per se.
As noted in (8) above, this was one of a number of reasons given for the then Minister's decision not to offer the land for sale to the former owners. Those reasons in full were:

(a) Sections 53 (3) and 53 (4) of the Lands Acquisition Act specify that where land is being disposed of within seven years of its acquisition, the former owner should, as a general principle, have the first opportunity to purchase it back at a reasonable price provided the Commonwealth has not made substantial improvements to the land since its acquisition.
(b) The seven year time limit has expired.
(c) The former sole registered owner of the land at the time of acquisition was Mr F. W. Young, now deceased.
(d) The Commonwealth has made substantial improvements to the land since acquiring it.
(e) The Commonwealth incorporated the title of the land acquired from Mr Young with several others into one title.
(f) It is the practice where consolidation of titles has taken place not to make an offer where significant improvements have been made at Commonwealth expense or where the former owner is deceased.

(g) The land acquired was not part of a larger holding and previous Government decisions supported the principle that there is no need to offer the land to heirs where disposal is outside the seven year limit.
(h) No special circumstances existed to justify exercising discretion in favour of the claim made.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Second Sydney Airport: Royal Australian Air Force Base, Richmond

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has he or his Department made any representations to the Department of Defence about the possible use of Royal Australian Air Force Base Richmond as the second Sydney airport; if so, what was the response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No such representations have been made. The possibility of siting a second major civil airport at Richmond was examined and rejected in studies prior to the current Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme. No strong or compelling reason was found to reconsider such a suggestion in the current context.
